nyt_corpus_1987.har/01/12/0002982.xml	        It's never happened. In order to be chosen unanimously for enshrinement at Cooperstown, a player must be named on every ballot by those members of the Baseball Writers Association of America who vote in that year. The closest to perfection so far was Ty Cobb, one of the original five members of the Hall, who was named on ballots by 222 of the 226 voters in 1936, a 98.2 percentage. Others to come close were: Henry Aaron in 1982 with 406 of 415 for 97.8 percent; Honus Wagner and Babe Ruth in 1936, each with 215 of 226 for 95.1 percent, and Willie Mays in 1979 (409 of 432 for (94.6 percent).

nyt_corpus_1987.har/01/26/0007187.xml	        Lou Gehrig and Frank Robinson each fell one homer short of the feat of 50 homers and a batting title: Gehrig hit 49 for the Yankees when he led the league with .363 in 1934, and Robinson, another triple crown winner, also hit 49 when he led the league with a .316 average for the Baltimore Orioles in 1966. Three other Hall of Famers - Babe Ruth, Johnny Mize and Willie Mays - won batting titles and had 50-homer seasons in their careers, but never combined the achievements in the same year. nyt_corpus_1987.har/02/09/0011842.xml	        Not content to scour old newspapers for missing homers or stolen bases, Topp and his 42 colleagues, all members of the Society for American Baseball Research, seek accuracy as well on a player's name, date and place of birth, ethnic origin, height and weight. Of 12,864 listed major-leaguers since 1871, a total of 9,616 (or their descendants) have returned questionnaires to the committee, which also pores over birth certificates and organizes the occasional cemetery expedition to check tombstones. ''We change baseball history,'' Topp said. Among the committee's determinations is that Babe Ruth's father, George Herman Ehrhardt, gave his own name to the son (the family name was changed to Ruth at some unestablished point) and that long before Henry Louis Gehrig was so known, he had been given a very Teutonic name by his German-immigrant parents. Also uncovered: the fact that Pete Burg, an infielder with the 1910 Boston Braves, stood only 5 feet 1 inch instead of a listed 5-10, to say nothing of a 19th-century guy named Ryan who changed his identity to Sheehan on Sundays because his parents didn't want him playing Sunday ball.

nyt_corpus_1987.har/03/04/0018468.xml	        There are 37,000 Girl Scouts in New York City (of a total of nearly three million in the United States), and starting this summer many will sport the new outfits: pants or a pleated skirt with side closures, in royal blue instead of the time-honored green, and a white blouse with faint blue and green stripes, replacing a plaid blouse. (The uniforms will be introduced at the Kennedy Center in Washington next week at the national kickoff of the 75th anniversary of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A.) Meanwhile, two display windows in the lobby of the Empire State Building's main entrance on Fifth Avenue are already filled with Girl Scout memorabilia, including sketches of old uniforms (updated periodically according to passing styles), lunch boxes, recruitment posters, training manuals and a 1924 photograph of Babe Ruth buying a Girl Scout cookie. The historic items will be on view through the end of the month.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/03/05/0018885.xml	        ''McSorley's New York,'' produced and directed by Marcia Rock, focuses on a little piece of New York that, in a city of regular upheaval, seemingly refuses to change. Opened in 1854 as ''The Old House at Home'' by an Irish immigrant named John McSorley, the bar is still owned by an Irishman, Matt Maher, and still gets sawdust sprinkled on its floor each morning. On the walls are pictures of such famous patrons as Abraham Lincoln, Babe Ruth and Franklin Delano Roosevelt. In a city of drinking establishments, McSorley's has survived draft riots and Prohibition, depressions and gentrifications. As one devoted customer puts it, ''It's nice to have something that's enduring.''

nyt_corpus_1987.har/03/22/0023439.xml	        Love: There are many kinds of love in baseball; brotherhood among players, teacher-pupil relationships between managers and players, or players and fans. When Whitey Herzog and George Brett went to see a Kansas City Chiefs football game together the night before Herzog's Cardinals would play Brett's Royals in a 1985 World Series game, that was a beautiful teacher-pupil relationship. When the sick child that Babe Ruth supposedly saved grew up and visited the dying Ruth in return, that was love.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/03/23/0024073.xml	        This year the Yankees are abandoning run-of-the-mill season tickets in favor of what might best be called collector's items. The new, full-color tickets bear pictures of Yankee stars from Babe Ruth to Dave Winfield, attractively presenting as well such middle-era greats as Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle and Yogi Berra, who is shown leaping into the arms of Don Larsen after the latter's perfect game in the 1956 World Series. ''No club has the history of ours,'' said Art Adler, the team's marketing vice president, ''and this was one way of getting fans excited about the season.''
nyt_corpus_1987.har/03/29/0025331.xml	        SIXTY-ONE: The Team, the Record, the Men. By Tony Kubek and Terry Pluto. (Macmillan, $19.95.) In 1961, at the age of 25, Tony Kubek was the starting shortstop for the New York Yankees, arguably the best baseball team of all time. With Ralph Houk, its rookie manager, the team won 109 games, hitting an incredible 240 round-trippers, then soundly defeated the Cincinnati Reds in the World Series. But 1961 is most memorable for the assault by Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris on Babe Ruth's record 60 home runs. The country went wild. A stripper billed herself Mickey Maris. Fans checked daily box scores, noting the progress of the M and M boys more closely than they charted the Dow Jones. Sales of M & M candies soared. The pressure on both players was enormous, but it was Roger Maris who somehow earned the derision of the fans. On the last day of the season he did pop the record-breaking homer, but his hair fell out, he developed a rash and never again scaled the heights of that year. Mr. Kubek, who provides commentary for television's ''Game of the Week,'' and Terry Pluto, the co-editor of ''A Baseball Winter,'' help us remember that frenzied time. Peppered with anecdotes (like the time Whitey Ford and Mickey Mantle put pine tar in Mr. Ford's deodorant - which Yogi Berra had the annoying habit of borrowing), this is an insider's view: lively, entertaining and, perhaps best of all, nostalgic.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/04/05/0027237.xml	        LEAD: The Mets ended their 26th and final spring training in St. Petersburg today, and also ended 62 years of New York baseball presence in this city on the Gulf of Mexico where Babe Ruth and the Yankees once trained.

nyt_corpus_1987.har/04/08/0028339.xml	        Babe Ruth and any number of the sport's greatest players - as any competent history of the game discloses - were hard drinkers and roisterers. They're in the Hall of Fame, voted there by writers not known to be models of temperance. At almost any Old Timers' Game, some revered former center fielder or second baseman will be lionized, despite the fact that he played many a game with a hangover or booze on his breath. Grover Cleveland Alexander, who sometimes slept it off in the dugout, was respectfully portrayed in the movies by a future President.

He started the year with a total of 495 home runs, hit two last week and another on Tuesday night against Ron Darling. The last man to cross the threshhold of 500 was Reggie Jackson on Sept. 17, 1984. Now, Jackson has 548 and already ranks sixth on the list, which is headed by Henry Aaron at 755 and Babe Ruth at 714. nyt_corpus_1987.har/04/27/0034555.xml	        The list of the top 15 stopped at 41 times and Kiner did it 40 times during his career from 1946-55, placing him 16th to the leader, Babe Ruth with 72. Had there been a list of batters with three home runs in a game most often, Kiner certainly would have made it because his total of four times with the Pittsburgh Pirates (twice in 1947, once in 1948 and once in 1951) would have placed him second to the major league leader, Johnny Mize, who did it six times. For the record, Mize had only 30 two-homer games in his career, and neither he nor Kiner, both Hall ofFamers, ever hit four homers in a game. nyt_corpus_1987.har/05/05/0037136.xml	        The two young stars attended different high schools in Los Angeles -Strawberry played for Crenshaw, Davis for Fremont. But they played on the same team for two summers in a Senior Babe Ruth League. Strawberry was the right fielder, Davis the shortstop.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/05/06/0037510.xml	        The movie newsreel was a sort of People magazine of its day. Sandwiched between the local movie house's double features, newsreels presented glimpses of the lives of the rich and famous - Babe Ruth, Charles Lindbergh, Franklin D. and Eleanor Roosevelt, Joe Louis, Al Capone, John Dillinger, J. P. Morgan, Mussolini and Gandhi. There were views of disasters, royal marriages, frivolous and serious world championship contests, beauty contests and all the ''miss'' beauty parades -Miss Watermelon, Miss Cotton, Miss Peanut Butter and the like, all accompanied by appropriate commentary. The newsreel was, first of all, patriotic and moralistic and secondly, a slice of life.

The latest inning that Mays managed a home run was the 16th, at Candlestick Park on July 2, 1963. That drive, leading off the inning and coming off Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves, ended a scoreless pitching match between Spahn and Juan Marichal, both of whom are in the Hall of Fame, along with Mays. nyt_corpus_1987.har/05/15/0040387.xml	        Tony Calbi is a retired 74-year-old lifelong resident of Bristol. As a boy, he saw Babe Ruth play at Muzzy Field. ''He came through here many times, but I remember once he hit a home run to dead center field, over an old oak tree,'' Calbi recalled. ''I've only seen one other person do that - Ben Reilly.'' This Ben Reilly, suffice to say, did not make the Baseball Encyclopedia, but did play for the local factory team, New Departure. And in Bristol, if you're local, especially if you can hit or pitch, you're special.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/05/17/0041368.xml	        In the Negro Leagues, hundreds of black men made livings playing and managing in baseball on the other side of the color line. Teams like the Chicago American Giants, the Pittsburgh Crawfords, the Indianapolis ABC's, the Kansas City Monarchs, the Newark Eagles, the Homestead Grays and the St. Louis Stars roamed the country. The awesome hitters Josh Gibson (perhaps the premier powerhitter of his time, Babe Ruth notwithstanding) and Ray Dandridge; the pitcher Leroy (Satchel) Paige; the blazing baserunner James (Cool Papa) Bell, all plied their trade in the Negro Leagues.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/05/17/0041368.xml	        The supreme blow was struck in 1974, when Henry Aaron, late of the Negro League team the Indianapolis Clowns, broke Babe Ruth's home run record by hitting number 715. Baseball aficionados bickered over whether or not Aaron's record should be qualified - Aaron had not saved the league as Babe had, they cried, Aaron needed more times at bat to reach 714 than Ruth did, etc. There had been, of course, a similar debate in the case of Roger Maris, who in 1961 broke Ruth's single-season home run record, but the controversy over Aaron's feat had clear racist overtones. Among other slights, Commissioner Kuhn skipped the game in which Aaron broke the record, sending instead a black assistant, Monte Irvin.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/05/23/0043074.xml	        What would Eddie Shore, known as the Babe Ruth of hockey, have said about this? Shore, who played from 1926 through 1940, incurred fractures to his hip, collarbone and back, had a jaw that was broken five times, a nose broken 14 times, an ear that was virtually chewed off, and was a guy who witnessed all of his teeth being knocked out, and who needed 978 stitches in order to get through his 14-year career.

nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/02/0053629.xml	        The fuss involves Roger Maris, Babe Ruth, Frank Robinson, Wally Berger and Al Rosen, not to mention the American League pitchers who wish they could put a ''Do Not Disturb'' sign on their fastball when McGwire is batting. The fuss also involves the spelling of his name with a ''W'' instead of a ''U.'' That's ''W'' as in Wonderful or Wow. With 28 homers in the Athletics' first 74 games, the 6-foot-5-inch, 225-pound first baseman had as many home runs as Maris did in the Yankees' first 74 games in 1961. That, of course, was the year Maris hit 61 homers to break Babe Ruth's monument of 60, which had endured since 1927.

nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/06/0054639.xml	        It'll be 50 years old next month. York, a right-handed hitting catcher and third baseman who later was a fixture at first base, belted 18 home runs in August 1937, and no slugger has ever had a better month. Willie Mays of the San Francisco Giants came close with 17 in August 1965, and that stands as the National League record. York hit only 17 other homers in 1937 for a total of 35. Mays had 52 in 1965. When Babe Ruth hit 60 home runs for the Yankees in the 1927 season, the last 17 came in September, and that's the monthly record York eclipsed, as well as the 60-year-old standard that still stands for left-handed batters. QUESTION: In a tennis match, Player A returns Player B's serve with a right-handed backhand shot, then switches the racquet to his left hand and returns Player B's subsequent shot with a left-handed forehand? Is such a switch permissible during the playing of a point?

In it, the home run became commonplace and the game's popularity and prestige peaked.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/13/0056395.xml	        * McGwire, who began the season as a platooned infielder, hit only five home runs in the Athletics' first 28 games, then hit 14 in the next 20 games. He reaches the three-day All-Star break with a major league leading 33 home runs, including 11 in the last 16 games. In hitting 33 before the break, he has matched the number Roger Maris hit in the comparable period on his way to breaking Babe Ruth's record in 1961.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/13/0056427.xml	        LEAD: FOR more than half a century, the All-Star Game has been the barometer of the Yankees' season. To know how the Yankees were doing in any July, all anybody ever had to do was look at the American League team. In the beginning, Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Lefty Gomez dominated the All-Star rosters. When the Yankees were rolling to pennant after pennant, Joe DiMaggio, Bill Dickey and Phil Rizzuto were always in the All-Star Game, then Mickey Mantle, Whitey Ford and Yogi Berra.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/13/0056427.xml	        FOR more than half a century, the All-Star Game has been the barometer of the Yankees' season. To know how the Yankees were doing in any July, all anybody ever had to do was look at the American League team. In the beginning, Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Lefty Gomez dominated the All-Star rosters. When the Yankees were rolling to pennant after pennant, Joe DiMaggio, Bill Dickey and Phil Rizzuto were always in the All-Star Game, then Mickey Mantle, Whitey Ford and Yogi Berra. When the Yankees won the World Series again in 1977 and 1978, their All-Stars included Reggie Jackson, Thurman Munson and Graig Nettles.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/19/0057944.xml	        Years ago, when training and preparation were less intense, more athletes tried to play two professional sports, one after the other. One who did it was George Halas, who played 12 games in right field for the Yankees in 1919, then suffered a hip injury that ended his baseball career. He continued to play pro football and became famous as the owner and coach of the Chicago Bears. Had he stayed healthy, his baseball career would not have been secure because the next year the Yankees got a new right fielder, Babe Ruth.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/20/0058373.xml	        Now in only his fourth full season, Mattingly has emerged as a cherished Yankee who someday will deserve to be honored out there in left field at Yankee Stadium, out there with the monuments for Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, with the plaques for Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris, among others. And whenever Yankee fans yearn for the good old days, they should remember that with Mattingly at first base, these are the good new days - no matter what the principal owner thinks.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/21/0058558.xml	        Despite the persistent ache, Mattingly's eighth-inning double Sunday night gave him at least one extra-base hit in 10 consecutive games, surpassing the league record that had been set by Babe Ruth in 1921.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/21/0058712.xml	        During his eight-game streak, the Yankee first baseman hit a total of 10 home runs, including two grand slams. He drove in 21 runs with 17 hits in 37 times at bat for a .459 average. He also had two doubles. He scored 11 runs. He had two walks and only two strikeouts. With 49 total bases in his 37 times at bat, he had a 1.324 slugging average. And the Yankees won five of the eight games. To compare the stature of the Mattingly-Long streaks with other batting records of their type, three of baseball's most astute accountants were consulted - Seymour Siwoff and Steve Hirdt of the Elias Sports Bureau, which keeps the stats for both the National League and the American League, and Alan Roth, who has been charting baseball numbers for more than four decades. Here is the composite ranking: l. Joe DiMaggio's 56-game streak, which also was the core of his being on base in 84 consecutive games. 2. The 44-game hitting streaks of Pete Rose and Willie Keeler that share the National League record. 3. The Mattingly-Long streaks. ''If Babe Ruth had hit a homer in eight consecutive games,'' Siwoff said. ''it would have been part of his litany. Now that Mattingly has done it, what Long accomplished will be appreciated for what it was and is -one of the great records.'' 4. Frank Howard's total of 10 home runs over six consecutive games for the Washington Senators in 1968. ''He hit as many home runs in six games,'' Hirdt said, ''as Mattingly did in eight.'' 5. Twelve consecutive hits, set over four games by Mike (Pinky) Higgins of the Boston Red Sox in 1938 and equaled over three games by Walt Dropo of the Red Sox in 1952. ''As great a record as this is,'' Roth said, ''a home-run record is harder to get.'' 6. Tony Lazzeri's total of 15 runs batted in, set over two consecutive games for the 1936 Yankees. 7. Twenty-five total bases over two consecutive games, set by Ty Cobb of the Detroit Tigers in 1925 and equaled by Joe Adcock of the Milwaukee Braves in 1954. Adcock had 18 in one game with four homers and a double. 8. Oscar Grimes's 17 consecutive games in which he batted in at least one run for the 1922 Chicago Cubs. 9. Seven consecutive extra-base hits, set by Elmer Smith of the Cleveland Indians in 1922 with three doubles and four home runs, and equaled by Earl Sheely of the Chicago White Sox in 1926 with six doubles and one home run. 10. Paul Waner's 14 consecutive games with at least one extra-base hit (12 doubles, 4 triples and 4 homers). Going into last night's game in Minnesota, Mattingly had 10 straight games with at least one extra-base hit. 11. Eight consecutive pinch-hits, set by Dave Philley of the 1958 Philadelphia Phillies and equaled by Rusty Staub of the 1983 Mets. 12. Joe Sewell's 115 consecutive games without a strikeout for the 1929 Indians over 437 times at bat. He struck out only 4 times in 152 games that season, as he also did in 155 games in 1925. ''Bo Jackson,'' Hirdt said, ''strikes out four times in a game now.'' 13. Ted Williams's streak of getting on base 16 consecutive times for the 1957 Red Sox - two singles, four homers, nine walks, one hit by pitch. 14. Rudy York's 18 home runs in one month (August) for the 1937 Detroit Tigers. Babe Ruth hit 17 in September for the 1927 Yankees; Willie Mays hit 17 in August for the 1965 San Francisco Giants. 15. Al (Red) Schoendienst's eight doubles over three consecutive games for the 1948 St. Louis Cardinals. Stan Musial of the 1954 Cardinals and Nate Colbert of the 1972 San Diego Padres each hit five home runs in a doubleheader, but their record was not ranked because it occurred on one day, not over a span of at least two days.
nyt_corpus_1987.har/07/21/0058712.xml	        To appreciate what Mattingly and Long accomplished, consider that of the top six sluggers in career homers, only Reggie Jackson hit a homer in as many as six consecutive games. Henry Aaron didn't. Neither did Babe Ruth, Willie Mays, Frank Robinson nor Harmon Killebrew, but Roger Maris did in accumulating his record 61 homers for the 1961 Yankees.

O'Rourke. The answers appear in the lower left corner of this page.  1. What train passed through Westchester on Feb. 19, 1861?  2. Which was the first major department store to come to Westchester, in 1934?  3. Name the famous television host who once lived in the county and whose sons attended the Harrison Avenue School in Harrison.  4. Which Westchester College did Cybill Shepherd attend?  5. Name the baseball hero buried in the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne.  6. What municipality was the site of New York State's first public reading of the Declaration of Independence?  7. What famous film maker established a studio at Mamaroneck's Orienta Point?  8. Where was the world's first cocktail believed to have been mixed?  9. What 20th-century racket sport originated in Westchester?  10. In the television series ''The Dick Van Dyke Show,'' where did the Petry family live?  11. Name the man who was America's first full admiral and who moved to Hastings-on-Hudson in 1861.  12. In the television series ''Happy Days,'' the pennant of which Westchester college was seen in the malt shop?  13. In which Westchester community will you find the third oldest courthouse in the United States?  14. Which marathon is the second oldest in the United States?  15. Name the former Westchester resident who was the first woman to fly across the Atlantic.  ANSWERS  1. President Abraham Lincoln's inaugural train.  2. B. Altman and Company.  3. Johnny Carson.  4. College of New Rochelle.  5. Babe Ruth.  6. White Plains  7. D.W. Griffith  8. Elmsford/Greenburgh  9. Platform or paddle tennis  10. New Rochelle  11. Admiral David Farragut  12. Iona College  13. Bedford  14. The Yonkers Marathon.  15. Amelia Earhart

nyt_corpus_1987.har/08/30/0070345.xml	        Another glimpse of the old Deadwood is found at the Franklin Hotel, which has stood at 700 Main Street since 1903. It still offers some of the original claw-foot bathtubs in the rooms and a lobby and dining room that seems to jump right out of a Western movie. Many suites bear the names of the rich and famous who have slept in them - Babe Ruth, John Wayne, Teddy Roosevelt. Behind the hotel stands one of the city's most understated treasures - its public library. That lofty, turn-of-the-century building holds virtually every edition of every newspaper ever published in Deadwood, including details of all of those murders, hangings and other forms of mayhem, plus 2,500 books on frontier history (some extremely rare) and typescript copies of the diaries of some original residents. nyt_corpus_1987.har/09/02/0071039.xml	        The mock tribunal might be the least relevant and most superficial legal forum in the United States. It meets four or five times a year to decide ''important'' cases, such as whether Babe Ruth pointed to the bleachers before slamming his famous home run in the 1932 World Series against the Chicago Cubs (the decision was that the legend should stand). In another spirited case, the invention of the martini was squarely and chauvinistically traced to San Francisco, but not before the evidence was ingested by the presiding judge.

nyt_corpus_1987.har/10/05/0080168.xml	        Andre Dawson of the Chicago Cubs, a free-agent transplant, and Mark McGwire of Oakland, a rookie, led their leagues with 49 home runs each, marking only the second time in major league history that the league leaders had that many home runs in the same season. In 1930, Hack Wilson hit 56 home runs and Babe Ruth had 49 in winning league home-run titles. Only three other times did pairs of players hit as many as 49 home runs in the same season, with Roger Maris (61) and Mickey Mantle (54) accomplishing the feat most recently, in 1961.

Just as his 714 homers and his 94-46 record with a 2.28 earned run average as a left-handed pitcher certify him as the best player in baseball history, his enduring esteem as a newsmaker is another reason why he remains the most celebrated baseball player in history.

nyt_corpus_1988.har/01/01/0106176.xml	        Art and antiques collectors will long remember 1987 as a banner year for auctions. It saw world records toppled with the sales of two van Gogh paintings, a Bugatti automobile, a Mozart manuscript, a Stradivarius, a Gutenberg Old Testament, Charlie Chaplin's hat and cane and Babe Ruth's locker tag.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/01/01/0106176.xml	        By year's end, two of van Gogh's paintings were declared, successively, the most expensive artworks ever auctioned. In March, a painting in his ''Sunflowers'' series brought $39.9 million at Christie's in London, and in November ''Irises'' was sold for $53.9 million at Sotheby's in New York. Equally astounding, although far lower in the prices realized, were Babe Ruth's brass locker tag from Yankee Stadium, which brought $7,150 at Phillips in New York in November, a record for a locker tag, and Chaplin's hat and cane, which were sold for $151,800 at Christie's South Kensington in London last month, an all-time high for a costume worn by a film star.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/01/10/0108499.xml	        LEAD:  OVERTIME: A Twentieth Century Sports Odyssey. By Peter Schwed. (Beaufort, $15.95.) Many young sports fans know the joy of settling onto a grandfatherly lap and listening to colorful tales from someone who professes to have seen Babe Ruth swing a bat or experienced the patriotic euphoria created by Jesse Owens in 1936.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/01/10/0108499.xml	        OVERTIME: A Twentieth Century Sports Odyssey. By Peter Schwed. (Beaufort, $15.95.) Many young sports fans know the joy of settling onto a grandfatherly lap and listening to colorful tales from someone who professes to have seen Babe Ruth swing a bat or experienced the patriotic euphoria created by Jesse Owens in 1936. In this collection of childhood memories and homespun stories, Peter Schwed - the author of several books, a former editor at Simon & Schuster and a self-proclaimed ''sports freak'' who grew up in the 1920's - tries to be everyone's grandfather. A native of Long Island and a passionate club-level tennis player, he writes mainly of such personal passions as his family's devotion to Princeton sports, his father's penchant for horses, his brother's sense of humor and his own quest for a tennis haven. Mr. Schwed's sports knowledge, his admiration for athletic achievements and compassion for perhaps the most maligned of athletes, the defeated, are evident. But his meandering accounts of the intricacies of such sports as badminton and carom billiards, combined with his sometimes overly romantic style, dampen the impact of his reflections. The author also missed several opportunities to break new ground. Any tidbit concerning perhaps the most profound enigma in tennis history, Bill Tilden, would have been welcomed. But Mr. Schwed, who edited a book written by Mr. Tilden while the former player was serving a prison term for homosexually molesting a minor, dismisses the incident in one paragraph. Sports books of this nature can often provide useful reminders of some glorious past feats. Unfortunately, ''Overtime'' deteriorates rather quickly into a family album.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/01/14/0109423.xml	        Of the 200 baseball personalities in the Hall of Fame, only 74 have been elected on the writers' ballot; the other 126 were chosen by the Veterans Committee or other special committees. But every so often, the writers' vote is strange. Nine of 415 ballots in 1982 did not include a vote for Henry Aaron. Of the 226 ballots in the original election in 1936, two did not include a vote for Ty Cobb, and 11 did not include a vote for Babe Ruth.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/01/18/0110470.xml	        Undoubtedly, playing a longer schedule (162 games compared with 154) and drawing fewer walks (201 to 355) helped give Mattingly an edge in three of the six hitting categories, but then Mattingly had no Babe Ruth batting in front of him. In terms of fielding, Mattingly's percentage in his four full-time years has been a steady .995-.996, and Gehrig ranged from .989-.992, making the current Yankee a bigger glove man figuratively as well as actually.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/01/18/0110470.xml	        Among players with careers of that length, none ever knocked in a run a game, on average. Hank Greenberg came closest, driving in 1,276 runs in 1,394 games (a difference of 118) with the Detroit Tigers and the Pittsburgh Pirates from 1930-47. Gehrig fell 174 r.b.i. short, for he batted home 1,990 runs in 2,164 games. Another Yankee, Joe DiMaggio, also ranks high with a difference of 199 (1,537 r.b.i. in 1,736 games). Gehrig could have probably had more runs batted in if the batter in front of him most of the time on those powerful Yankee teams, Babe Ruth, had not driven home so many himself. Ruth missed by 292 r.b.i. of averaging one a game (2,211 in 2,503 games). But he was a pitcher in 163 of those games, probably more interested in keeping the bases clear than in clearing the bases.

nyt_corpus_1988.har/02/07/0116684.xml	        When Billy Dee Williams took over last week for James Earl Jones in ''Fences,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning play at the 46th Street Theater, it was a little like an athlete being asked, on short notice, to take over for Babe Ruth - or Josh Gibson. Mr. Jones won a Tony award for his towering portrayal of Troy Maxson, the Josh Gibson-like ex-Negro League slugger caught in a vise of frustration and limitation with members of his own family. But Mr. Williams, though he had not appeared on Broadway in 10 years and had only brief rehearsal time for ''Fences'' (four weeks as against several years and several different productions for Mr. Jones), brought his own well-worn pair of spikes to the part.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/02/07/0116684.xml	        The reasons why actors playing athletes seem, like modern athletes themselves, to have gotten bigger, better, faster and stronger, is, obviously, because scripts involving sports have frequently become more ambitious. Gone are the days of simple star biographies in which the demands of playing Babe Ruth required little more than fitting into an oversized camel's hair coat or swinging a mean cigar. These days, sports stories commonly use the milieu of athletes and their exploits for far wider purposes, to show us something about who we are and how we live.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/02/07/0116684.xml	        ''The word 'home,' for instance, is used again and again in the play,'' he said, ''home plate, the home you leave, the home you strive to return to when you leave the batter's box or the front door.'' The character Troy Maxson, Mr. Jones said, was bounded and made mad by fences - the fences around his home, the ones he put up around the lives of his wife and son, the ballpark fences that contained him as a hitter and as a black man. ''This is a man who, in his madness, has learned to guard the plate so that nothing will get past him.'' The madness of the old home run hitter who might, save for the color of his skin, have been Babe Ruth's replacement in right field, was, as Mr. Jones saw it, ''not very different from the madness of Lear.''

So let's get going. Let's see some smoke. You've got plenty of clout, not to mention nine appointees on the board of your development agency whose main purpose in life is to make you happy. nyt_corpus_1988.har/02/25/0122185.xml	        ''One of the riveting exhibits at the Hall is a formal photograph of the living inductees (there were eleven of them, and ten are in the picture) who came to Cooperstown'' for Dedication Day in 1939. ''Connie Mack, spare and erect and fatherly in a dark suit and high collar, sits next to Babe Ruth in the front row; the Babe, moon-faced and gone to beef, has an open collar above his double-breasted suit, and his crossed left leg reveals that his socks have been rolled down to shoe-top level. Tris Speaker, playing short center field as usual, stands directly behind Ruth, and Honus Wagner and Walter Johnson, with their famous country sweetness perfectly visible, occupy the corners. As you study the photograph (never a quick process, no matter how many times you have seen it), your gaze stops at the other men's faces, one by one, as recollection of their deeds and their flair for the game comes flooding back: Eddie Collins, Grover Cleveland Alexander, Nap Lajoie, Cy Young (pipe in hand), and George Sisler - old warriors squinting in the sun, comfortable at last.''
nyt_corpus_1988.har/02/25/0122212.xml	        Mr. O'Farrell, who played for the Chicago Cubs, the St. Louis Cardinals, the Cincinnati Reds and the New York Giants, also served as manager in St. Louis (1927) and Cincinnati (1934). He had a career batting average of .273, but was most renowned for throwing out Babe Ruth attempting to steal second base in the ninth inning of the seventh game of the 1926 World Series. The play ended the Series, with the Cardinals beating the Yankees.

nyt_corpus_1988.har/03/21/0129350.xml	        Gehrig accomplished it five times, which puts him right behind Babe Ruth, just like on the Yankee lineup card. In the period from 1921-31, Ruth had six seasons in which he knocked in more runs than games he played. His high points came in 1921 (171 r.b.i. in 152 games) and 1929 (154 in 135). Gehrig's five seasons fell in the period from 1927-37 and his best differential (r.b.i. minus games played) exceeded Ruth's best by 10. In 1931, Gehrig drove home 184 runs, the American League season record, as well as a number 29 higher than the 155 games Gehrig played and a differential 10 better than Ruth ever achieved.

nyt_corpus_1988.har/04/03/0132985.xml	        BABE RUTH, LOU Gehrig, Ty Cobb, Stan Musial, Ted Williams: perhaps a disproportionate number of baseball's top hitters have been left-handed. Most pitchers are right-handed, and if left-handed hitters have an advantage, that's what it is. A right-handed curveball breaks in toward a left-handed batter, making it easier to handle than a pitch that breaks away. Mattingly has proven equally dangerous against left-handers as right-handers, though. Pitchers sometimes link Mattingly with Boston's great hitter, Wade Boggs, another lefty. But they acknowledge that Mattingly's power, his ability to create big innings with a three-run home run, places him a notch above Boggs, and thus in a league by himself.

There is no more completely satisfactory drama in literature than the fall of Humpty Dumpty.''

nyt_corpus_1988.har/06/05/0151448.xml	        Ralph Houk, who led the extraordinary 1961 New York Yankees to the world championship in his first year as a major league manager, and Robert W. Creamer, whose biographies of Babe Ruth and Casey Stengel are sports classics, even prove that something new can be said about Roger Maris, Mickey Mantle, Whitey Ford and all the other stars on the second-greatest team in Yankee history. (Most students of the game reserve No. 1 status for the 1927 Yankees of Lou Gehrig and Babe Ruth.) To set the scene, Mr. Creamer, who takes turns with Mr. Houk in telling the story of ''Season of Glory,'' paints a vivid portrait of 1961, a year of social change and unrest, in which the daily headlines focused on the space age, the Bay of Pigs and the civil rights movement. It was also a year of change for baseball. The addition of new teams forced the extension of the season from 154 games to 162, giving rise to the then commissioner of baseball Ford Frick's stern assertion, even before Maris hit 61 home runs, that any records broken that year would be accompanied in the record books by an asterisk. And at Yankee Stadium, after leading the team to 10 pennants and seven World Series championships in his 12 years as manager, the aging Casey Stengel was being forced out. Taking the crafty veteran's place was a young, untried and relatively unknown Yankee coach and former minor league manager, Ralph Houk.

''He's always bringing in some Babe Ruth players for help or just drops in and walks around, giving advice to kids and grownups in the batting cages. Everybody is crazy about the guy. He loves to teach and he has a great rapport with the kids and their parents. And at times he's been booked six weeks in advance. I think everyone realizes he's totally different than the George Foster that was portrayed by the media.''

nyt_corpus_1988.har/07/24/0164083.xml	        McGraw, says Mr. Alexander, was the pre-eminent figure in baseball until the blazing ascent of Babe Ruth. With his prodigious home runs, Ruth changed the game for good. He modernized it, almost single-handed. Looking back, we recognize the Babe more easily than we do McGraw - even though McGraw hung on as the Giants' manager until 1932, three years before Ruth left the game. ''I'm sort of a permanent fixture,'' he said in 1930, four years before his death, ''like home plate and the flag pole.'' The truth was, he'd become an anachronism.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/07/24/0164421.xml	        In her review of ''The Goddess and the American Girl'' by Larry Engelmann (June 12), Grace Lichtenstein said that in the 1920's and 1930's the tennis players Suzanne Lenglen and Helen Wills ''were bigger headliners than Jack Dempsey or Babe Ruth.''
nyt_corpus_1988.har/07/24/0164421.xml	        That's an eye-catching remark (you even used it in the headline over the story), but it isn't true. In researching biographies of sports figures in the 1920's and 1930's, including Babe Ruth, I spent weeks and weeks reading through newspapers and magazines of that period. While Lenglen and Wills were superb athletes who frequently attracted a great deal of well-deserved attention, particularly in Britain and France, the publicity they generated and the headlines they gathered did not approach the massive, detailed, continuing press attention given to Dempsey and Ruth, who were clearly the most prominent and the most lastingly popular sports figures of the era - in short, the biggest headliners.  ROBERT W. CREAMER  Tuckahoe, N.Y.

nyt_corpus_1988.har/08/14/0170915.xml	        Even his passing had a measure of greatness. Losing his battle with cancer, Ruth addressed his fans in Yankee Stadium on a national Babe Ruth Day held April 27, 1947. Wearing his trademark camel's hair overcoat and cap, he leaned painfully over the microphone and spoke extemporaneously. ''You know how bad my voice sounds,'' he croaked. ''Well, it feels just as bad.'' But then Ruth struggled to his rhetorical feet and went on to deliver his celebrated anthem to baseball, ''the only real game in the world,'' the game that ''comes up from the youth.''

nyt_corpus_1988.har/08/21/0173046.xml	        There are two contexts in which the magnitude of a trade should be judged. The first is the extent of news media coverage and public interest in a deal. In this respect, l'affaire Gretzky ranks with the Tom Seaver, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and O. J. Simpson trades as a mega-event. The second and more important criterion relates to the impact of the trade on the teams involved. There can be little doubt that no other deal in the history of sports has even come close to affecting the fortunes of the parties to the transaction as radically as did the transfer of Babe Ruth from the Boston Red Sox to the New York Yankees, in 1920.  ROBERT N. GOLDMAN  New Rochelle, N.Y.

The last six homers Maris hit were also off right-handers; Ruth's 60th came off the left-handed Tom Zachary of the Washington Senators. nyt_corpus_1988.har/09/30/0183982.xml	        Japan's legendary home-run hitter, Sadaharu Oh, admitted yesterday what many ballplayers discovered before him: Great hitters do not necessarily make great managers. At a news conference in Tokyo, Oh said that he would resign as manager of the Yomiuri Giants next week after another disappointing season by the team that once dominated Japanese baseball. The front office, which used the expiration of Oh's five-year contract as a graceful moment to ease him out, appointed Motoji Fujita as manager. Oh, 48 years old, took full responsibility for the team's third-place finish in the Central League. ''I had expected this to come,'' said Oh. ''Over the past five years I have not been able to meet expectations, and I accept that. In this world of professional sports, you have to win. That's the bottom line.'' Oh's entire career was spent with the Giants, starting in 1959. During his 21-year playing career, the team won 13 pennants and 12 Japan Series titles, and Oh hit 868 home runs, exceeding the 755 by Henry Aaron and the 714 by Babe Ruth. But managing in a six-team league, his Giants were third three times, second once and won the pennant last year but lost the series to the Seibu Lions.

nyt_corpus_1988.har/11/27/0202021.xml	        GRACIE: A Love Story. By George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) Reading George Burns's loving tribute to his late wife, the comedienne Gracie Allen, is the next best thing to watching reruns of the couple's long-running 1950's television series. Burns and Allen were married, both on stage and off, for 40 years. They began as a vaudeville act in the 1920's, graduated to radio in the 1930's, then gave television one of its first and most memorable situation comedies from 1952 to 1958. The key to the act's success was not Mr. Burns, who always played the straight man, nor the material, which could sometimes be corny even by vaudeville standards. What kept the show going was Allen, who used her exquisite comic timing to transform a stock ''dizzy dame'' character into what Mr. Burns calls ''the national symbol of misunderstanding.'' Gracie's role as the dumb wife is dated, but her ''illogical logic'' can still draw laughs: she once determined to meet Babe Ruth and his twin brother, for instance, after reading that the Babe's double had won a game. She also once threatened to run for governor of the State of Coma, saying she had been there for years, and sometime later announced her candidacy for President on the Surprise Party. After she retired in 1958, Allen's heart ailments gradually worsened. She died in 1964 at the age of 58. Mr. Burns tells her story as if he were doing a stand-up comedy routine; he even lets the reader know when he is puffing on his cigar as a signal to laugh. This entertaining monologue is the kind of memorial that would please any comic for one simple reason: it leaves the audience with a smile.
nyt_corpus_1988.har/12/04/0203748.xml	        THE GODDESS AND THE AMERICAN GIRL: The Story of Suzanne Lenglen and Helen Wills. By Larry Engelmann. (Oxford University, $21.95.) An ''overlong, overdue dual biography'' of two tennis rivals who, in the 1920's and 30's, ''were bigger headliners than Jack Dempsey or Babe Ruth.''

nyt_corpus_1989.har/01/11/0213162.xml	        Besides, selecting Hall of Fame players is not exactly a science. Among the first five players elected in 1936, Ty Cobb was snubbed by five voting writers, Babe Ruth and Honus Wagner both by 11, Christy Mathewson by 21 and Walter Johnson by 37.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/01/15/0214316.xml	        Mr. Morehart's death leaves Mark Koenig, the starting shortstop, as the only surviving member of the team that featured Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/01/16/0214489.xml	        In 1927, however, a prominent member of the New York Giants football team that posted an 11-1-1 record and finished first in the 12-team N.F.L. standing was Hinkey Haines, a former all-America halfback from Penn State. Four years earlier, Haines was a reserve outfielder for the Yankees when they won the World Series from the Giants in six games. Haines, a rookie who got into 28 regular-season games and batted .160, appeared twice in that 1923 Series. He replaced Babe Ruth in right field in the eighth inning of Game 3, with Ruth switching to first base, and Haines grounded out in his only time at bat during a 1-0 Yankee loss to Art Nehf. In Game 6, Haines went in as a pinch-runner for Fred Hofmann and scored on a single by Bob Meusel during a five-run Yankee eighth, then played center field the last two innings and was there for the final out of the Series. That was the final major league appearance for Haines, who died in 1979 and remains the only athlete to play for both World Series and N.F.L. champions. Nettles and Dempsey came up with Minnesota, Evans with Atlanta, Fisk with Boston and Buckner with Los Angeles, where he batted once in 1969 as a pinch-hitter and thus qualified as a 1960's major leaguer. Simmons began his career in 1968, five years after Tommy John, who at 45 is still looking to catch on with someone. nyt_corpus_1989.har/02/12/0222845.xml	        I can corroborate J. E. Eberspacher's recollection of Babe Ruth's called shot home run. It is not legend. I was not sure of the year until I read the Eberspacher letter. The event is as clear to me today as on the day it happened. I was listening to the ball game being broadcast with my friend, Frank Rubin, on the newly purchased family Atwater Kent radio. When the announcer said the Babe was pointing to right field, while at bat, indicating where he was going to hit the ball, we looked at each other in amazement and breathless anticipation of the next pitch. Then it happened. A home run. We were ecstatic. Yes, it really happened.  BERNARD LEON  The Bronx
nyt_corpus_1989.har/02/12/0222847.xml	        There is no doubt about Babe Ruth in that ninth inning: when at bat he raised his right hand and pointed to right field, and the next ball went in that direction for a winning home run. There are 15 national organizations - including Little League and Babe Ruth, American Legion, National Police Athletic and Pony leagues - that have local branches offering competition beginning at age 6 with instruction on the hand-eye coordination connected to batting.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/03/10/0230287.xml	        The contemporary and informal space, with a big bar up front overlooking Central Park South, is filled with sports memorabilia, including the uniforms of Mantle, Babe Ruth and Joe DiMaggio; autographed photos; paintings; posters, and even nonstop videos replaying old World Series film and interviews with Mantle. The main-level dining room has soft pillow-lined booths and bare pine tables; a step-down back room is more tranquil, removed from the cacophonous bar. Young, bouncy waiters and waitresses, wearing floppy baseball shirts, are as eager and enthusiastic as a Little Leaguer on opening day.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/03/12/0231021.xml	        The Oakland Athletics, the defending American League champion, is the only Arizona-based franchise to win the World Series in that span -and win it three years in a row (1972, 1973, 1974). In batting practice you can see their two young sluggers, Jose Canseco and Mark McGwire, dispose of dozens of baseballs over the Phoenix Stadium fences. The first time I talked to Canseco was after a 1986 workout at the stadium. I mentioned that in the minor leagues the year before he had hit 40 homers. ''Forty-one,'' he said without a smile. Then a 21-year-old rookie, Canseco took his slugging seriously enough to become that spring's ''phenom,'' baseball slang for phenomenal prospect. T HE EXCITEMENT OF SPRING training, however, does not just come from observing the season's new stars. I last saw an aging Henry Aaron there in 1976. The man who broke Babe Ruth's record would complete his career with a record 755 home runs. But that spring he was hoping to finish with a flourish for the Milwaukee Brewers, who then trained in Sun City, northwest of Phoenix.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/03/19/0232750.xml	        Like most men in business, baseball players compartmentalize their jobs. What goes on across the white lines is infinitely more important than what goes on behind them. A close friend who consistently strikes out with the bases loaded isn't as much use to a ballplayer as a despised teammate who consistently strokes game-winning hits. The respect a player feels for a teammate's personal life has nothing to do with the respect he feels for a teammate's baseball talent. Babe Ruth, Pete Rose and Wade Boggs are three of the greatest hitters ever in the game, and yet not many teammates might envy their personal lives. Yet to a man, every player in the game would want one of those three at the plate if a World Series championship was on the line.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/03/31/0236076.xml	        Mr. Blessing's other broad concerns are American mythology and racism. His protagonist, like the real Cobb, gropes to figure out why his statistically superior baseball record and exemplary business career would eventually be eclipsed by the Horatio Alger legend of the home-run-slugging Babe Ruth, whom he regarded as a freak. While the question is interesting, the stagy debates it prompts about cultural myth-making are static, with or without a hokey projection of Ruth's ghostly face as a backdrop.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/04/02/0236583.xml	        Every time he looks at the picture he knows what a pain he was. He also knows what he can never thank that sweating, earnest, unrelenting father enough for: a prized original photograph of a little kid with Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig that few, if any, other men or boys can boast of. It has been on loan in the private rooms of some famous writers who say they'd rather have been the boy than get seven figures on their next work. It has, he blushes to say it, on occasion served as his etchings. But most of all, it is the reminder of what his father was really about -a great healer for man and boy.

Or that Babe Ruth's increasing girth is the reason the New York Yankees wear pinstripes. The owner Jacob Ruppert ''thought he would look slimmer that way.''

nyt_corpus_1989.har/04/23/0243190.xml	        LEAD:  BASEBALL ANECDOTES. By Daniel Okrent and Steve Wulf. (Oxford University, $18.95.) Even the most erudite baseball fan may not know that Babe Ruth was the game's first underwear model, that the brainy catcher Moe Berg counted Sanskrit among the languages he knew, that Rogers Hornsby avoided movies to protect his batting eye or that the former Yankee manager Billy Martin had cosmetic surgery on his nose when he was 22 years old.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/04/23/0243190.xml	        BASEBALL ANECDOTES. By Daniel Okrent and Steve Wulf. (Oxford University, $18.95.) Even the most erudite baseball fan may not know that Babe Ruth was the game's first underwear model, that the brainy catcher Moe Berg counted Sanskrit among the languages he knew, that Rogers Hornsby avoided movies to protect his batting eye or that the former Yankee manager Billy Martin had cosmetic surgery on his nose when he was 22 years old. Of such beguiling minutiae is ''Baseball Anecdotes'' made. Daniel Okrent, co-author of ''The Ultimate Baseball Book,'' and Steve Wulf, a senior editor at Sports Illustrated, essentially have written a history of the game in stories - comic, tragic, controversial - starting with baseball's disputed origins and ending with the 1986 World Series. The monochromatic prose rarely does justice to these lusty tales. Some are attributed, some are not and some have the ring of apocrypha about them. The younger fan is enthralled to discover that Hank Greenberg's mother promised to make him 61 baseball-shaped portions of gefilte fish back in 1938 if he broke Babe Ruth's record of 60 home runs in a season. Readers curious about players' afterlives will learn that the Yankee outfielder Mickey Rivers became a professional bingo player, that Honus Wagner toured Pittsburgh saloons in search of recognition and free beers and that a drink-dissipated Grover Cleveland Alexander did a stint as a circus freak. (The authors do not say what kind.) Idolators of macho men will find their demigod in the Cleveland Indians' outfielder Joe Charbonneau, who tried to fix his own broken nose with a pair of pliers, pulled one of his own teeth and stitched up a stab wound with a fishing line. Some stories, however, touch on a provocative point and fail to follow through: the authors never explain why Mr. Martin got that nose job or why the legendary double-play partners Joe Tinker and Johnny Evers did not speak to each other for two years. Gargantuan Boog Powell and paunchy Mickey Lolich are cited for their heft, with no mention of what they weighed. And it is maddening to be told that the career minor leaguer Steve Dalkowski was the hardest-throwing pitcher to walk the earth without reporting the speed of his fastball.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/04/30/0245286.xml	        If one cannot meet with a client, for example, the other will. ''If there's something impossible for me to get to, Felix can be there,'' said Mr. Harris. ''It's not bad having Babe Ruth as a substitute.''

For decades, nobody even came close. But then Henry Aaron kept swinging his bat and then Nolan Ryan kept other bats swinging.

The fruitful partnership began in 1929, when Raleigh stitched numbers on Yankee uniforms. New York was the first major league team to regularly wear uniform numbers.  An Inspiration of Dreams

nyt_corpus_1989.har/05/07/0247888.xml	        Yes, this is a picture book, but ever so much more. Babe Ruth, who could cuss, guzzle and whore to outdo any sailor of legend, was also the most genial and accommodating of men. He would pose for photographers in any requested position, however ridiculous or uncomfortable. Thus, in ''The Babe: A Life in Pictures,'' we see him chopping wood, riding a cow, in drag, dressed as a cop, and hanging from an exercise bar in a good imitation of an ape. He also endorsed everything from underwear to shaving cream to zippers; his story becomes a primer of graphic design from World War I through the Depression.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/05/07/0247888.xml	        Yes, this is a baseball book, but ever so much more. Babe Ruth - need one bother to say it yet again? - was the greatest player who ever lived, a man who would have made the Hall of Fame for his pitching alone, but then changed America's greatest game forever by blasting more home runs in a single year than most earlier sluggers had hit in a lifetime or most entire teams in a full season.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/05/07/0247888.xml	        But scores of unusual shots are also included. I never knew, for example, that someone in the stands had taken a home movie of the supposed ''called'' home run against Charles Root in the 1932 World Series. Well, the Babe was pointing at something, but the trajectory seems to indicate Root himself or the Cubs' dugout, not the center-field fence. (This perennial debate of American cultural history shall no more be ended by these photos than the Zapruder film shall resolve the Kennedy assassination!) Yes, this is a book about America - its legends, its foibles, its rituals of daily life - all seen through the fairy-book life of an incorrigible kid, abandoned by his parents and brought up in a reformatory, who became such a powerful symbol of America that Japanese infantrymen often charged our Pacific trenches with the shout (in English): ''To hell with Babe Ruth!''
nyt_corpus_1989.har/05/07/0247902.xml	        After the summer of 1949, the Red Sox and the Yankees, afflicted by complacency, the arrogance of power and a racist policy that made them among the last of the major league teams to hire black players, lost some of their stature. The Yankees surrendered their collective personality to what Mr. Halberstam calls ''cold-blooded organizational skill.'' And the Red Sox continued to labor unavailingly to escape Sisyphean punishment for having sold Babe Ruth to the Yankees in 1920.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/05/07/0247902.xml	        By Mr. Halberstam's account, a good measure of the drama of the pennant race stemmed from a battle of opposing styles and traditions. He does his utmost to be evenhanded, but it is clear nonetheless that his primary allegiance is to the Yankees. The 1949 Yankees were physically and mentally tough, disciplined, classy and proud of a tradition of winning that went back to the era of Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig. ''Everyone demanded complete effort,'' the outfielder Gene Woodling recalled. ''It was not a team where anyone ever said 'nice try' when you made a long run after a fly ball and didn't get to it.'' There was even a Yankee physical ideal: clean-cut, gentlemanly. Yogi Berra played for a while under the shadow of not looking like a Yankee, much less a ball player. (Bucky Harris, who preceded Casey Stengel as the Yankee manager, called Mr. Berra ''The Ape.'') The Red Sox - in some respects the toy of their rich owner, Tom Yawkey, who wanted them to be happy above all - tended to the freewheeling, good-old-boy, late-hours style of Jimmie Foxx, Lefty Grove and Ellis Kinder (a tradition carried on more recently by Wade Boggs). A mainstay of the 1949 team, Kinder arrived in Cleveland one morning so drunk that he had to be rolled through the train station in a wheelchair. That afternoon he pitched brilliantly in relief in both ends of a doubleheader against the Indians. ''Ellis did love a good time,'' his widow said.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/05/14/0249953.xml	        ''The Natural'' is a perverse movie because half of it knows better. A couple of times, it actually defies tradition by showing whole sequences of plays instead of unrelieved highlights; and Robert Redford's swing is maybe the best acting he's ever done. But the film violates baseball reality in too many other ways. Roy Hobbs, the mythic hero, has no teammates to speak of, his bat never breaks, and, since he is too ethereal for statistics, we don't even know where he stands in relation to Babe Ruth's record, which was a fixation during the 30's. And on and on. As Hobbs rounds the bases hemorrhaging from his old bullet wounds to win the playoff game and the pennant, all I could think was, ''No wonder the National League loses so many World Series'' - which was not what the movie wanted me to think, I know, but that's the difference between a fan and a movie.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/05/14/0249953.xml	        However, a fan shouldn't grumble too much, I daresay, because the good news is that there is at last some real baseball in the baseball movies, which previously had been as suspect as wartime sausages. Gone, it seems, are the days when Gary Cooper, swinging like a nervous housewife who just wants to get it over with, could be flopped from right-handed to left-handed and palmed off as the great Lou Gehrig in ''Pride of the Yankees'' (1942). For ''Major League,'' Steve Yeager, the ex-Dodger, sweated the actors until they looked like the real thing, and for the admirable ''Eight Men Out,'' D. B. Sweeney actually took the trouble to learn to swing left-handed, though pedants might note that his character, Shoeless Joe Jackson, would probably not have lifted his hand on the follow-through. Babe Ruth didn't, and he claimed to be a Jacksonian.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/05/14/0249953.xml	        One's only consolation at the time was that Hollywood was equally cavalier toward every occupation it touched, and William Bendix, who couldn't even manage a decent home-run trot for ''The Babe Ruth Story,'' was no more at sea than Don Ameche inventing the telephone or Robert Walker frowning over ''Ol' Man River.'' Since it was understood that all professional lore is boring, we never actually learned how anyone did anything.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/05/21/0251908.xml	        Mickey Mantle's, a sports-oriented American restaurant in Manhattan, is a virtual baseball museum, where kids are invited to tour memorabilia that include photographs, paintings and old film clips. (The Mick's old uniform, No. 7, is there, and so are those of Babe Ruth and Joe DiMaggio.) Border Cafe, a Southwestern-theme restaurant with two locations in New York City, distributes crayons to kids and features television monitors showing programs for youngsters. Its Broadway branch also has a ''grazing bar,'' where children are encouraged to inspect some of the raw ingredients that go into the food, from sweet peppers and corn to oranges and lemons.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/02/0255373.xml	        The 1939 New York World's Fair simply refuses to depart from either memory or popular imagination. This now-legendary celebration of the ''world of tomorrow'' is being remembered in an exhibition in the Edna Barnes Salomon Room of the New York Public Library, on Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. The show, called ''The Last Fair on Earth,'' includes photographs of popular attractions like Democracity, the robot Eleckro, Futurama and such celebrities as Franklin D. Roosevelt, Fiorello H. La Guardia, Albert Einstein and Babe Ruth. Guidebooks, souvenirs and architectural designs for the Trylon, Perisphere and other exhibits are also on display. The exhibition continues through Nov. 11, and is open Mondays through Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 869-8089.  Saturday  DREAM BOATS AHOY!
nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/04/0255724.xml	        An anecdote recounted by Stephen Jay Gould in his review of Lawrence S. Ritter and Mark Rucker's picture biography of Babe Ruth (May 7) is even more hilarious in its complete form. My brother, who was a combat correspondent in the Marine Corps during the battle to take Okinawa in World War II, told me that in addition to shouting (in English) ''To hell with Babe Ruth!'' ostensibly to break the marines' morale, the Japanese shouted ''To hell with Lou Gehrig!'' and ''To hell with Moe Berg!'' - this last in reference to the multilingual journeyman catcher who, because of his knowledge of Japanese, had accompanied an all-star team to Japan as player and translator, and who, because of his generosity in conducting baseball clinics for the Japanese and otherwise making himself available to them, had become a national idol. The cream of the jest, of course, was that most of the marines had never heard of Moe Berg. Incidentally, the most famous quip at Berg's expense was that he could speak 10 (or more) languages competently but couldn't hit a curveball in even one of them.  BERNARD KOGAN  Wilmette, Ill.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/04/0255913.xml	        In assembling an all-time team, third base had always been the thinnest position for candidates. Only seven are waiting for Mike Schmidt to join them in 1995 at the Hall of Fame: the old-timers Frank (Home Run) Baker, Fred Lindstrom and Jimmy Collins along with George Kell, Robinson, Mathews and Traynor. The other positions always had many more legends to choose from but Lou Gehrig dominated the first basemen, Rogers Hornsby the second basemen, Honus Wagner the shortstops. In the outfield, take any three: Babe Ruth, Henry Aaron, Joe DiMaggio, Ted Williams, Ty Cobb, Stan Musial, Mickey Mantle, Pete Rose. Among the catchers, judge Mickey Cochrane, Bill Dickey, Yogi Berra, Roy Campanella and Johnny Bench. For pitching, consider Cy Young, Walter Johnson, Christy Mathewson, Sandy Koufax, Bob Feller, Lefty Grove, Steve Carlton, Tom Seaver.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/04/0256096.xml	        The Presley estate has long been aggressive in protecting Elvis's name and image, successfully shutting down productions that capitalized on him without authorization. And the estate has been in the forefront of efforts in various state legislatures - New York most recently - to prohibit the commercial exploitation of deceased celebrities without permission of their estates; Barry Ward of Memphis, the estate's lawyer, has testified at hearings in Albany, seeking to convince lawmakers to follow the lead of California and Tennessee, states offering the widest protection to stars and their heirs. Others involved in these lobbying efforts have been the estates of John Wayne, Babe Ruth, Charlie Chaplin and W. C. Fields.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/06/0256465.xml	        A .256 hitter with 91 home runs in his 10-year major league career, Gaston could probably have benefited from a few tips from the man who would hit more home runs than Babe Ruth. Nevertheless, Gaston eventually learned enough about hitting that he was able to serve as a highly respected hitting coach for the Toronto Blue Jays for seven seasons and thus be in position to be named their manager, first on an interim basis May 15, then for the rest of the season a week ago. nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/13/0258216.xml	        The first musical to get this Papp treatment is ''Romance in Hard Times,'' written and composed by William Finn, author of ''March of the Falsettos'' and ''In Trousers.'' The show, which has a cast of 14, is set during the last years of the Depression and features singing and dancing versions of Eleanor Roosevelt, the Duke of Windsor, Babe Ruth, Shirley Temple and Bill (Bojangles) Robinson. It tells of a woman who decides to put off the birth of her child until the world gets better and who eventually is pregnant for more than 20 months.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/15/0258799.xml	        ''When you deal the type of player Langston is,'' Woodward said, ''there is a certain part of the fans who even if you get Babe Ruth back, they're not going to be pleased with the deal because you're trading a popular player. Then when you take young pitchers instead of a quality player, they really don't like it. We were rolling the dice to a degree.''
nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/18/0259436.xml	        Keeping track of a player's pace is not, however, a universal practice. Not everyone rushes to read where a Mark McGwire or a Kevin Mitchell fits in with Roger Maris and Babe Ruth.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/18/0259557.xml	        HANK GREENBERG: The Story of My Life. By Hank Greenberg; Edited and with an Introduction by Ira Berkow. (Times Books, $19.95.) Had Henry Benjamin Greenberg lived to complete his autobiography, the story of his life in baseball would probably have been as flat as his big feet. Happily, his family sought the help of Ira Berkow, a New York Times sports columnist. The collaboration was unusual. Greenberg died at the age of 75 on Sept. 4, 1986. Mr. Berkow inherited 800 pages of rambling conversation that Greenberg had dictated, and edited those words into the heart of the book. Greenberg, who played for the Detroit Tigers from 1933 until 1946, with four years out for military service during World War II, relates the usual baseball lore. He tells stories of players' shenanigans, names the greats of the game and recalls his good and bad days at the plate. He was contentious during the annual contract talks and explains why. He was contemptuous of managers who coldly cut aging veterans, even Babe Ruth, from the roster. Latter-day players who outdistanced Greenberg in the record books have written similar stories. What was special about this player beyond his 6-foot 4-inch frame, dedication to the game and courtly manner? Greenberg is one of two Jewish players - Sandy Koufax is the other - to be named to the Baseball Hall of Fame. Greenberg does not deny his heritage, but he does not make much of it. It is Mr. Berkow who adds perspective and stature to Greenberg through interviews with sportswriters and the player's family, friends and colleagues. Greenberg was remembered by players and writers for his grace under the almost daily pressure of anti-Semitic vulgarities shouted by opposing teams and fans. He was regarded as the model by Jackie Robinson and other minority players who tried to concentrate on the game and ignore the viciousness of racial discrimination. Such a contribution is reason enough to celebrate Greenberg's life.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/21/0260230.xml	        * When Johnson got his chance to play regularly in 1987, he hit 36 home runs. Whitey Herzog, the manager of the Cardinals, promptly impounded his bat and asked the umpires to check it for cork. ''He looks like Babe Ruth up there,'' Herzog said, ''and I know he ain't that good.''
nyt_corpus_1989.har/06/26/0261635.xml	        A Split Decision  Q. Suppose that a peeved Darryl Strawberry manages to hit 32 home runs by the All-Star Game one of these seasons, but is so unhappy playing for the Mets that they decide to trade him to an American League team, such as Toronto, during the All-Star Game break. If Strawberry hits 30 home runs for the Blue Jays during the rest of the season for a total of 62, will he be recognized as baseball's career leader for most home runs in a season?  A. He would go down as the major league leader for one season, but the American and National League leaders would not be dislodged from their places in the record book, according to the commissioner's office, which had to deal with a similar problem 28 years ago. When Roger Maris hit 61 home runs in 1961 and broke Babe Ruth's sacred mark, Maris created a quandary of Ruthian proportions because the American League played a 162-game season that year and Ruth had made his mark in the 154-game format of 1927. So the record book now lists Maris as the American League (and therefore major league) leader for 162-game seasons and Ruth as the leader for 154-game seasons. It also singles out Hack Wilson (56 homers for the Chicago Cubs in 1930) as the National League leader for a 154-game schedule and Willie Mays (52 in 1965 for the San Francisco Giants) and George Foster (52 for the Cincinnati Reds in 1977) as the National League co-leaders for a 162-game season.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/07/02/0263101.xml	        Lou Gehrig is remembered for his record streak of 2,130 consecutive games, for his 493 home runs and .340 average, for having been baseball's best first baseman, and for having been the cleanup hitter behind Babe Ruth on the 1927 Yankees, considered by many historians to have been baseball's most dominant team.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/07/02/0263190.xml	        Controversy over voting in flanneled personages has been a part of the hall ever since 1936 when the first five players were chosen - Ty Cobb, Walter Johnson, Christy Mathewson, Honus Wagner and Babe Ruth. In the beginning, only 10-year members of the Baseball Writers of America voted for players to enter the hall. And in 1936, of 226 writers, 11 of them left Ruth off their ballots. What those loose-cannon 11 were thinking of, or whether their pens just ran out of ink, no one knows. But the Babe managed to get in anyway.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/07/12/0265338.xml	        There's no question that Greenberg lived a life worth examination. In the 1930's, as the first great Jewish baseball player, he was a pariah to some and a paladin to others (including Ira Berkow, a New York Times sports columnist, who edited the transcriptions of Greenberg's taped recollections after his death). As claimant to Babe Ruth's crown as the game's most powerful hitter, Greenberg was a national celebrity. After his baseball career ended (he had managed to save $300,000 of the $447,000 he had earned in uniform), he became a wealthy man, buying into (and selling out of) the ownership of two ballclubs, and then becoming a successful private investor.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/08/06/0272696.xml	        CLEARING THE BASES: Baseball Then and Now. By Bill Starr. (Michael Kesend, $18.95.) Ty Cobb was not as good as his .367 career batting average, say the baseball computer analysts; if he were playing today he would hit only .289. That only proves Cobb's greatness, say the critics of such analysis - .289 is impressive hitting for a 102-year-old. Bill Starr, a minor-league player in the 1930's and owner of the San Diego Padres of the Pacific Coast League until 1955, says that the players of the 1920's and 30's get a bum rap. It is wrong to assume that because athletes are generally faster, bigger and stronger than in the old days, baseball players necessarily are better, Mr. Starr says in ''Clearing the Bases.'' Those traits make for better football and basketball players, but baseball depends on hand skills more akin to those used in golf, and quickness rather than foot speed. The theory that a lively ball created higher batting averages in the 20's and 30's is bunk, says Mr. Starr. Rather, Babe Ruth established that hitting drew fans and a higher salary, and players altered their bats and styles in Ruth's image. Mr. Starr cranks out his own statistics to show that players of the old days managed to hit the long ball while keeping strikeouts - much more an embarrassment then than now - to a minimum. Mr. Starr emphasizes that his book is no nostalgia trip. Too bad, for as he makes these and various other cases with quotes from old-timers, the reader gets too-brief glimpses of a time when all manner of spitballs were common, owners figured one ball should last a whole game and crowds milled around the outfield during games.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/08/07/0273165.xml	        Among the Grand Slam events, Palmer was a winner once in the United States Open, twice in the British Open and four times in the Masters. But in his 22 appearances in the PGA Championship, from 1959-80, second best was the best he could do, and he did it thrice. In 1968, he finished one shot behind Boros; in 1970, he was two in back of Dave Stockton, and in 1964, he wound up three strokes short of Bobby Nichols even though Palmer's rounds of 68, 68, 69, 69, made him the only competitor in the field to break 70 in each round. Since he joined the Senior PGA Tour for players over 50 years of age in 1980, the score has evened somewhat for the player who never won a PGA Championship; Palmer has won the Senior PGA Championship twice, in 1980 and 1984.  Yankees Go Home  Q. Who holds the Yankee record for stealing home in his career?  A. Lou Gehrig. He did it 15 times, which is astonishing for such a powerful hitter, and his partner in slugging, Babe Ruth, did it 10 times, which might be even more astonishing. Throw in Ben Chapman, a Yankee outfielder in the lineup with Gehrig and Ruth from 1930-34 who also stole home 15 times in his career, and what emerges is a Yankee team glorified for its ability to pound the ball, but always a threat to swipe home plate.

Where does Jackie Robinson rank?  A. He placed ahead of Tinker and behind Evers once he got the chance to play in the major leagues.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/08/14/0275222.xml	        Stealing Home  Q. An answer last week to a question about Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig's steals of home reported that Ty Cobb, with 50, and Max Carey, with 33, head the career list for this feat. Where does Jackie Robinson rank?  A. He placed ahead of Tinker and behind Evers once he got the chance to play in the major leagues. For the record, Robinson shares ninth place on the career list for swiping home plate with Frankie Frisch, each with 19. Also for the record, Robinson did his swiping in a significantly shorter amount of time than any of those ahead of him, and he did it with powerhouse Brooklyn Dodger teams from 1947-56 that hardly had to steal home to score runs.

Extra Hitting  Q. What is the record for extra-base hits by a batter in a season?  A. It depends on which side of the plate you're batting from. Babe Ruth, with 119 long hits, holds the major league mark, set in 1921 with the Yankees, and that's also the record for left-handed batters. Ruth had 59 home runs, 44 doubles and 16 triples (as well as 85 singles). Ruth's mark is also the American League high for a season. The National League standard belongs to Chuck Klein, also a left-hander, who achieved 59 doubles, 40 home runs and 8 triples for 107 extra-base hits with the Philadelphia Phillies in 1930.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/09/11/0282434.xml	        Much of the material is fascinating. Mote tells us, for example, how Jack Norworth, a vaudeville performer and song writer (''Shine On Harvest Moon'') who had never attended a big league game, wrote the lyrics to what became ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game'' on a subway train in 1908. He also contends that, based on his research, the first song written about the game was ''The Base Ball Polka,'' written in 1859, and lists the 15 musical tributes to Babe Ruth, written from 1920 through 1948, a musical record for a baseball figure. Mote lists about 1,000 songs written about baseball, including such memorable tunes as ''Joltin' Joe DiMaggio'' (1941) through the recent ''Talkin' Baseball'' series by Terry Cashman.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/09/18/0284094.xml	        LEAD:  Always on Base  Q. Did any major leaguer ever have a season with at least 400 times at bat in which he reached base more than half the times he batted?  A. You can count on one hand the number of players who have done it since 1900. On the other hand, only two players really matter - Babe Ruth and Ted Williams - because they dominated this particular aspect of batting, doing it seven of the nine times it was accomplished.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/09/18/0284094.xml	        Always on Base  Q. Did any major leaguer ever have a season with at least 400 times at bat in which he reached base more than half the times he batted?  A. You can count on one hand the number of players who have done it since 1900. On the other hand, only two players really matter - Babe Ruth and Ted Williams - because they dominated this particular aspect of batting, doing it seven of the nine times it was accomplished. In 1941, when he batted .406, Williams, baseball's last .400 hitter, put together a .551 on-base average, the best ever. It was so good that for the season, he finished 99 percentage points ahead of the American League's second-best performer in on-base average, Roy Cullenbine of the St. Louis Browns. Williams had 185 hits that season, including 33 doubles and 37 home runs, and walked 145 times. The Boston Red Sox outfielder also has the fourth-best on-base percentage in baseball history, .516, in 1954, and he didn't do badly in 1942 or 1947 either, when he barely failed to reach base half the time with .499 percentages.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/09/28/0286550.xml	        LEAD: rrIn baseball, 900 has never been much of a number. Henry Aaron and Babe Ruth didn't hit that many homers. Tris Speaker didn't even hit that many doubles. Cy Young didn't pitch that many victories. No team has ever had that high a winning percentage. Nobody ever made a fuss over a 900th hit or a 900th strikeout.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/09/28/0286550.xml	        rrIn baseball, 900 has never been much of a number. Henry Aaron and Babe Ruth didn't hit that many homers. Tris Speaker didn't even hit that many doubles. Cy Young didn't pitch that many victories. No team has ever had that high a winning percentage. Nobody ever made a fuss over a 900th hit or a 900th strikeout. The only 900 number of any significance in baseball is 938, Lou Brock's record career total of stolen bases.
