nyt_corpus_1989.har/10/08/0289049.xml	        TOTAL BASEBALL. Edited by John Thorn and Pete Palmer with David Reuther. (Warner, $49.95.) Baseball is the game of numbers. Its order and its complexities have invited, even demanded, statistics for more than a century. ''Total Baseball'' is one of the best baseball statistics books ever. It uses the traditional statistics, accumulated though painstaking research (Ty Cobb had 4,190 hits, not 4,191), as well as new ones: the so-called sabermetrics popularized by Bill James and by John Thorn and Pete Palmer in their book, ''The Hidden Game of Baseball,'' to rate players of different eras by adjustments that reflect how the game has changed. Their computer base goes back into the last century, and using the Thorn-Palmer scheme of Linear Weights (best defined in the book, not in a short review) they determine that the best single season by a pitcher was Silver King's in 1888 with the St. Louis Browns, when he had 45 wins, 21 losses and a 1.64 e.r.a. Similarly, their numbers maintain that the 10 all-time best careers ever were those of Babe Ruth, Ty Cobb, Hank Aaron,Ted Williams, Willie Mays, Nap Lajoie, Walter Johnson, Cy Young, Tris Speaker and Mike Schmidt. Pick your statistic, traditional or newfangled, and look at the records of 13,000 players. Don't be put off by the 2,294 pages; the first 678 are essays, mostly forgettable. The numbers start on page 679.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/10/30/0296078.xml	        In the Yankee eighth, Alexander retired Joe Dugan on a grounder to shortstop, Pat Collins on a foul pop to first and Herb Pennock on a pop to second. With Meusel, a .315 hitter, at bat, Ruth attempted to steal second base, but was thrown out by the Cardinals' catcher, Bob O'Farrell. That mistake by Ruth ended the Series, giving Alexander a save and O'Farrell something to savor.  Longer Than Simms  Q. How many current quarterbacks in the National Football League have been regulars with the same team as long as Phil Simms has been one with the Giants?  A. Basically, there are none, not even Joe Montana, who started his career with the San Francisco 49ers in 1979, the same year Simms began with the Giants. But Montana did not become a regular until late in the next season: he only started one game in his rookie season, and he made only 23 pass attempts, while Steve DeBerg did the bulk of the quarterbacking for the 49ers.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/11/07/0298535.xml	        ''To an extent, I lead a baseball-dominated life,'' she continues. ''Not only does the stadium emit strange lights and sounds - my mother and I soon become accustomed to the twi-nights, accept them as naturally as Norsemen must have tolerated their endless days in the land of the midnight sun - but the entire neighborhood is designed around the sport. Bronze statuettes of baseball heroes pose at the intersections like signposts. I pass 'Babe Ruth' on my way to school, meet Diana at Yogi Berra Plaza. Every day I walk through an outdoor baseball hall of fame.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/11/26/0304438.xml	        There have been history movies for decades, of course, from Eisenstein's ''Ten Days that Shook the World'' (with its famous - and unhistorical - scenes of Kerensky hiding under his couch) to ''The Babe Ruth Story.'' But the latest examples have been particularly big-budget affairs, beginning with Richard Attenborough's ''Gandhi'' a few years ago, and continuing through such serious and less serious efforts as Roland Joffe's ''Killing Fields,'' Bernardo Bertolucci's ''Last Emperor,'' Alan Parker's ''Mississippi Burning'' and Mr. Attenborough's ''Cry Freedom.'' In a world dominated by Top Guns, Lethal Weapons and Police Academies, the mere fact that some directors concentrate on critical episodes of our past is in its way heartening. At the same time, there is something disconcerting about the tendency of movies-as-history to construct Technicolored and sound-tracked edifices of entertainment on the slender foundations of what appear to be actual events, or, at the very least, to mingle fact with fancy, history with imagination, in such a way that the average viewer has no way of sorting out one from the other.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/12/04/0306539.xml	        Six other cities have provided sites for the showdown, but for Army and Navy, it's apparent they'd rather be in Philadelphia, for 67 of the 89 games have been held there. Eleven times the rivals met in New York City, which was a home advantage of sorts for Army, and twice they met in Baltimore; advantage, Navy. Single games have been played in Princeton, N.J. (a 6-6 tie in 1905), Chicago (a 21-21 tie in 1926), and Pasadena, Calif. (a 42-13 Navy romp in the Rose Bowl stadium in 1983). This year there will be another site, Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., which geographically gives West Point a home-away-from-home advantage.  Sluggers by Decade  Q. An article in the Times's Sunday sports section last week mentioned that Mike Schmidt of the Philadelphia Phillies had hit the most home runs, 313, for the period 1980-89. Over the decades, how many players have exceeded Schmidt's total for such a 10-year span?  A. Only seven other players, all of them Hall of Fame members, have outslugged Schmidt, and more than half of them did it in the decade of 1960-69, when baseball expanded twice, thrusting into the major leagues a lot of pitchers who didn't belong there. Babe Ruth, who helped put the roar into the Twenties, hit the most home runs in a decade, 467 in 1920-29, during his first 10 years with the Yankees. For the next decade, 1930-39, Jimmie Foxx of the Philadelphia Athletics and the Boston Red Sox hammered 415 home runs, which is second to Ruth.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/12/05/0306708.xml	        In previous eras, there have been incidents of, to use the modern slang of contumely, ''hot dogging.'' The most famous was the moment when Babe Ruth pointed, or didn't point, before hitting a home run in the 1932 World Series. And the best known self-aggrandizer of that era was Dizzy Dean. But both the Ruth incident and the Dean character stand out as exceptions.
nyt_corpus_1989.har/12/10/0308160.xml	        The debate is not about Kermit the Frog versus the Three Little Pigs, Willie Mays versus Babe Ruth or investment versus savings. Some of these terms are defined in E. D. Hirsch Jr.'s well-presented new effort, ''A First Dictionary of Cultural Literacy,'' and some are not. The issue is really whether our primary educational focus should be on rote memory of certain facts - any facts - or on developing the tools and processes whereby students learn.

nyt_corpus_1989.har/12/25/0311974.xml	        As for Huggins, his managerial career intersected the rise of Babe Ruth and the Yankee dynasty in the 1920's. nyt_corpus_1990.har/01/22/0319116.xml	        A. If you had picked up a major league baseball record book in April 1921, the listing under ''Most Home Runs in a Career by a Player Since 1900'' would have read: ''Gavvy Cravath, 119.'' If you had picked up the record book the following April, the listing would have been: ''Babe Ruth, 162.''
nyt_corpus_1990.har/01/22/0319116.xml	        As for Cravath, he played 11 major league seasons in 1908-20: as an outfielder with the Boston Red Sox for one season, the Chicago White Sox and the Washington Senators for parts of another, and the Philadelphia Phillies for nine seasons, the last two as player-manager. Six times he led the National League in home runs, with a high of 24 in 1915, when the Phillies won the pennant. In the World Series that year, Cravath's team was beaten in five games by the Red Sox, whose leading home-run hitter over the regular season, with four, was a pitcher named Babe Ruth.

nyt_corpus_1990.har/02/25/0329851.xml	        The lines at the aquarium are testament to its popularity - with more than 10.5 million visitors since it opened in the summer of 1981. Group reservations are a must and the best time to tour the facility is as early in the day as possible. Admission: Adult, $7.75; students, senior citizens and active military, $6; children 3 to 11, $4.75; children under 3 free. Reduced group rates. (Rates to increase in June for marine mammal pavilion.) The Inner Harbor's most celebrated seagoing attraction is the Constellation, the oldest United States naval vessel afloat, which is permanently berthed at the Inner Harbor. The splendidly restored frigate, launched in 1797, had an active naval career until the end of the Second World War. The vessel is open daily from 10 A.M. until 4 P.M., later hours in the summer months. Admission: Adults, $2.25; senior citizens, $1.75; children 6 to 15, $1.25; active military, $1. Telephone: 301-539-1797. The glitter of the Inner Harbor has never posed a serious threat to Baltimore's oldest tourist attraction, Fort McHenry. There, on the morning of Sept. 14, 1814, having survived a 25-hour British naval bombardment, the American garrison displayed a 30-by-42-foot flag. Francis Scott Key, a lawyer and amateur poet, observed the flag from a truce ship nearby, sat down shortly after and wrote ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' The 43-acre national park at the restored fort is a green and peaceful respite from the rest of the city. It offers a terrific view of the vast working waterfront, escorted tours and a film on the fort's history. Open daily from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. (8 P.M. in the summer). Admission $1, adults; children and senior citizens free. Telephone: 301-962-4299. Babe Ruth He made his baseball reputation elsewhere, but George Herman Ruth was born in Baltimore and devotees of the national pastime come to his hometown to see where it all started. The 12-foot-wide rowhouse at 216 Emory Street, rather grandly named the Babe Ruth Birthplace and Maryland Baseball Hall of Fame, is chockful of baseball memorabilia, including a life-size mechanized figure of the Sultan of Swat in his prime, along with gold plaques commemorating each of his 714 home runs. Open daily from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., later in summer months. Admission: Adults, $3; senior citizens, $2; children, $1.50. Telephone: 301-727-1539.
nyt_corpus_1990.har/02/25/0329851.xml	        The Baltimore Orioles play their home games at Memorial Stadium (on Babe Ruth Plaza no less) on 33d Street. The Birds open to Kansas City on April 2 in a game that is traditionally a sellout. Tickets and homestand information, 301-481-6000 or 800-448-9009, or 202-432-0200 in the Washington area.

nyt_corpus_1990.har/03/04/0331634.xml	        Satisfactory (March 10, 1989), 42 Central Park South (688-7777) - This is virtually a baseball museum of photographs, posters, videotape and vintage uniforms that include Mickey Mantle's No. 7, Babe Ruth's and Joe DiMaggio's. Service is enthusiastic, and the food familiar though uneven. One welcome feature here is a children's menu offering lower-priced, smaller entrees. Hamburgers are superior, as is chicken pot pie (available in children's portion) with fresh chicken, carrots, okra and peas. Also on the menu are grilled shrimp and crabmeat sandwich; no-bean chili; homemade desserts, and a low-fat, low-calorie section, Spring Training Specials. nyt_corpus_1990.har/04/01/0339785.xml	        SUMMER OF '49, by David Halberstam. (Avon, $4.95.) Rallying from way behind, the Boston Red Sox come within a game of beating the Yankees for the pennant. Last year our reviewer, Justin Kaplan, said David Halberstam's account of the race is ''vigorous, altogether engrossing, loaded with dugout insight and wonderful vignettes.'' Perennial/Harper & Row has reissued BASEBALL ANECDOTES, by Daniel Okrent and Steve Wulf ($9.95). The book is full of ''beguiling minutiae,'' Maria Gallagher said here in 1989. ''Even the most erudite baseball fan may not know that Babe Ruth was the game's first underwear model, that the brainy catcher Moe Berg counted Sanskrit among the languages he knew, that Rogers Hornsby avoided movies to protect his batting eye or that the former Yankee manager Billy Martin had cosmetic surgery on his nose when he was 22 years old.''
nyt_corpus_1990.har/04/01/0339801.xml	        In 1930, the Yankees paid Babe Ruth the unprecedented sum of $80,000 to hit home runs. When reminded that this was more than President Herbert Hoover earned, the Bambino reportedly quipped, ''I had a better year than he did.'' Today, when even the average major leaguer's salary is about two and a half times what President Bush makes, there is far less laughter on the scene; as this past winter's lockout again dramatized, baseball has become not just big business but confrontational big business, with the worst labor-management relations on the national sports scene. Now comes a timely book purporting to tell us how it happened.
nyt_corpus_1990.har/04/01/0339805.xml	        Yaz was taken aback by Fenway Park when he first saw it. There was the Monster, the big green wall in left field, and right field 380 feet away, to be precise. Well, Yaz flourished at Fenway. He played the wall better than Ted Williams, who preceded him in left field, or Jim Rice, who followed him. When he started with the Sox, the wall had rivets sticking out of it, and 2-by-4's and tin. You played the rivets or the tin or ''the holes in the scoreboard.'' Yaz admits he ''didn't have the grace of DiMaggio'' or the power of Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle or Ted Williams - but none of them got as many hits and as many home runs.
nyt_corpus_1990.har/04/01/0339872.xml	        LEAD: BIG STICKS: The Batting Revolution of the Twenties. By William Curran. (Morrow, $18.95.) William Curran, the author of ''Mitts,'' gives us a detailed and lively history of baseball in the 1920's, with chapters on Babe Ruth, Rogers Hornsby, John J. McGraw, Ty Cobb, the Chicago Cubs and the 1927 Yankees' ''Murderers' Row.
nyt_corpus_1990.har/04/01/0339872.xml	        BIG STICKS: The Batting Revolution of the Twenties. By William Curran. (Morrow, $18.95.) William Curran, the author of ''Mitts,'' gives us a detailed and lively history of baseball in the 1920's, with chapters on Babe Ruth, Rogers Hornsby, John J. McGraw, Ty Cobb, the Chicago Cubs and the 1927 Yankees' ''Murderers' Row.'' His focus is the ''batting revolution'' that, he argues, transformed the ''scientific'' game of the 1910's into the power game of the 20's. Previously, teams struggled to score a run at a time as batters choked up on the bat to gain enough control to push the ball over the infielders' heads. In the power game, batters were encouraged to swing from the heels and, to quote one of Mr. Curran's colorful but somewhat misplaced metaphors, ''runs scored by the half dozen and base hits showered the still-new steel-and-concrete ball parks like cherry blossoms in a high wind.'' Batting averages rose an average of 40 points from 1918 to 1925. More remarkable was the increase in home runs. In 1917, Babe Ruth tied for the league lead in home runs with nine; the league record was 16. In 1919, Ruth hit 29 homers in 130 games; in 1920, he hit 54. The only losers were the pitchers, whose collective earned run average ballooned from 2.68 in 1917 to 4.33 in 1925. The hitting revolution was abetted by new rules that restricted and then prohibited trick pitches like the spitter. The so-called rabbit ball, which is usually identified as a primary cause of the hitter's ascendancy, had nothing to do it; Mr. Curran takes a full chapter to dispute angrily the theory that the owners imported a ''live'' ball to increase home run production. Mr. Curran writes well, but not well enough to hold the interest of the general reader. However, for those who thrive on stories, statistics and descriptions of past batting heroes, pennant races and World Series, ''Big Sticks'' may prove irresistible.
nyt_corpus_1990.har/04/03/0340347.xml	        Mr. Verral's works in the 1950's included novels about a boy detective. He wrote nonfiction books about jets and about space, as well as biographies of Babe Ruth, Casey Stengel and the rocket pioneer Robert Goddard.

nyt_corpus_1990.har/04/29/0348331.xml	        CULT BASEBALL PLAYERS: The Greats, the Flakes, the Weird, and the Wonderful. Edited by Danny Peary. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, Paper, $9.95.) Bait-and-switch alert: Willie Mays is not a cult baseball player. Neither are Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle, Duke Snider, Ted Williams, Henry Aaron or Lou Gehrig, though all appear in ''Cult Baseball Players,'' an uneven collection of 60 hero-worshiping essays by writers of large and small repute.
nyt_corpus_1990.har/04/29/0348331.xml	        CULT BASEBALL PLAYERS: The Greats, the Flakes, the Weird, and the Wonderful. Edited by Danny Peary. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, Paper, $9.95.) Bait-and-switch alert: Willie Mays is not a cult baseball player. Neither are Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle, Duke Snider, Ted Williams, Henry Aaron or Lou Gehrig, though all appear in ''Cult Baseball Players,'' an uneven collection of 60 hero-worshiping essays by writers of large and small repute. The title whets the appetite for an anthology flush with one-game wonders, flamboyant flameouts, assorted oddballs and box-score cameos; the subtitle backs off that promise, allowing the aforementioned Hall of Famers to horn in. In fact, the only one-game wonder in the book is one of the writers: Larry Colton, who pitched two innings for the Philadelphia Phillies in 1968. But yes, the expected eccentrics do make the lineup: blunderful Marv Throneberry, Dick (Dr. Strangeglove) Stuart, Mark (The Bird) Fidrych, the minor-league fireballer Steve Dalkowski, the backward baserunner Jimmy Piersall, the starlet-struck Bo Belinsky, the catcher turned World War II spy Moe Berg. The best profiles establish a personal connection between writer and subject. The Washington Post sportswriter Thomas Boswell enjoyed two unblemished encounters with his hero, Roy Sievers. The film director John Sayles tells why he adopted Dick Stuart as his soul mate in fielding futility. The actor John Lithgow says he ''first encountered the entire concept of 'biceps' in connection with Big Klu,'' the sleeveless Cincinnati slugger Ted Kluszewski. The book's editor, Danny Peary, the author of ''Cult Movies,'' waxes long-winded about his own idol, Vic Power, then appends a 22-page transcript of an interview he did with the slick-fielding first baseman. Mr. Power's comments on life as a black-skinned Puerto Rican big-leaguer in the 1950's make some of the best reading in the book. They will enlighten a generation of fans who never saw him play. They don't, however, make him a cult baseball player.
nyt_corpus_1990.har/04/29/0348672.xml	        LEAD: Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig never accepted money for their autographs, and Ted Williams used to privately visit sick children in hospitals for free. Today's athletes embarrass themselves by accepting money for autographs when real heroes once signed them out of love for the game and for the kids who make it so special.

I mention Brown, who died in 1976, because he was much loved and stories are told of his generosity, his eccentricities and his friendships - the strange estate in this cove had been visited by Brown's drinking and golfing cronies, Bing Crosby, Bob Hope and Babe Ruth. In the center of one of Keawaiki's brackish fishponds was a semi-ruined dwelling, which had been a little pavilion once upon a time, where Brown kept the girl of his dreams, a hula dancer named Winona Love.

Now here's strong evidence to the contrary. ''A Stone of the Heart'' is set in Queens in 1961, as Roger Maris is striving to break Babe Ruth's home-run record, a goal that rivets the attention of Michael, the 14-year-old protagonist. ''The feat seemed so herculean,'' he recalls, ''compared to the accomplishments and work of my father.''

nyt_corpus_1990.har/06/03/0358250.xml	        America canonized a legion of heroes between the two world wars, but even in the era of Lucky Lindy, Babe Ruth and Rudolph Valentino, few could match the luster of Richard Evelyn Byrd. A handsome Virginia aristocrat, Byrd, who was born in 1888, played the role of the peerless polar explorer to the hilt, frequently (and ostentatiously) risking his life to save his comrades while opening up both the Arctic and Antarctica to aviation. To many he seemed the embodiment of the Boy Scout virtues: courage, honor, patriotism, skill, magnanimity, modesty and moral rectitude.

nyt_corpus_1990.har/06/03/0358687.xml	        But in person, Vincent is far more engaging - a thoughtful, gentle, often charming man, with a wry sense of humor, who likes to quote both Dizzy Dean and the English romantic poets and managed to finish reading biographies of Wordsworth and Henry Adams during the lockout. He has a boyish enthusiasm and can get truly annoyed with himself for slipping and calling his old friend George Bush by his first name or, worse yet, Poppy. ''I've got to be more careful about that,'' he says reprovingly. And he has an intense, old-fashioned sense of loyalty, whether to his home state of Connecticut; his alma mater, Williams College, or to his friends, each of whom is inevitably described as a ''great guy'' or a ''terrific fella.'' Indeed, Vincent appears to be utterly without guile or pretense. During the labor talks, he kept saying he was trying to follow the old adage: ''When in doubt, do the right thing.'' And when he told this to a group of jaded sportswriters gathered for an evening briefing, no one snickered. Clearly, after two decades of arcane law and corporate politics, Vincent is relishing being a part of baseball. Unlike Ueberroth, who seemed more comfortable marketing the game than watching it, Vincent has pledged to try to get to all 26 major-league ball parks this season. During the marathon labor talks, he had Scott Sanderson, the Oakland Athletics pitcher and one of the players' representatives, show him the grip for a split-fingered fastball. And before a settlement was reached, he asked all the players present to sign a ball that now is displayed in his office next to the one autographed by Babe Ruth. ''This job is not like running a manufacturing business or a car dealership or a movie company,'' Vincent says, swiveling about in his leather office chair and plucking a cigar from a box behind him. ''Part of the marvel of baseball is its very special relationship with the American soul. And I'm very conscious of that.

nyt_corpus_1990.har/08/06/0374125.xml	        Let's consider a batter who com pletes a season with 198 hits in 600 times up, the hits consisting of 142 singles, 30 doubles, 6 triples and 20 home runs. His total bases would amount to 142 (142 singles worth 1 base each) plus 60 (30 doubles worth 2 bases each) plus 18 (6 triples worth 3 bases each) plus 80 (20 homers worth 4 bases each), which would equal 300 bases. Dividing that amount by 600 times at bat would yield a .500 slugging percentage, which would be considerably short of the major league record for a season, .847, set by Babe Ruth for the 1920 Yankees (73 singles, 36 doubles, 9 triples, 54 home runs). Ruth nearly matched that slugging average the following year with an astounding 85 singles, 44 doubles, 16 triples and 59 homers for a slugging percentage of .846.
nyt_corpus_1990.har/08/12/0375722.xml	        LEAD: As soon as i'd gotten the improbable call inviting me to Chicago to play in the Fifth Annual Equitable Old-Timers All-Star Game, my baseball dream merchant appeared. My vision was pure, uncomplicated: the brick and ivy of Wrigley Field, patriarchal, antediluvian, the baseball acropolis where Babe Ruth called his shot.
nyt_corpus_1990.har/08/12/0375722.xml	        As soon as i'd gotten the improbable call inviting me to Chicago to play in the Fifth Annual Equitable Old-Timers All-Star Game, my baseball dream merchant appeared. My vision was pure, uncomplicated: the brick and ivy of Wrigley Field, patriarchal, antediluvian, the baseball acropolis where Babe Ruth called his shot. A standing-room-only crowd, 40 living legends - Joltin' Joe, Hammerin' Hank, Mr. Cub - and me. I'd be sitting on the bench, sandwiched between Bob Gibson and Steve Garvey, discussing hook slides and politics. Up in the stands, my dad would be sharing the moment. Then manager Monte Irvin's words would jump-start my nervous heart. ''Go up there and pinch-hit for Aaron,'' he'd say. I'd been invited to play at Wrigley with these great names in baseball history because, well, it's a weird story. Back in 1968, I was a rookie pitcher with the Philadelphia Phillies. In my major league debut at Crosley Field in Cincinnati, the first batter I faced, Pete Rose, lashed my third pitch, a room-service fastball, for a stand-up double. Really, I'm not making this up. Rose didn't score - Vada Pinson whiffed on a slider, leaving Rose on third - but as fate would have it, a few days later I got the bejabbers beat out of me by two thugs in San Francisco, separating my shoulder. I never pitched in another big-league game. My career stats: 1 game, 2 innings pitched, 3 hits, 1 run, 2 strikeouts.

Clark, a Cooperstown millionaire who had accumulated his wealth with the Singer Sewing Machine Company, donated the land for the Hall of Fame, thereby inspiring the first baseball writers' vote in 1935 that elected Ty Cobb, Babe Ruth, Honus Wagner, Christy Mathewson and Walter Johnson as charter inductees. nyt_corpus_1991.har/01/11/0414391.xml	        Dominating the first segment of sporting items, which include autographs, photographs and uniforms of baseball, football and hockey players, are baseball cards from the 1880's to the 1960's. Baseball items have been collected for a century, but have escalated in popularity as celebrity memorabilia did in recent years. The most important offering is a complete set of 239 palm-sized baseball cards from 1933, issued by the Goudey Gum Company of Boston, the first published by a gum producer and the first complete set from that year ever auctioned, Guernsey's says. Four cards depict Babe Ruth, two show Lou Gehrig, and the rest feature such stars as Mel Ott, Carl Hubbell, Lefty Grove, Jimmy Foxx, Dizzy Dean and Rogers Hornsby.

nyt_corpus_1991.har/01/29/0418735.xml	        With his many notable achievements on the football field -- some so spectacular they still read like fiction -- Red Grange fit easily into that group of superstars that helped elevate the 1920's into a golden age of sports in the United States. nyt_corpus_1991.har/02/05/0420433.xml	        Only a few baseball players are identified forever with a year: Babe Ruth with 1927, Bobby Thomson with 1951, Roger Maris with 1961. Baker: Puppeteer No Longer
nyt_corpus_1991.har/02/17/0423925.xml	        Washington and London, at Odds in the Air  All's fair in love, war and international airline negotiations. Disputes over airline rights can divide even friends as close as Britain and the United States. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner rejected British Airways' proposed fare cuts to the United States last Tuesday. Britain had blocked the sale by Pan Am and Trans World Airlines, both desperate for cash, of several London routes to Heathrow airport that United and American Airlines want to buy. Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways, flew into New York himself last week to display solicitude for the ailing airlines. The dispute is "not about knocking Pan Am or T.W.A. out of business altogether," he said. He also urged timid Americans to resume traveling abroad; those who don't risk losing business, he said. What British Airways actually seeks are broader operating rights in the United States, said American analysts. Problem is, that sort of deal might normally take a year to work out; T.W.A. and Pan Am need agreements within a few months.  Oddball Salary Inequities  When Babe Ruth was asked, about 60 years ago, why he deserved $80,000 when President Hoover only made $75,000, Ruth's legendary response was, "I had a better year than he did." A week ago, Roger Clemens signed a four-year contract giving him a record average of $5.4 million a year; President Bush draws $200,000. Clemens won 21 games, holding opponents to an average of less than two runs a game. George Bush showed quick reflexes in the Persian Gulf but bobbled the tax issue. So Clemens did have the better year. But 27 times better? Enough so that the cost of a single Clemens victory more than covers Bush's salary for an entire season? And the President certainly outplayed, say, Jeff Parrett, the Atlanta Braves pitcher, who recently settled for $855,000 after winning five, losing 10. Memo to team owners wanting to economize: draft George, the former Yale baseball captain, when his Washington contract is up. Alcohol-Fed Inflation Economists have found another fuel to blame for increasing wholesale inflation. A record 5.9 percent jump in alcohol prices raised the core inflation rate in January by five-tenths of 1 percent. Higher alcohol taxes do not figure into producer prices, but many manufacturers took the chance to raise their own prices. Some economists said that, even after accounting for liquor costs, the rising core rate would keep the Federal Reserve from easing further. "The Fed will rest on its oars for at least a couple more weeks," said Irwin L. Kellner of Manufacturers Hanover Trust. The broader inflation rate, including food and energy, fell one-tenth of 1 percent, as oil prices declined. Golden Arch of Catfish?  McDonald's believes it has found a recipe for Southern success: The Crispy Catfish Sandwich, a 2.3-ounce patty with lettuce and tangy sauce on a bun. McDonald's plans to sell it at 214 outlets in Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, Kentucky and Tennessee. Restaurants that specialize in catfish are hardly trembling. Don Buckner, general manager of Hall's on the River in Winchester, Ky., described McDonald's seafood sandwiches as "block pieces of fish" -- suitable for someone who would otherwise have a quarter-pounder. His $9.95 all-you-can-eat catfish dinner includes vegetables and hush puppies, he added. No hush puppies at McDonald's, said a spokeswoman, convinced that Southern customers will accept french fries. Competition for Cellular Lines All that static on the cellular phone lines is coming from aggrieved duopolists. The Federal Communications Commission decided on Wednesday to allow a new form of mobile service in six cities, including New York. Radio dispatch companies for taxis and delivery services will be able to squeeze thousands of other customers into their narrow slices of the radio spectrum. Cellular services that have flourished under rules allowing only two in each city could find competition heating up. Analysts doubt the new service, to be offered initially by Fleet Call Inc. of Bloomfield, N.J., will match cellular's flexibility and features. But the cellular industry called the decision unfair and threatened a fight. Production Declines Ease The slump in industrial output continued for a fourth month in January, but the decline was a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent after much steeper drops in the two previous months. Some economists said the report hints that the worst of the recession is past. But industries used only 79.9 percent of their capacity, the least in four years. In Brief A seven-tenths of 1 percent decline in already lean business inventories in December gave economists hope that any increase in demand would result in higher production. Citibank, long aloof and superior, has decided to join the automated teller machine masses. Its machines will become part of the Cirrus network, sharing access with machines from 7,200 other banks and financial institutions.  COMPANIES

nyt_corpus_1991.har/03/04/0427686.xml	        Play Lazzeri did, from 1926 to 1939, and to the tune of a lifetime batting average of .292 -- one year he hit .354 -- and whacking out 178 home runs and driving in 1,191 runs. And at second base, Lazzeri, who stood nearly 6 feet tall and had long, graceful movements, was considered one of the smartest of players. Among his teammates, he was a respected leader, as well as a practical joker. Once when Babe Ruth showed up late for a game and tried to pull his spiked shoes out of the locker, he found them nailed to the floor. It was, the players knew, typical Lazzeri handiwork.

nyt_corpus_1991.har/04/07/0435549.xml	        Yankee fans can be forgiven if they prefer to dwell on the franchise's heroic past rather than contemplate its dubious present. "The Yankees Reader," deftly edited by Miro Weinberger, a student at Yale University, and Dan Riley, the editor of "The Red Sox Reader" and "The Cubs Reader," presents tales from the glorious history of what once was baseball's most consistently successful team. Babe Ruth, Yogi Berra, Roger Maris, Reggie Jackson and Don Mattingly, among others, are celebrated by such writers as Grantland Rice, Red Smith, Shirley Povich and Thomas Boswell. Included are contemporary newspaper accounts of the opening of Yankee Stadium, the end of Lou Gehrig's iron-man streak and Don Larsen's perfect game in the 1956 World Series, as well as excerpts from players' memoirs, Hemingway's tribute to Joe DiMaggio in "The Old Man and the Sea" and Casey Stengel's hilarious testimony at a Senate subcommittee hearing on antitrust laws and professional sports in 1958.
nyt_corpus_1991.har/04/07/0435550.xml	        The careers of the Babe Ruths, the Willie Mayses and the Sandy Koufaxes are celebrated in baseball lore, but in "One Shining Season" Michael Fedo celebrates the mediocre ballplayer who had his one moment in the sun. Insightful interviews with 11 former major leaguers tell us why these players enjoyed a period of extraordinary play and why they were never able to duplicate it. Ned Garver pitched for the 1951 St. Louis Browns and won 20 of his team's 54 games that season. He developed arm trouble, and although he had a solid 14-year career in the big leagues, he never approached his 1951 form. Billy Grabarkewitz of the Los Angeles Dodgers, who batted .376 for the first three months of the 1970 season, castigates meddlesome coaches who tried to change his batting style during that hot streak. Wes Parker, also of the Dodgers, decided that the Spartan life he led during his career season of 1970 wasn't worth the price and retired from the game two years later. Though his play in those two years was solid, it never approached the standard he set in 1970, when he batted .319. If you enjoy hearing yesterday's stars tell their tales, you will enjoy hearing the Bob Hazles, the Walt Dropos and the Dave Nicholsons tell theirs as well.
nyt_corpus_1991.har/04/07/0435697.xml	        After 1949 the weakness of the Red Sox teams encouraged his self-absorption. nyt_corpus_1991.har/04/07/0435708.xml	        Such was the unfortunate mind-set of the 50's, and consequently, I could not have imagined that a young black man from my home state would someday surpass Babe Ruth's record, nor could I have ever dreamed of the hardships that same young man would have to go through just to do the thing he loved and did so well.

nyt_corpus_1991.har/04/16/0437761.xml	        The Yankees haven't won a pennant since 1981, one of the team's longest droughts since the Babe Ruth days. nyt_corpus_1991.har/07/02/0456872.xml	        PETE ROSE 's ban from baseball caused producers of a television movie about BABE RUTH to alter the film, in which Rose portrays TY COBB . The producers of the film, which is to appear on NBC on Oct. 6, sought permission from major league baseball to use team logos and uniforms. "Usually, when we grant rights, we demand to review the script so as not to portray baseball in a negative light," RICK WHITE , president of Major League Baseball Properties, said yesterday. When the producers decided to use the career hits leader to play Cobb, the man whose record he broke, they were given some stern advice. "We told them, 'We don't want you not to employ Pete Rose, but if you do, he can't appear in a uniform because he is on the disqualified list,'(TM)" White said.(AP)  SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL

nyt_corpus_1991.har/11/03/0484516.xml	        Professor's comments: "Most of the students who take the course have no idea why Babe Ruth was famous. They know the name, but they have no idea why he was significant. Or that Joe Louis was the first black to hit the front pages of the American media. We focus on individuals who impacted not just their sport but our lives. We have athletes in the class, but not as many as you think. Normally, no more than 7 or 8 in a class of 50. Because you have to study. It's not a gimme class." -- Lawrence Knuth, instructor Course title: The Beatles -- Their Music and Their Times  Institution: University of Southern California  Department: Music

nyt_corpus_1992.har/04/05/0519229.xml	        Tom Seaver, the Hall of Fame pitcher, in collaboration with Marty Appel, the author of "Baseball's Best" and "Yesterday's Heroes," has compiled his choice of 50 spectacular events in major league baseball since 1903, when the fledgling American League met the National League in the first World Series. They include accounts of Walter Johnson's only World Series, Babe Ruth's called-shot home run, Joe DiMaggio's hitting streak, Willie Mays's celebrated over-the-shoulder catch and the "worst to first" World Series last year. The story of the Miracle Mets of 1969 is included, and Mr. Seaver describes his emotions after his team won the World Series: "I realized for the first time that the ultimate joy is not in the clubhouse, spraying champagne. . . . That day I understood that the process in itself is the reward." Mixed in are fascinating facts. Sunday games were played only in Chicago, St. Louis and Cincinnati until 1933, when the 13 other teams overcame religious objections. The Cincinnati Reds introduced baseball under the lights in 1935. The Yankees introduced numbers on uniforms in 1929, and Mr. Seaver witnessed a change when he joined the New York Mets in 1967: "I was there when the flannel turned to double knit." "Great Moments in Baseball" is for addicts who yearn for more than computerized statistical tables.
nyt_corpus_1992.har/04/05/0519235.xml	        Here is a 608-page book, first published in 1981 and newly brought up to date, with nary a sentence beyond its very brief preface, just columns of names, dates and numbers. But these stats are far from static -- what stories they tell! What more drama could a baseball fan find than in the 11 lines under "Pinch-Hit Home Run in First At-Bat in Majors"? Want more heroics? See the roster of players who most often spoiled no-hitters by getting the only hit in a game. The record is five times, shared by Cesar Tovar and Eddie Milner. "Shutout With Most Hits Allowed" -- Walter Johnson holds the record, allowing 15 hits in 15 innings and surviving with a 1-0 Washington win against Boston in 1913. "The Great All-Time Baseball Record Book" -- which was originally compiled by Joseph L. Reichler, the former editor of The Baseball Encyclopedia, who died in 1988, and updated by Ken Samelson, the encyclopedia's research coordinator -- also lists memorable performers like players who got two hits in one inning twice in one game or who suffered two strikeouts in one inning, and pitchers who hit two home runs in one game twice in one season. There's enough trivia to win bar bets until the winter meetings. Plenty of baseball buffs know the identity of the best-hitting pitcher of all time: Babe Ruth, of course. But the worst? Ron Herbel, with a .029 career average. Most runs scored in an inning? Eighteen, by the Chicago Cubs on Sept. 6, 1883. (For the modern era, it's 17, by the Boston Red Sox on June 18, 1953.) Best hitting brothers? Paul and Lloyd Waner. Saber metricians, go crunch yourselves.

nyt_corpus_1992.har/04/17/0522118.xml	        On April 18, 1923, a huge crowd of 74,200 watched the dominant New York Yankees play their first game in their new stadium, built in the Bronx on the site of an old lumber yard. Gov. Al Smith threw out the first ball, and the Yankees went on to defeat their increasingly bitter rivals, the Boston Red Sox, 4 to 1. Only one more drama was needed to cap off Yankee Stadium's debut, and Babe Ruth provided it. He was coming off a poor season, had fought with management, watched his play diminish, and was now looking to redeem himself. With two men on in the third inning, Ruth launched a scorching line drive into the stands. The Times reported: "The biggest crowd in baseball history rose to its feet and let loose the biggest shout in baseball history. Ruth, jogging over the home plate, grinned broadly, lifted his cap at arm's length and waved it at the multitude."

nyt_corpus_1992.har/04/17/0522167.xml	        The new film about Ruth, "The Babe," has no room for separate versions. But it recounts a childlike success story at a time when adult-minded disclosures are sometimes thought to represent a deeper truth. So this film does its best to bolster the mythic Ruth naivete, even going so far as to dress John Goodman as an oversize child for the title role and show him marveling at modern inventions (circa 1920) like the elevator. At the same time, the film also acknowledges the kinds of recreational habits that would easily have kept Babe Ruth out of public office had he lived today.
nyt_corpus_1992.har/04/17/0522167.xml	        "The Babe," as genial and lumbering as the man whose story it tells, needs all the faux innocence it can muster to reconcile the extremes of Babe Ruth's career. Great effort on the part of the director Arthur Hiller and the screenwriter John Fusco has been expended to establish boyish guilelessness in the man once famed for being higher paid than the President of the United States, before that was commonplace. It took even greater effort to link that naivete with celebrity, prehistoric baseball groupies and the Babe's habit of showing up on the playing field still soused after all-night benders.

Mr. Goodman is convincing as both the incorrigible carouser and the abandoned boy who later showed great kindness to children. And even in the film's clumsy domestic scenes he shows some spark. nyt_corpus_1992.har/06/29/0539572.xml	        A. It might well be Babe Ruth or Ted Williams, but for the time being, the name in the record book for most times walking to first base on an intentional pass by a pitcher belongs to Henry Aaron, who also holds the mark for most times trotting around the bases on an unintentional pitch. The statistic of intentional walks was not kept too scrupulously for record books before 1955, a year that was considerably beyond Ruth's last game (1935) and about three-quarters into Williams's career (ended 1960). Those two left-handed-hitting outfielders are 1-2 in walks received, intentional or otherwise, with Ruth having walked 2,056 times and Williams 2,019.

nyt_corpus_1992.har/08/30/0553265.xml	        I HAD A HAMMER: The Hank Aaron Story, by Henry Aaron with Lonnie Wheeler. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.50.) Hank Aaron had to battle more than the opposing teams to earn his place in the Baseball Hall of Fame. After leaving segregated ball parks to spend most of his career with the Braves, Mr. Aaron was the object of racial slurs and even death threats as he approached his record-breaking 715th home run. Last year our reviewer, Fannie Flagg, found this book "beautifully written," noting that "it is virtually impossible to consider it just another sports autobiography." The history of the man whose record Mr. Aaron broke is also out in another edition: THE BABE RUTH STORY, by Babe Ruth as told to Bob Considine (Signet, $4.99). "Bob Considine . . . has done much more than describe Ruth's vagaries and exploits," Rex Lardner said in The New York Times in 1948. "He has captured the team personality of the Yankees of the 20's and 30's."

nyt_corpus_1992.har/09/13/0556259.xml	        In baseball the impact came a bit later. In the late 1920's, Andy Cohen, a New York Giant second baseman (from El Paso, of all places), was the first Jewish ballplayer promoted as a drawing card on the basis of ethnic identity. However, beginning in the 1930's, Hank Greenberg in Detroit produced the key commodity -- home runs -- that attracts fans and makes baseball stars transcendent. In 1934, Greenberg drew attention to his Jewishness by refusing to play an important game against the Yankees on Yom Kippur, even though he was the leading hitter on a Tigers team headed for the World Series. The degree to which he was depicted as a hero (for being "true to his religion") may seem odd now, but it altered the viewpoints of many during a time when overt anti-Semitism was a social norm. Then, in 1938, Greenberg came within two home runs of matching Babe Ruth's season record of 60. In 1941, he became one of the first major leaguers to enter the armed forces -- drafted in May, released two days before Pearl Harbor, an Army Air Corps enlistee a week later, in for the duration.

nyt_corpus_1992.har/10/14/0562796.xml	        "Baseball and Billions" looks behind the value of franchises, the financial threats against municipalities to keep teams from moving, and the profits that are concealed by accounting legerdemain. It's the player salaries that dominate the headlines, not the turnstile or the media or even the hot-dog profits. The best answer to accusations of player greed was given by Babe Ruth in 1930, when his pay reached $80,000 after he had helped to make millions for the Yankees. When he was told that his annual pay was $5,000 more than President Herbert Hoover's, Ruth replied: "What the hell has Hoover got to do with it? Besides, I had a better year than he did."

Not content to drop Babe Ruth's name in this late episode, Mr. Evans has also thrown Ruth's ghost into an earlier scene. nyt_corpus_1993.har/04/11/0601435.xml	        Fifteen months after the Yankees made an obvious steal by acquiring MELIDO PEREZ, BOB WICKMAN and DOMINGO JEAN for STEVE SAX, White Sox General Manager RON SCHUELER defended the trade that one Oakland A's scout said will be remembered as the "worst one since Babe Ruth." Although Schueler conceded that he regretted not extensively scouting Wickman and Jean, he said: "I'd make that trade again." Why? Because, Schueler said, Perez failed as a starter in Chicago, he is unimpressed with Wickman and he is unsure if Jean will produce in the majors. But Sax, now a third-string second baseman because of shoddy defense, belittled the trade. "If I was in their shoes," he said, "I would be saying, 'Why did we trade a couple of good pitchers for this guy?' nyt_corpus_1993.har/07/02/0618906.xml	        Recycled paper goes directly to mills, where it is quickly reduced to pulp, Mr. Gerrard noted. Trash paper, by contrast, is sorted by carriers, who are, at least theoretically, able to paw through it for tasty contracts or salacious tender-offer statements. Some trash paper, moreover, ends up in landfills, which are virtual archives: Dig into the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, and you can find perfectly legible contemporaneous newspaper stories on Babe Ruth and Herbert Hoover.

nyt_corpus_1993.har/07/25/0623687.xml	        Though he is just 49 years old, Giuliani often seems a striking throwback in New York City's anything-goes atmosphere. It's as if his cultural and psychic sensibilites froze about 1961, the year he left the tutelage of the Christian Brothers at Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn. This is a man so square that he started an opera club in high school and still refers to his old high-school classmates as "other youngsters"; so corny that he proposed to his current wife at Disney World; so accepting of authority that he says the nuns and brothers who taught him were right to smack him around, because he often deserved it. He says that he simply "missed" the convulsions of the 60's, that the dilemmas of long hair or inhaling "never came up." Pictures of Abraham Lincoln and Babe Ruth hang on his office wall; David Dinkins displays photographs of Nelson Mandela and Jennifer Capriati.

nyt_corpus_1993.har/08/01/0625634.xml	        Reggie Jackson hit 563 balls over the wall in his 21-year major league career, sixth on the career list; only Hank Aaron, Babe Ruth, Willie Mays, Frank Robinson and Harmon Killebrew had hit more. No one has ever moved about a ball field with as much obvious delight or seeming need to be in the spotlight, to virtually lasso it if necessary. It appeared that Reggie Jackson, 6 feet tall, 215 pounds and broadchested as a rooster, his eyes behind dark glasses and a roll to his stride, luxuriated as the chants of "Reg-gie!" "Reg-gie!" washed over him.

nyt_corpus_1993.har/08/15/0628980.xml	        The majors continue to be their own worst enemy, but the bulk of the game has never been in greater shape. The various rungs of the youth baseball ladder (Babe Ruth, Pony, Police Athletic League, etc.) leading from Little League to American Legion have more participants than ever. Baseball camps are proliferating. More young men at more high schools and colleges than ever are playing good, well coached baseball. A record 360,000 fans attended the National Collegiate Athletic Association regional tournaments and College World Series. Adult leagues for players 30 and older are rapidly increasing. The minor leagues, though handicapped by their association with the majors, last year had their best attendance since 1950, when there were three times as many teams.

nyt_corpus_1993.har/08/29/0631546.xml	        THOUGH its most popular summer game nowadays is slow-pitch softball, Stamford has always been a good baseball town. Its Little League and Babe Ruth League programs have produced world and national champions, respectively, and it lays claim to having the oldest continuous Twilight baseball league in the state. And in the 1940's there were four men's hardball leagues in the city, including a strong industrial league, along with a Class B minor league team in 1947 and 1948.

nyt_corpus_1993.har/11/29/0652993.xml	        Two haunting books of baseball nostalgia: BASEBALL ARCHAEOLOGY: Artifacts from the Great American Pastime. Photographs by Bret Wills. Text by Gwen Aldridge. (111 pages. Chronicle Books; $29.95.) Photos of Lou Gehrig's glove, Babe Ruth's bat, "a piece of wood taken from the pile that Cy Young chopped himself in early November 1954, several months before his 88th birthday and personally autographed by him, Nov. 8, '54." The fresh, bright pages here make the mustiest of objects look new. And BASEBALL'S GOLDEN AGE: The Photographs of Charles M. Conlon. By Neal McCabe and Constance McCabe. (198 pages. Harry N. Abrams; $29.95.) This gallery of marvelous photographs by a master serves as a vivid reminder that the likes of Honus Wagner and Ed Walsh were once youths. The caption of the most famous baseball photo ever made -- that of Ty Cobb sliding into the New York Giant third baseman Jimmy Austin -- reveals that Mr. Conlon, in his concern over whether Austin had been hurt by Cobb's flying spikes, was not even aware that he had snapped the picture.

nyt_corpus_1993.har/12/05/0654102.xml	        On a cool and cloudy April 18, 1923, 60,000 fans crowded into Yankee Stadium to witness the opening of a quantum leap in ball parks: a triple-deck Colosseum built for a mere $2.5 million. The concrete-and-steel gem had quirky outfield dimensions tailored for Babe Ruth; three grand entrances graced by carved eagle-and-baseball bat emblems; ornate ticket kiosks and an exquisite Gothic facade -- a copper tiara for the greatest of baseball cathedrals -- ringing the overhanging roof.

nyt_corpus_1994.har/01/30/0665444.xml	        Who was the second person to walk on the moon?: Edwin A. (Buzz) Aldrin Jr., after Neil A. Armstrong, on July 20, 1969. What was Orson Welles's second film?: "The Magnificent Ambersons" (1942) followed by "Citizen Kane" (1941). Who was Elizabeth Taylor's second husband?: Michael Wilding, who followed Conrad Hilton Jr. and preceded Michael Todd, Eddie Fisher, Richard Burton (twice), John W. Warner and Larry Fortensky. The same baseball player is No. 2 on the lists of lifetime home runs and home runs in a single season. Who is it?: Babe Ruth had 714 lifetime homers after Hank Aaron's 755. Ruth had 60 home runs in a single season, surpassed by Roger Maris's 61. What is the second-largest corporation in America?: Exxon is No. 2 on the Fortune 500 list, with $103.5 billion in sales in 1992, after General Motors' $132.7 billion. What is the second-oldest college in the United States?: The College of William and Mary was founded in 1693; Harvard dates to 1636. Which Wright brother was the second to fly?: Wilbur, following his brother Orville on Dec. 17, 1903. Who was the second Director General of the United Nations?: Dag Hammarskjold. The same baseball player is No. 2 on the lists of lifetime home runs and home runs in a single season. Who is it?: Babe Ruth had 714 lifetime homers after Hank Aaron's 755. Ruth had 60 home runs in a single season, surpassed by Roger Maris's 61. What is the second-largest corporation in America?: Exxon is No. 2 on the Fortune 500 list, with $103.5 billion in sales in 1992, after General Motors' $132.7 billion. What is the second-oldest college in the United States?: The College of William and Mary was founded in 1693; Harvard dates to 1636. Which Wright brother was the second to fly?: Wilbur, following his brother Orville on Dec. 17, 1903. Who was the second Director General of the United Nations?: Dag Hammarskjold. The Swede succeeded Trygve Lie of Norway in 1953. Intermediate

REGENTS VOTE TO ALTER AIDS GUIDE The New York State Board of Regents voted to revamp its guidelines on AIDS instruction to advise teachers that H.I.V. infection can be prevented in ways other than sexual abstinence, including condom use. VENDETTA ALLEGED IN CHIEF'S SUSPENSION The police chief of Harrison, N.Y., has been suspended without pay in what one town official called a political vendetta by the Town Supervisor. The charges against the chief, Albert Klein, 64, a 36-year veteran of the Harrison Police Department, were not made public, and Chief Klein refused to comment. Page 28. nyt_corpus_1994.har/04/09/0679298.xml	        Among the eliminated titles was this one: Fallout Shelter Contractors. Think about that. Fallout Shelter Contractors has been retired. nyt_corpus_1994.har/04/10/0679388.xml	        At the beginning of the 1904 baseball season, an amateur photographer wandered onto the playing field at the Polo Grounds and asked the star pitcher of the New York Giants to pose. Christy Mathewson obliged with a demonstration of his "body swing" -- now called a windup -- and Charles M. Conlon embarked on a 38-year career in which he virtually invented the iconography of the national pastime. Through 1942, Conlon (1868-1945) spent his summers carting his bulky Graflex camera (which until 1934 used glass negatives) to various ball parks to capture images of the players in action and in repose -- images so vivid and fresh that "ballplayers from another era are standing in the sunshine of the 20th century," as Neal McCabe and Constance McCabe write in BASEBALL'S GOLDEN AGE: The Photographs of Charles M. Conlon (Abrams, $29.95). Conlon remained an amateur photographer -- he was a proofreader at The New York Evening Telegram -- but his avocation made him "de facto the official photographer of baseball," one whose visions of the sport were seen annually for decades in Baseball magazine, the annual baseball guides, The Sporting News and baseball textbooks. Conlon once reminisced, "The fun I have had, the days in the open, the associations, the confidences I have enjoyed -- well, you can't buy those things." The 205 shots Constance McCabe, a photography conservator, has chosen from the 8,000 surviving Conlon negatives convey the eternally fresh wonder a spectator might feel at being in the open air alongside John McGraw squatting by third base, or watching Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig warm up on the sidelines. Thanks to excellent production, and a brilliant job of design by Carol Robson, great names from the recesses of baseball antiquity come vividly to life, from Honus Wagner, Napoleon Lajoie, Ty Cobb, Joe Tinker, Johnny Evers, Frank Chance and Walter Johnson to Grover Cleveland Alexander, Jimmie Foxx, Rogers Hornsby and Tris Speaker. Ms. McCabe's brother, Neal, brought his lifelong enthusiasm for baseball to his research on Conlon and his subjects; the text offers delightful nuggets of information about the innumerable firsts that Conlon recorded: the first American League umpire, the first batter in the World Series, the first photo on a baseball bubble-gum card. "Baseball's Golden Age" is equally enthralling in image and word and amply illustrates the timeless fascination of the field of dreams. MICHAEL ANDERSON  IN SHORT/BASEBALL: NONFICTION
nyt_corpus_1994.har/04/10/0679390.xml	        Paige earned his reputation -- on and off the field. Even though some contemporaries resented his share of headlines and the gate, they also knew that Paige's name and his brilliant pitching produced crowds, publicity, money and opportunities for black ballplayers. "You gotta understand," said Connie Johnson. "He was like a Babe Ruth for us, but he was our Babe Ruth. I think it's hard for people nowadays to understand how big he was. He was like the biggest guy we knew. It didn't make no difference what kinda stuff he did, 'cause that only made him more bigger than life. An' don't you believe that Satchel didn't know he was, too."

nyt_corpus_1994.har/06/05/0691865.xml	        History does repeat itself. Back in 1961 there was a question on everyone's lips: "Is the Mickey Mantle baseball more lively than the Babe Ruth baseball?" To settle the question back then, The Times asked the consulting firm of Foster D. Snell to make a physical evaluation of the two balls. Stephen Taub and I spent several days on the project. The results of our tests performed in Central Park were published on the front page on Aug. 16, 1961, with the data from the tests covered in full on page 19. The conclusion in the paper was "Baseball Hit by Ruth Not Unlike Those of '36 or Today." ROBERT W. BATEY  Rye Brook, N.Y.

nyt_corpus_1994.har/07/15/0699474.xml	        JIM ABBOTT will attend Jimmie Reese's memorial service today in Santa Ana, Calif., then fly back to Seattle for Friday night's game. Reese, who died Wednesday at age 92, had served as the California Angels' conditioning coach since 1972. He was a mentor and close friend of Babe Ruth's during his playing days in New York. Reese's 78-year career also influenced many others, including NOLAN RYAN, REGGIE JACKSON and Abbott. "I was very appreciative for his guidance," said Abbott. "Jimmie was a Yankee. nyt_corpus_1994.har/07/24/0701393.xml	        "The Catcher Was a Spy: The Mysterious Life of Moe Berg" is a delightful book that recounts one of the strangest episodes in the history of espionage. Nicholas Dawidoff, a contributor to Sports Illustrated, The New Republic and other magazines, has written a painstakingly researched yet compact biography of the bizarre catcher -- a major league ballplayer, Princeton graduate, amateur linguist, ladies' man, raconteur, professional freeloader, lawyer, quiz show contestant and spy. The book is a wild ride through history, combining characters like Heisenberg, Ted Williams, the O.S.S.'s Wild Bill Donovan, Babe Ruth, Albert Einstein, Julia Child, Nelson Rockefeller and Chico Marx. It's filled with brilliant scientists, lascivious outfielders and truculent geisha girls. As a biography it appears to lack only one element: a hero. But it has something better. It has Moe Berg.
nyt_corpus_1994.har/07/24/0701393.xml	        These would all be fatal flaws were Mr. Dawidoff not such a good writer. "The Catcher Was a Spy" is relentlessly entertaining, and Mr. Dawidoff's style is so unobtrusive that you forget he's there. One story almost justifies the cover price by itself. It involves Babe Ruth, a geisha house and Moe Berg's knowledge of the katakana, the Japanese phonetic alphabet. One must admire the author's honesty and work ethic. It would have been far easier, and perhaps more lucrative, to take the many Moe Berg legends at face value and spin a heroic tale of a brilliant athlete-scholar-spy.

nyt_corpus_1994.har/08/05/0704307.xml	        Aaron is 60 years old. He is freer now with that sudden sunny smile that cracks open the firm, wary nut of his strong, handsome face. He was, after all, only a country teen-ager when he first played pro ball, with the Indianapolis Clowns of the dying Negro League. His 23-year major league career began 40 years ago; he was in the second generation of African-American players, the settlers who had to plant and tend the ground the pioneers, like Jackie Robinson, broke. Twenty years ago, Aaron passed Babe Ruth's record of 714 career home runs, for which he seems never to have been forgiven.
nyt_corpus_1994.har/08/11/0705590.xml	        Many of his other stories have less to do with his thesis but are worthwhile reading anyway. Part of Roger Maris's motivation in chasing Babe Ruth's home-run record in 1961, successfully as it turned out, had been simply to spite the fans who were booing him for excelling Mr. Mantle. (Yankee management, incidentally, never saw fit to reward Maris for his accomplishment.) Johnny Sain, despite his great value as a pitching coach, antagonized managers because he tended to create "a separate team of pitchers whose loyalty was only to him," Mr. Halberstam writes. Among the new breed of sports reporter known as chipmunks was a writer who once asked a player about a telephone call that had interrupted an interview. When the reporter learned that the player's wife had been the caller and that she had been feeding their baby, he posed the un-locker-room-like question, "Breast or bottle?"
nyt_corpus_1994.har/08/12/0705754.xml	        Another new team, taking up residence in the 67-year-old ballpark where George Bush played first base for Yale, and Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Ted Williams appeared in exhibition games. A $3.5 million facelift, accomplished with private donations, has given the stadium new seats and lights, and a nice landscaped hill overlooking right field, where picknickers can enjoy the game. Tradition still rules. The crescent-shaped roof over the grandstand has not been tampered with. Fans will still see the 35-foot-high manual scoreboard, and the facelift has spared the special double seat built for William Howard Taft, whose 300-pound frame needed a little room to spread out. nyt_corpus_1994.har/08/12/0705784.xml	        The superstar, of course, was Babe Ruth, responding to criticism in 1922 over his salary of $52,000. It seems likely that the Yankee owner Jacob Ruppert or one of his sportswriter stooges had needled the Babe about making so much more than his fans. It was rarely pointed out then how many tickets the brewery owner sold because of the Babe or how his presence helped sell beer.
nyt_corpus_1994.har/08/14/0705998.xml	        Because of his participation in a prewar exhibition tour of Japan, the Japanese evidently thought that Berg -- a little-known player with a lackluster .243 lifetime batting average -- was a name to conjure with in baseball circles. Sometimes, though, they would switch to "To hell with Moe Berg!" -- leaving their American listeners in utter bewilderment.  LOUIS JAY HERMAN  New York
nyt_corpus_1994.har/08/14/0706042.xml	        Come next month, when gaveling resumes at the auction houses, the offbeat will star once again, both in specialty sales of penny-arcade machines and artist-designed helmets and in individual offerings like a 1957 tape of John Lennon at age 16 singing two songs and the shell-shaped chaise on which Mae West was frequently photographed. In other words, frenzied bidding may continue through the year, matching or surpassing some of the prices achieved since January. CROWD PLEASER Madonna was cheered in 1990 when she sang "Express Yourself" in Barcelona, Spain, laced up in a corset designed by Jean-Paul Gaultier. On stage again this past May at Christie's in London, the costume was applauded when it was auctioned for $18,150, a record for Madonna regalia and any corset. SIGHTED WITHOUT IT In June, after fierce bidding at the Las Vegas auction of Elvis Presley's 1973 American Express credit card, John Corbett of the "Northern Exposure" television series, was the winner. The card cost him $41,400, more than any other sold at auction and seven times the expectations of Butterfield & Butterfield, the auction house. SULTAN OF SWAT SCORES AGAIN The bat Babe Ruth used to hit his 56th home run in 1921 -- a record, briefly -- brought $63,000 in April, exceeding all prices paid at auction for a bat. ROYAL FLUSH Louis XV did not own the carpet emblazoned with the royal coat of arms of France that was auctioned at Christie's in London in June for $2 million. The rug, the costliest in the world, was probably ordered by a court aristocrat, whose name does not survive. There is no mystery about the new owner: Djanhanguir Riahi, a retired Iranian businessman who lives in France, is a passionate collector of 18th-century French furniture. The Savonnerie he bought is huge, more than 18 feet square -- ideal for the ballroom-size drawing room in his Paris mansion. NANTUCKET NEST Why did Harold Sack, a New York antiques dealer, pay a record $118,000 in January in New York for a set of six baskets woven in Nantucket, Mass., a century ago? "Takes two to tango at an auction -- and that's what happened," Mr. Sack says. FAR FROM THE TIGRIS Lost for a century, a 3,000-year-old architectural relief from the palace on the Tigris of the Assyrian King Ashurnasirpal II was found recently on a wall of a snack shop in a boy's school in Dorset, England. Last month, the carved stone slab, depicting a royal attendant, bow in hand, was auctioned at Christie's in London for $11.9 million, a record for any antiquity. NEWER IS BETTER Gold Leicas keep racking up auction records for cameras at Christie's in London: Last November, a 1901 Leica plated with 130 troy ounces of gold for Sultan Abdul Aziz of Morocco brought $58,717. In June, a gold-dipped Leica Luxus from 1931 sold for more: $59,717. EAT YOUR HEART OUT, BARBIE All decked out in a white dress with lace cuffs and a straw hat, a two-foot-tall German doll with a bisque head was auctioned in February at Sotheby's in London for $277,095, a record price for a doll. It was made in 1909 by Kammer & Reinhardt, in Germany. Its ears were pierced. But no earrings. NOT VAN GOGH'S IRISES . . .  The near-mint condition of the black and gold flowers painted on a red tin coffeepot of the early 19th century spurred the bidding to $36,800. The sum, a record for decorated toleware, was realized at a Christie's sale in June.

nyt_corpus_1994.har/09/12/0711723.xml	        Not that this makes his decade-by-decade history of 20th-century baseball any the less engaging. nyt_corpus_1994.har/09/12/0711723.xml	        And partly you enjoy seeing how the whole story is pieced together. A consequent policy to keep a cleaner, more tightly wound ball in play shifted the advantage from the pitcher to the hitter and helped clear the way for the Babe Ruth era.

nyt_corpus_1994.har/09/18/0712668.xml	        "Baseball" begins the first of its nine "innings" tonight at 8 on PBS. Parts 2 through 5 will be seen tomorrow through Thursday, followed by Nos. 6 through 9 next Sunday through Sept. 28. Spanning the sport's 250-year history -- and 18 1/2 hours of broadcast time -- the epic debunks the myth that Abner Doubleday created the game and profiles stars like Babe Ruth and Ty Cobb and executives like A. G. Spalding and Branch Rickey. Mr. Burns examines the infamous fixing of the 1919 World Series by the Chicago White Sox and tracks the Brooklyn Dodgers from their rise from ignominy to their 1955 World Series victory over the New York Yankees and their move to Los Angeles in 1958. He traces the labor movement that once found players treated like indentured servants. But the central focus is an illuminating narrative about the game's legacy of racism, with Jackie Robinson, of course, playing the principal, Lincolnesque role.

nyt_corpus_1994.har/10/16/0718217.xml	        As the wheel keeps turning, the celebrities who last -- and there are very few of them -- are not necessarily those whose achievements are the greatest. (I suspect Charles Lindbergh will barely be remembered several generations from now.) They are the ones who manage to embody something so timeless and transcendent that they are beyond fashion, beyond the loop, beyond celebrity. They are individuals whose images stubbornly refuse to yield to the new -- people like Fred Astaire and Babe Ruth and Ernest Hemingway. Their images freeze in our consciousness while the parade of lesser celebrity continues on its way to obscurity.

Ch. 4 "MAD AT YOU" -- Game Show :30 In the first installment of this prime-time game show, disgruntled victims of the salary cap in the National Football League bid on valuables from the home of union leader Gene Upshaw, whom they blame for pay cuts. Tonight's contestant: former New York Giant Phil Simms, who will seek $2.25 million of Upshaw's personal possessions to make up for his lost salary. HBO "DREAM ON" -- Comedy :30 Rabid baseball fan Martin Tupper's brain jumps without warning from the present-day strike to scenes from baseball movies depicting players playing. Tonight: Martin is hospitalized for post-traumatic stress syndrome when he cannot stop dreaming of William Bendix playing Babe Ruth. Tupper: Christopher Russo. Ch. 4 "UNSOLVED MYSTERIES" -- 1:00 "Mysteries of the Salary Cap" are explored in reports on the first cap on athletes in ancient Greece, featuring an interview with Phillipides, the first marathoner; a football player forced to retire because of the N.F.L. cap acquires psychic powers; kryptonite found inside baseballs made in Costa Rica.

nyt_corpus_1994.har/11/27/0727744.xml	        Although the story of Babe Ruth's impact on the national pastime has been told many times, Mr. Fox's account of the jump shot -- benefiting from the author's interviews with four of the men who invented the move independently in the late 1930's and 1940's -- is original and absorbing. Coaches distrusted the new shot at first. It looked too much like gimmickry, even cheating. But teammates and opponents of the pioneering jumpers were astonished and flabbergasted. As one who tried to defend against Glenn Roberts, an All-American at Emory and Henry College in Emory, Va., put it, "Who can guard a man who jumps like a rabbit from a brush pile and, flooey -- two points?"
nyt_corpus_1994.har/11/27/0727744.xml	        Mr. Fox clearly has fun telling good stories about his favorite sports. But there is more to the history of sports than is evident to a "boyish enthusiasm." Sports need not become less fun just because we think about them as well as enjoy them. For example, the author might have linked the surging popularity of professional baseball and football during the 1920's (as the sports went "airborne") with the explosion of consumer culture and sporting celebrity. The sports heroes of the decade -- Jack Dempsey, Bobby Jones, Big Bill Tilden, Red Grange and Babe Ruth -- became household words and graced household products because of the newly pervasive machinery of nationwide publicity and advertising.

nyt_corpus_1995.har/02/09/0742268.xml	        Newton Baker, then the Secretary of War, asked that the 1918 baseball season be curtailed. It ended on Labor Day, with the teams playing anywhere from 122 to 129 games instead of the scheduled 154 games. In the World Series, the Boston Red Sox, with a left-hander named Babe Ruth winning twice, defeated the Chicago Cubs, 4 games to 2. Two months later the war was over.

He is angry because he defeated Cuba's icon, Teofilio Stevenson, three times in four bouts over several years -- which was tantamount to Roger Maris having the nerve to break Babe Ruth's home run record. He is angry because he never had a chance to win an Olympic medal -- fighters he defeated in the 1983 and 1987 Pan American Games went on to win those, while Cuba boycotted the Games a year later. nyt_corpus_1995.har/03/29/0751670.xml	        When Yankee Stadium was about to undergo a major overhaul in the mid-1970's, Bert Sugar the collector turned up at the club's front office with a check. "It was for the right to poke through all the storerooms under the stands," he said. "I told them there'd be more if I decided to buy anything." Eventually, he carted away 17 truckloads of Yankee memorabilia, including the stadium seats and the Gehrig uniform. He also got the original stadium cornerstone, Babe Ruth's contracts, a statue of Miller Huggins and most of the papers of Jacob Ruppert, who had built the place. The seats he sold off; the rest is in his private collection.
nyt_corpus_1995.har/04/02/0752494.xml	        For some, it was the last good time. One of our most engaging baseball storytellers, Bob Costas, chokes up remembering himself in 1959, 7 years old, walking out to center field after a game, holding his father's hand. Mantle hadn't even played that day, but he is intrinsic to Costas's memory of his connection to his father, to the promise of his young life, to a seamless sports history that included the lovable Babe Ruth, the noble DiMaggio and the passionate Robinson, who starred in what was the century's greatest feel-good sports moment, despite its cynical undertones.
nyt_corpus_1995.har/04/02/0752494.xml	        No wonder Babe Ruth was hailed as the burly beau ideal of working-class American manhood, the happy hedonist for an America trying to dump its puritanism, justify the culture of abundance and shake a stick at the world. Beyond selling a "pastime" to the masses, Ruth also sold the Credo of the Home Run: A man can never be faulted, even if he's wrong, for the bold, aggressive action in pursuit of victory; a real man must be willing to strike out, to go down swinging. And as long he hit well enough for the fans and filled enough seats for the owners, his similarly high batting averages in food, drink, sex and antisocial behavior were casually posted in the boys-will-be-boys box score. It was part of the game.

nyt_corpus_1995.har/04/09/0754020.xml	        I must disagree with Dave Anderson that the shortened schedule is a major stain on baseball. It must be remembered that prior to the first expansion, each of the eight teams in the league played a 154-game schedule. How many home runs would Babe Ruth have hit in a season, or in a lifetime, if he had played the 162-game schedule now in effect? Would Hank Aaron ever have overtaken him? Would Ted Williams have hit over .400 if he had to play eight more games, or would he have raised his average?

One statistical tidbit: Ruth remains the only player in baseball history to pitch in at least 10 seasons and have a winning percentage above .500 every year he pitched. nyt_corpus_1995.har/04/23/0757453.xml	        New Jersey has only a fraction of the fishing resources of New York or Pennsylvania, and most of the state's 4,100 freshwater bodies are on private property. Nevertheless, recreational fishing is a multimillion dollar industry here, thanks to everyone from the teen-ager equipped with a rod from Kmart to the fly-fishing devotee lugging hundreds of dollars worth of gear from Orvis. And though few outside the state ever associate New Jersey with fishing, a handful of spots, mostly in the northwest, have acquired mythical status, including Big Flat Brook, a four-mile stream in Sussex County where Babe Ruth is said to have fly-fished.

nyt_corpus_1995.har/05/19/0763584.xml	        *What do a Venus flytrap screaming "Feed me, Seymour!" and a blue genie belting "You ain't never had a friend like me" have in common? Answer: Howard Ashman. Ashman, whose death in 1991 stilled one of the theater's wittiest voices, wrote the lyrics for the Off Broadway hit "Little Shop of Horrors" and the hugely successful Disney movies "Aladdin," "Beauty and the Beast" and "Little Mermaid." On Thursday, a revue of his work "Hundreds of Hats" opens at the WPA Theater. Some of the material has never been heard before: numbers from his unproduced Babe Ruth musical, from another called "Fatty at the Opera" and songs cut from "Little Shop" and "Aladdin."

Fellow columnists competed to proclaim Babe Ruth the  Sultan of Swat, Caliph of Clout, Potentate of the Pill, Behemoth of Bust, Mightiest of the Maulers and Big Boy Blooie.

nyt_corpus_1995.har/06/04/0767032.xml	        The police charged him with breaking into a car rented by Mark Lassman, a sports-memorabilia collector. nyt_corpus_1995.har/06/09/0767768.xml	        Although Mr. DiMaggio is strongly associated with his triumphs of the 1940's, Mr. Durso emphasizes that he was also a star in the 1930's. His rookie year was 1936, only one season after Babe Ruth retired. The Yankees were at spring training in St. Petersburg, Fla., and Ruth remarked: "He must first show something in the stadium. Only one out of a hundred looks good, and they all look like a million dollars under a palm tree." DiMaggio answered that skepticism with a rookie year in which he hit .323, with 29 home runs and 125 runs batted in. Fans familiar primarily with the DiMaggio of the 1940's may be surprised to realize he played alongside Lou Gehrig for three full seasons in the 1930's. The Yankees won the World Series each of those seasons, 1936, 1937 and 1938.

nyt_corpus_1995.har/06/11/0768174.xml	        It has always been easy to make a symbol of the Mick. He arrived all blond and sunny, heralded as the new Joe DiMaggio, if not the next Babe Ruth. His power, his energy, his youth reflected his country; all things were possible when you had infinite resources and the will to win.
nyt_corpus_1995.har/06/11/0768174.xml	        But fans and sportswriters considered that golden year a prelude, not a peak, and the pressure to do better increased. It was not until 1961, when it became clear that he would not be the next Babe Ruth, that Mantle began to feel the affection from the stands that he has enjoyed ever since, at card shows, at old-timers' games, at joke-a-stroke golf events, at his fantasy camp, in his Manhattan restaurant. The affection seemed to grow as his vulnerability, his humanity, overtook the myth. There were financial and family failures. One of his four sons was diagnosed with Hodgkin's disease as a teen-ager and died at 36 from a heart attack after years of substance abuse. Last year, after his detoxification at the Betty Ford Center, Mantle was again embraced by his fans.

City officials raced to capitalize on the sport's popularity, building or acquiring 12 other courses by the 1930's. Because of its easy accessibility, Van Cortlandt became the glamour destination for celebrity duffers. Babe Ruth, Joe Louis, Sidney Poitier and Willie Nelson have played there.

Mr. Aaron's story is glowingly told, with reflections by famous figures like Harry Belafonte and former President Jimmy Carter. Noticeably missing, though, is Mr. Aaron, a good speaker and forceful personality, whom Mr. Tollin chose not to interview. Dramatic re-creations are used in dozens of episodes that might have been better told through archival material or interviews with many of Mr. Aaron's colorful friends and family members. "A documentary that holds up re-creations as reality's peer loses credibility" (Richard Sandomir). Mixed Nuts  1994. Columbia Tri-Star. $98.31. Laser disk, $34.95. 97 minutes. Closed captioned.
