Nor was Bob Welch suspended when it was discovered that he had an alcohol problem. If drinking destroys or even compromises a player's performance, individual ball clubs may decide to get rid of the player, but if performance remains satisfactory, no punitive action is normally taken.

nyt_corpus_1995.har/07/16/0775175.xml	        A hard-drinking philanderer who handed out book advances the way Babe Ruth handed out autographed baseballs, Liveright squandered most of the rest of his firm's profits buying bathtub gin and backing Broadway shows. J. Perelman. In July 1928, six of the ten best-selling books in America were Boni & Liveright titles. Five years later, Horace Liveright died broke.

nyt_corpus_1995.har/08/18/0783179.xml	        There seems to be a tendency toward regarding male athletes as players who have amusing, even helpful idiosyncrasies (an encouraging wife, a three-bag habit, thinly repressed rage) while female athletes are daughters, lesbians, hysterics who happen to have interesting sports skills. This is getting very old; 50 years ago, educators advised "silly virgins" not to waste vital birthing fluids on running and jumping and Babe Ruth's Rabelaisian sins were regarded as intrinsic to his prodigious talents while Babe Didrikson's vaudevillian style was perceived as cover-up to the sexual confusion that spawned her prodigious talents.
nyt_corpus_1995.har/08/20/0783878.xml	        "I can't remember anything that happened before I had a baseball in my hand," Rogers Hornsby once said. The career of baseball's greatest right-handed hitter is well told by Charles C. Alexander, whose previous books include biographies of Ty Cobb and John McGraw and "Our Game: An American Baseball History." Hornsby batted .424 in 1924, the highest batting average of the 20th century, and as player-manager he led the St. Louis Cardinals to a World Series triumph over Babe Ruth and the Yankees in 1926. Off the field, as Mr. Alexander chronicles, Hornsby was an unrepentant gambler who made a habit of biting every hand that fed him, and there were many: he played for or coached seven major league teams and had stints in the minors and even in Mexico. His obsession with the game sabotaged his personal life; Hornsby married three times, and when his first son was killed in an airplane crash, the young man's mother requested that Hornsby not attend the funeral. Mr. Alexander does an excellent job of describing this loner, who habitually killed time on the road by sitting in hotel lobbies watching guests check in and out -- something to fill the void before the next game.  CAROLYN T. HUGHES

nyt_corpus_1995.har/11/01/0805881.xml	        If the plaque and the bust had remained Stadium property through the past decades, they would reside in Monument Park, beyond left center-field, where the historic statuary of Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Mantle and other team greats is installed.
nyt_corpus_1995.har/11/05/0806648.xml	        Commenting about his onetime teammate Babe Ruth, Harry Hooper said, "I saw a  man transformed into something close to a god." In IDOLS OF THE GAME: A Sporting History of the American Century (Turner, $23.95), Robert Lipsyte, a sports columnist for The New York Times, and Peter Levine, a professor of history at Michigan State University, try to pinpoint exactly how and why Ruth and 15 other outstanding athletes metamorphosed into cultural icons. Books about the lionization of sports figures are nothing new, but Mr. Lipsyte and Mr. Levine have constructed an interesting premise: they contend that their subjects are literally symbols of different periods in 20th-century America. Arnold Palmer, Vince Lombardi and Mickey Mantle represent not only excellence on the playing field but also "the promise of post-World War II America." Billie Jean King and  Muhammad Ali are not only great competitors but also are emblematic of "the turbulent 60's, a time in which sports as well as the larger culture confronted  the inequities of race, sex and class." Placing coaches and athletes on cultural time lines is a risky proposition at best -- as is arguing that the contribution of a certain select group reflects the myriad forces at work in society at a particular time. There is something about sports that defies rigid classification. But one does not have to agree totally with the authors to enjoy their book. The description of John L. Sullivan's 75-round bare-knuckle championship bout against Jake Kilrain -- in 115-degree heat, no less -- is worth the price of the book in itself.
nyt_corpus_1995.har/11/23/0810863.xml	        Mr. Rosen was born and raised on Manhattan's Lower East Side. His father was  the safety engineer at the Waldorf-Astoria and an amateur artist who sketched some of the hotel's famous guests in his spare time. Jack's, the restaurant in the Clarion Plaza, is named for the elder Mr. Rosen, and its walls are lined with his drawings of Winston Churchill, Pablo Picasso, Babe Ruth and many other  famous faces.
nyt_corpus_1995.har/11/27/0811882.xml	        And then there was Babe Ruth, the Sultan of Swat, who came out of poverty to become the epitome of excess, of insatiable appetites. In the 1930's, Joe Louis would give Americans a propaganda coup by coming back to defeat the German boxer Max Schmeling. Louis, a true icon for his people, would  end up being a host at a gambling casino. Muhammad Ali, who was stripped of the  heavyweight title because he refused to fight in Vietnam, is recalled as "our last sports idol of any political significance."

nyt_corpus_1996.har/04/07/0842012.xml	        Equally excessive was the adulation that engulfed Mantle during his final eight seasons, when his failures were ennobled: for coming in second to Roger Maris in the 1961 home run derby, for his magnificent performance in the loss to the St. Louis Cardinals in the 1964 World Series (in which he broke Babe Ruth's record for World Series homers with a suitably mythic called shot), for simply continuing to put his crippled body on the diamond game after game. nyt_corpus_1996.har/06/14/0857579.xml	        REMEMBER Father Guido Sarducci's classic "Saturday Night Live" routine, the "Five-Minute University"? The one in which he rushed through the highlights of every subject at breakneck speed? That's what visiting "America's Smithsonian,"  the vast exhibition that opened this week at the New York Coliseum, feels like.  History? Here's Abe Lincoln's hat. Sports? Step right up and see Arthur Ashe's tennis racquet and a baseball signed by Babe Ruth. Culture? Yes, it must be, because there's a Henry Moore, and an Edward Hopper, and hey, that's an Andy Warhol over there. But keep moving, because now you're at Natural History, and you don't want to miss those dinosaur bones or the fossils preserved in amber. Ancient artifacts? Nice Cycladic figure over in that case, circa 2500 B.C. Want  some reminders of American ingenuity? Have a look at Samuel F. B. Morse's telegraph key, the Jarvik-7 heart and Alan B. Shepard's Freedom 7 space capsule. Like literature? Then you'll be sure to love the portraits of Mark Twain and F.  Scott Fitzgerald. Music? Dizzy Gillespie's trumpet, thank you.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/06/22/0859338.xml	        In the instance of "America's Smithsonian" the dumbing down is applied not only to history (why do Cesar Chavez, Booker T. Washington and the Marquis de Lafayette arbitrarily converge in one cul-de-sac?) but to cultural anthropology  (why is a Mayan artifact cheek-by-jowl with Mary Todd Lincoln's silver tea service?) and art (what's the link between Picasso and Richard Estes?). Chronology is often scrambled, and so are distinctions between real history and  kitsch; Lincoln's top hat is hidden behind an antique-looking carousel that turns out to be a reproduction. The sports and show-business collectibles, whether a baseball autographed by Babe Ruth or Indiana Jones's jacket, are presented with less historical context than can be found in the displays at a theme restaurant like Planet Hollywood.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/06/26/0860342.xml	        So we have articles on the two world wars and Vietnam, but not on the two Kennedy assassinations and Watergate. nyt_corpus_1996.har/06/26/0860324.xml	        Baseball stars present include Goose Goslin, Junior Gilliam and Phil Rizzuto, while Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig are absent. Likewise, the moon landing is represented not by the familiar picture of Neil Armstrong in his bubble suit but by a haunting shot of his footprint in the lunar dust; the 1970 Kent State killings are conveyed not by that well-known image of a teen-ager weeping over a slain student, but by a picture of a different young woman bending over the body, at a reverse angle that makes the scene appear freshly disturbing.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/21/0866183.xml	        The largest one-year contract in the history of team sports may seem excessive, but not since Babe Ruth sold baseball and the joys of consumer appetite as a globe-traveling ambassador of Yankee power (true, the chant soon became "Yankee, go home!") has a single athlete so dominated his sport and embodied his time. nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/21/0866193.xml	        As President Clinton continues his contract negotiations with the American public, it's clear he's far more interested in job security than in landing any  kind of raise, even a cost-of-living adjustment. That's just as well, given how salaries of elected officials have lost ground to those of sports stars over the years. In 1930, as Babe Ruth was trying to negotiate an $80,000 contract, reporters asked him if he wasn't embarrassed to be seeking more than the $75,000 that President Hoover earned. "I had a better year," the Babe answered. Well, Shaquille O'Neal just signed a $17 million-a-year contract with the Los Angeles  Lakers, meaning he'll make every five days what Mr. Clinton makes annually. But  did he have a better year?

nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/26/0867265.xml	        How many generations of Bronx youth have felt such kinship is impossible to say. The Yankees and their ball park, nestled between the Deegan and the Grand Concourse, have cast tall shadows across this borough since Babe Ruth celebrated its opening on April 18, 1923, by hitting the inaugural home run in what came to be known as his house.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/28/0867939.xml	        The Yankees placed second baseman PAT KELLY on the 15-day disabled list. Kelly, who just returned from rehabilitation last week, experienced what appeared to be a leg cramp Friday night. It turned out to be a strained right hamstring. To replace Kelly, the Yankees have called up MATT HOWARD, who will arrive today. "At this point, I'd much rather play it safe than rush him onto the roster," said Manager JOE TORRE, who can be cautious because MARIANO DUNCAN  is playing so well at second. . . . When the Yankees batted around in the third inning, it was the second time in three games they had done so, and the 18th time this season. . . . The Yankees will add a fourth memorial to Yankee Stadium's Monument Park in honor of Mickey Mantle, the team announced during the Old-Timers Day ceremony yesterday. Mantle's monument will be alongside those of  Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Miller Huggins and will be unveiled on Aug. 25. . . .  He still has it. In familiar form, REGGIE JACKSON hit a home run into the right-field seats off pitcher PEDRO RAMOS during the old-timers game.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/28/0868000.xml	        LUMPY and soiled, its hemp stitching tight in some places and loose in others, it looks like any old baseball: no way to tell immediately that it has a connection to the original field of dreams. But after closely studying the faded script and seeing the scrawled signature of Babe Ruth, the viewer senses a glow around the ball. Smaller than a regulation-size ball, the old orb inspires awe. "He could've blown the cover off this one," said Joseph M. Accetta, a lawyer on  the staff of Westchester County Surrogate Court Judge Albert Emanuelli, who is hearing a lawsuit involving the 1938 baseball. "He was one of the top five players who ever played the game. He hit 60 home runs with a dead ball," said Mr. Accetta, who is responsible for the ball's safekeeping. For Mr. Accetta, a baseball fan whose office is hung with framed mementos of baseball's greats, the lawsuit is a joy. He rattles off statistics and anecdotes without pause. For example, he cited the 1932 World Series game between the Yankees and the Chicago Cubs when Ruth, the Sultan of Swat, with two strikes against him, pointed to center field with his bat and proceeded to place the ball there. "He had great agility for a guy his size, tremendous power; he was a great athlete," said Mr. Accetta, a 30-year-old with a reverential attitude toward baseball history. He acquired his love of the game's past growing up in Queens,  where he listened to older men talk about baseball in New York during the 1940's and '50's. "I had expected a shiny white ball with the Babe's signature on it," said Mr. Accetta, who retrieved the baseball from a safe in the judge's chambers. "At first, it's a letdown when you see it. It's not in terrific shape. The cover is split in two places." Mr. Accetta, who coaches Little League and plays in two softball leagues, added, "It was even played with." But the baseball in question was not played with by Ruth. Boys of long ago played with it at least once, Mr. Accetta said. The autographed baseball is most likely a novelty item of the kind sold in gift  shops and candy stores for play by youngsters, said Greg Schwalenberg, curator of the Babe Ruth Birthplace and Museum in Baltimore. "Today's ball is the same dimension and weight as back then." Even though Ruth played in what is known as the "dead-ball era," evidence to support that contention is hard to come by, Mr. Schwalenberg said. A baseball, which is still hand-stitched, is a cushioned cork center with a leather cover held together with 108 stitches and is 3 inches in diameter, 9 to 9 1/4 inches in circumference and 5 to 5 1/4 ounces in weight. "Later, the ball became livelier, apparently it had more of a pop to it; it may  be that they were wound tighter inside," Mr. Schwalenberg said. Paul Ventry, a doctor in Potomac, Md., was a 10-year-old in 1938 when he stopped with his father, Victor, at the Peekskill train station. Standing there waiting for a train was Babe Ruth. Young Paul ran to a nearby store and bought a baseball. He got back in time to get the Babe's autograph. For the next half-century or so, the ball sat in a breakfront in the Ventry's Peekskill living room. According to court documents, Dr. Ventry claims that the baseball was a gift to him from his father, who died in 1973. At that time,  Dr. Ventry took the ball to his home. After their mother, Catherine R., died in  1992, his sister, Catherine V., claimed the baseball was family property and ought to be sold. A legal wrangle has ensued. "I delivered the baseball," said Joseph A. Scutieri, a lawyer for Dr. Ventry, referring to handing it over to Mr. Accetta. When asked whether he felt it in the palm of his hand, Mr. Scutieri said, "No, I didn't even do that." But like Mr. Accetta, Mr. Scutieri's work is more fun these days. "This case combines two things that I love, sports and my job," Mr. Scutieri said. "I'd love to make a living playing baseball. That's what I do in my free time, and here I get paid to argue what a Babe Ruth baseball is worth." This particular ball may not be worth very much, however. "It's a little dirty and worn," Mr. Scutieri said. "It's not in the shape the collectors want it to be, mint condition, whether it's baseball cards or baseballs. They don't want you touching anything or handling it. They want it in plastic wrap." For comparison, Mr. Scutieri offered information on a 1927 baseball, a memento from the same year Babe Ruth hit 60 home runs. "There's a 1927 baseball signed by the Yankee team, Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, the best team ever," Mr. Scutieri said. "That one is worth $14,000." He added, "The numbers on this ball are as high as $10,000, but it's not in very good shape." Despite the baseball's "priceless sentimental value," as stated in court papers, Dr. Ventry claims the baseball is worth about $100. Born George Herman Ruth in 1895, the Baltimore native played from 1920 to 1934 for the Yankees, in the House That Ruth Built, otherwise known as Yankee Stadium. In 1935, he played for the Boston Braves, retiring after one season. In 1938, the year the baseball was signed, he coached at first base for the Brooklyn Dodgers from June 19 to the end of the season. He hoped to be hired as  manager of the team, but Leo Durocher got the job. It was the last time the Babe wore a baseball uniform. Before his death in 1948, from throat cancer at 53, he  played golf tournaments and went on fishing and hunting trips. "The exact reason he was in Peekskill is not known," Mr. Schwalenberg said. Both lawyers say that the baseball became a focal point after a dispute arose between the brother and sister -- who is a lawyer in the town of New Windsor in  Orange County -- over the mother's insurance policies. A third sibling, Barbara  Ventry Magee, is not named in the dispute. Last summer Judge Emanuelli ruled that the baseball was part of the Ventry estate. But Mr. Scutieri persuaded the judge to reopen the case after he proved  that his client was improperly served with the original court documents and did  not have enough time to reply. Judge Emanuelli is expected to rule on the motion soon. For Mr. Accetta, the day the baseball leaves his care could be a sad one. "At some point, it has to go," he said.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/28/0868118.xml	        But after closely studying the faded script and seeing the scrawled signature of Babe Ruth, the viewer senses a glow around the ball. Smaller than a regulation-size ball, the old orb inspires awe.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/28/0868118.xml	        The autographed baseball is most likely a novelty item of the kind sold in gift shops and candy stores for play by youngsters, said Greg Schwalenberg, curator of the Babe Ruth Birthplace and Museum in Baltimore. ''Today's ball is the same dimension and weight as back then.''
nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/28/0868118.xml	        Standing there waiting for a train was Babe Ruth. Young Paul ran to a nearby store and bought a baseball. He got back in time to get the Babe's autograph.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/28/0868118.xml	        But like Mr. Accetta, Mr. Scutieri's work is more fun these days. ''This case combines two things that I love, sports and my job,'' Mr. Scutieri said. ''I'd love to make a living playing baseball. That's what I do in my free time, and here I get paid to argue what a Babe Ruth baseball is worth.''
nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/28/0868118.xml	        For comparison, Mr. Scutieri offered information on a 1927 baseball, a memento from the same year Babe Ruth hit 60 home runs.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/07/28/0868118.xml	        ''There's a 1927 baseball signed by the Yankee team, Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, the best team ever,'' Mr. Scutieri said. ''That one is worth $14,000.''

To the Giants, though, it is all relative. And what may seem to many to be such a small issue today produced one of the more bizarre chapters in the Dan Reeves regime.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/08/19/0872354.xml	        He homered in his first Little  League at-bat  a tape-measure job of 175 feet -- and no ball park has held him since. Mark McGwire has everything Babe Ruth had, except 60 home runs, and Babe Ruth had everything Mark McGwire has, except a goatee, a Gold's Gym membership and a son. Both were former pitchers, both would never turn down a T-bone steak and both have swung desperately for the moon.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/08/19/0872354.xml	        It has been an incongruous nine-year wait. He has been a phenom, an invalid and trade bait all at once, but the main problem is his odd pair of narrow feet. McGwire is all toes. They are absurdly long and angular, while his arches are far too small to support his 6-foot-5-inch, 250-pound body. The result has been plantar fascia -- known mostly as a basketball injury -- and it slowed him to the relative speed of that man again, Babe Ruth.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/08/23/0872933.xml	        Speaking of sports, August of 1927 was the coldest in New York history, with an average of 68.5 degrees, 7 below normal, and a high of only 83, on Aug. 1. That year, Babe Ruth hit 60 home runs, but only 9 in August and only 2 in Yankee Stadium. Cause and effect, or mere coincidence? The Babe, after all, was a man who never met a party he didn't like.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/09/08/0876182.xml	        Of the 15 players who have hit 500 home runs, he is the only one to never hit 35 in a season or be the league leader. The others also led the league in seasons ranging from 1 (Frank Robinson) to 12 (Ruth), averaging 4.6 times.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/09/15/0877228.xml	        ''This type of unsigned photograph simply was not available in any quantity until now,'' said Donald J. Flanagan, a consultant to Christie's in New York on sports memorabilia. When such pictures of star players like Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Mickey Mantle have appeared in shops and auctions, he said, they have  usually sold for no more than $300 each. The prices are modest, probably because most of these photographs depict players out of uniform, often in studios.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/09/15/0877228.xml	        ''But now, unsigned action photographs and those of uniformed players may begin to catch on with collectors,'' Mr. Flanagan said. For the first time, a huge number of original prints of some of baseball's most famous early photographs are to be auctioned: Ty Cobb, his teeth clenched, sliding into third base in a cloud of dust; a tightly cropped shot of Babe Ruth's bulldog face; a portrait of the stolid Honus Wagner. The photographs are among 17,000 that were discovered last year in the basement of a Washington apartment building.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/09/15/0877228.xml	        IT WAS CONLON WHO CAPTURED COBB IN THE famous 1909 image and Babe Ruth in the cropped shot from 1927, one of many of his images of the Sultan of Swat. Conlon's other distinctive studies focus on ballplayers' grips on bats and on balls, including the hand of Mordecai (Three Finger) Brown, which he photographed in 1914.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/09/16/0877703.xml	        And should the Red Sox somehow deliver a knockout blow to New York, beating them enough times in those eight games to push the Yankees clear out of the playoffs, New England will rejoice in revenge for all the slights dating back to the snatching away of Babe Ruth. nyt_corpus_1996.har/09/17/0877829.xml	        It is pointless to wish for a return to a simpler time. For one thing, such nostalgia conveniently overlooks the fact that with a few exceptions like Babe Ruth, the great players of earlier eras were grossly underpaid by miserly owners who ran professional baseball like a plantation. Many of today's owners wish they still could. The charming verities of baseball, from its arcane rules to its sunny heroes, were never the whole story about a game that has long been a big business.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/09/18/0877976.xml	        For 50 years, Barry Halper has built a baseball memorabilia empire so vast that his 984 historic uniforms move on dry cleaning racks for viewing in his New Jersey house. nyt_corpus_1996.har/09/29/0880395.xml	        My son and I listen to the Red Sox on radio from Hartford, make an annual trek to friendly Fenway Park and attend several games in the Bronx despite the fan abuse. My son may be doomed to a lifetime of heartache (even though every Red Sox fan knows the so-called curse of Babe Ruth from 1918 is irrelevant today), but he will do so in concert with his dad, knowing that he is a better person for the experience. When the Red Sox do win the World Series, he and I will savor together the ultimate triumph.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/03/0880984.xml	        While the Cowboys have made the playoffs in 24 of their 36 years in the National Football League, capturing five Super Bowls and feeding Dallas's seemingly intense need to present itself as a city of big-league winners, the Rangers' 25-year history had been one of failure, disappointment and gallows humor. nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/06/0881378.xml	        Now: Who's the greatest baseball player of all time? The answer, of course, is Babe Ruth. And always will be. Other sports are allowed to grow, evolve, mutate. But baseball is locked into a mythology that its greatest era was in the past, when only white guys played and all the teams were gathered in a handful of Northern industrial cities.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/06/0881378.xml	        Baltimore's Brady Anderson was headed for a record home-run total for leadoff hitters until it occurred to the Orioles that his homers would produce more runs if he batted second. Seattle's Edgar Martinez was headed for an all-time record for doubles before an injury sidelined him for three weeks. (He still hit more than 50.) Cleveland's Albert Belle was on pace to hit 50 home runs for the second consecutive season. Only one other hitter has ever done that: Babe Ruth. If the strike hadn't cut a third of Belle's season away in 1994, Belle would probably have threatened a third consecutive 50-home-run season.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/06/0881378.xml	        Critics of the 90's game are quick to decry these phenomenal numbers: the ball is ''juiced,'' the bats are corked, the new parks favor the hitters, expansion has watered down the talent, pitching has become a lost art. Commissioner Ford Frick wanted to put an asterisk next to Roger Maris's name in the record book if he didn't break Babe Ruth's record of 60 home runs within the old 154-game limit; many of today's baseball experts seem to want to put an asterisk on the entire 1996 season.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/06/0881378.xml	        It's true that almost all the ballparks built in the last few years, particularly Baltimore's Camden Yards, Cleveland's Jacobs Field and Denver's high-altitude Coors Field, favor hitters. But this trend is simply a return to the 20's and 30's, when nearly all parks were built or altered to favor hitting. The surviving specimens -- Detroit's Tiger Stadium, Boston's Fenway Park and Chicago's Wrigley Field -- remain three of the best hitters' parks in the game. Babe Ruth, Jimmy Foxx, Rogers Hornsby and Lou Gehrig were great hitters, but they had help.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/06/0881378.xml	        The current number of major league teams, 28, hasn't even kept up with the population increase since the Babe Ruth era, when there were 16 clubs. When you realize there were no black or Hispanic players in Ruth's time, and throw in the tremendous lure of sports megasalaries, you have to wonder if today's baseball talent pool isn't far deeper than the one that produced Ruth. (And the argument that basketball and football have siphoned off significant numbers of great athletes is nonsense. As the baseball careers of Bo Jackson and Michael Jordan illustrate, athletes with body types best suited to football and basketball rarely make very good baseball players.)
nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/06/0881378.xml	        What the modern game hasn't produced is a handful of players who tower above the others in a few statistical areas: Babe Ruth's home-run totals, Ty Cobb's .367 lifetime batting average, Cy Young's 511 career victories. But it has produced more good, all-around players at every position than in any other era. The game may never have seen a better hitting catcher than Piazza. Completing his fourth full season, Piazza has a career batting average of nearly .325 and is producing runs at a greater rate than Mickey Cochrane, Yogi Berra, Johnny Bench or any other catcher who ever played the game. And Piazza is just one of several great players at a position that has traditionally been baseball's most barren, including Hundley, Rodriguez, Oakland's Terry Steinbach, Boston's Mike Stanley, Philadelphia's Benito Santiago and Cleveland's Sandy Alomar Jr.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/07/0881944.xml	        With all due respect to Messier, Gretzky has been a defining and transitional figure in his sport much the way Babe Ruth was in baseball and the triumvirate of Larry Bird, Magic Johnson and Michael Jordan was in basketball, raising the level of skill and fan awareness. Gretzky had McEnroe touch and Ashe diplomacy. And he still does.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/18/0884122.xml	        The first Yankee World Series was the first to be played entirely in one ball park, the Polo Grounds, owned by the Giants and rented by the Yankees, who won the first two games by 3-0 scores. Naturally, the first Series homer by a Yankee came from Babe Ruth, in Game 4. Overlooked, though, was that with a 3-2 lead in the five-of-nine-game format, the Yankees lost Ruth after Game 5 because of an arm infection and a bad knee, and then lost the next three games as well.
nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/18/0884122.xml	        Babe Ruth's feeble bat (2 for 17 with nary a homer) made this second straight all-Polo Grounds Series notable. Painful for Yankee fans, was the bottle bat of Heinie Groh of the Giants, who outhit the Babe, .474 to .118.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/10/18/0884122.xml	        In Babe Ruth's final Series, he made his biggest splash with the ''called home run'' in Chicago in Game 3. He too hit two home runs in the game, the second coming immediately after Ruth's controversial one. And Gehrig wound up outperforming Ruth with 9 hits, 3 homers, 8 runs batted in and a .529 average.

nyt_corpus_1996.har/12/09/0894502.xml	        WHEN WILLARD MET BABE RUTH.  By Donald Hall. Illustrated by Barry Moser. (Browndeer Press/Harcourt Brace & Company; $16.) On a summer day in 1917, Willard's dad pulls a red roadster out of a ditch. The strapping young driver turns out to be the best pitcher in baseball, the Boston Red Sox's Babe Ruth, who says, ''Sorry I was going so damned -- darned -- fast,'' and gives young Willard a baseball glove. Eighteen years later, on opening day of the Babe's last year in baseball, Willard meets him again, in the locker room of the Boston Braves, and introduces him to his 10-year-old daughter, Ruth. With the help of Barry Moser's sun-washed watercolors, the poet Donald Hall evokes the long-ago time when baseball was a constant hum in our daily lives, connecting one generation to the next.

nyt_corpus_1997.har/02/09/0907489.xml	        Joe Franklin, the 70-year-old New York institution who ended his television talk show in 1993 after a record 43-year run, returns tonight in ''50,000,000 Joe Franklin Fans Can't Be Wrong,'' a documentary on WNET. Franklin, as fans know, staged one the most compellingly bad TV programs in history. The documentary chronicles visits from stars like Bing Crosby but, more typically, Mrs. Babe Ruth and the Sparks, an a cappella group that sang''I Like You Very Much.'' Franklin had been on the air almost 20 years before Joshua Brown, the director, was born. Brown doesn't deny Franklin's camp appeal, but he hopes to convey his ''benevolent'' side as well. ''There's something touching,'' he says, ''in the way he's always trying to champion new talents, regardless of their actual abilities.''

He is billed by the gallery as a follower of Joseph Cornell, but Cornell was never as rambunctiously playful as Mr. Burke is. His ''Hercules in Pinstripes,'' which includes several baseballs that viewers can send through a maze, is a tribute to Babe Ruth, and Sousa can almost be heard in ''Old Glory -- New Promise''; here viewers may participate by unrolling a weathered flag.

nyt_corpus_1997.har/10/19/0966065.xml	        Gallagher's brazenly claims to be not only New York's first steakhouse but also the first in the entire country. It was founded during Prohibition as a speak-easy in 1927, by a retired Ziegfeld Follies girl named Helen Gallagher and her husband, Jack Solomon, a bookie. Quickly Gallagher's became one of the favored ''drops'' for the boxers, horse owners, horse players, chorus girls, ballplayers, politicians, mobsters, actors and sundry other flamboyant types whose old photographs still cover the walls. Over the years at Gallagher's you could see Babe Ruth or Marilyn Monroe, Fred Astaire or Max Baer. These days, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir have been known to come by, as have Jackie Mason, the celebrity divorce lawyer Raoul Felder, the Harlem numbers king ''Spanish'' Raymond Marquez and whoever is enjoying a long run at the Broadway theaters just down the street. In other words, it's still full of Sid Zion's kind of people.

During the 1951 season, she hurried to an autograph signing and gave Gil Hodges, then in a batting slump, the St. Christopher medal that she'd won in Confirmation class; the saint, she hoped, ''would watch over his swing so that he could return home safely each time he went to bat.'' Hodges's comeback began immediately, and a month later he had hit 17 home runs in 44 games, ''three ahead of Babe Ruth's mark.'' In the summer of what turned out, at last, to be the triumphant season of 1955, Doris finally made contact with her by now aging hero and came away with an autograph she would never trade: ''Keep your smile a long, long while. Jackie Robinson.''

nyt_corpus_1998.har/05/17/1017841.xml	        Coming into this weekend's series against the Minnesota Twins, the Yankees had won 26 games and lost only 8. It was the second-best record after 34 games in franchise history. The only Yankee team with a faster start over the same span was the vintage 1928 squad, which went 27-7. That team had Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig and went on to win the World Series in a four-game sweep over the St. Louis Cardinals.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/05/17/1017841.xml	        In sports, there are teams and individuals and events that capture the collective imagination and live in history like great works of art. Bobby Thomson hitting his home run against the Dodgers. Babe Ruth hitting 60. Joe Louis knocking people out. Brooklyn's Boys of Summer. Lombardi's Green Bay Packers.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/05/18/1018045.xml	        On a squad with few flamboyant players, Wells cuts a distinctive figure with his affinity for good times and keen sense of Yankee history. Instead of posting large ''K's'' on the stadium facade to mark every strikeout recorded by Wells, a group of his fans displays pictures of beer mugs. No one in the front office was offended yesterday.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/05/18/1018074.xml	        Wells has always admired Babe Ruth, who did not go to Point Loma High but did set a standard for pitching, hitting and carousing.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/05/20/1018490.xml	        Your list of Major League Baseball's perfect games (Sports pages, May 18) omits the most remarkable one of all. Babe Ruth, starting pitcher for the Boston Red Sox in a 1917 game, walked the first batter and was ejected from the game for arguing the ball-four call. Ernie Shore relieved Ruth. The runner was picked off first. Shore retired 26 consecutive batters.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/05/20/1018524.xml	        Eric Davis met Wells when both played in Detroit. ''He's good people,'' Davis said. ''He enjoys the game, he loves having fun and he's a people person.'' Davis said that the beauty of Sunday's performance was that Wells -- so often focused on because of the brawls, the bars, the weight, the Boss's criticism -- brought the focus back to baseball. Fans were reminded that instead of just the character who wore Babe Ruth's hat, David Wells is, above all, one heck of a pitcher.

nyt_corpus_1998.har/05/31/1021141.xml	        Today collectors seem motivated more by love, often tinged with nostalgia, than by thoughts of making a killing. Still, Dr. Manevitz worries that people, including some of his patients, become too obsessed. ''You shouldn't define yourself through your things,'' he said, sounding almost convincing.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/06/04/1022093.xml	        Straddling the mound, Hernandez wore his baseball pants in a style straight from the days of Babe Ruth, drawn up just below his knees, leaving his dark blue socks exposed. Wearing No. 26, Hernandez pitched in the manner of another Cuban-born pitcher, Luis Tiant, the former Indians, Red Sox and Yankee right-hander; like Tiant, Hernandez threw pitches at many speeds, from many angles. Sometimes he attacked with a three-quarter motion, sometimes he dropped his shoulder and threw sidearm.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/06/07/1022886.xml	        In the final column, which he wrote on Wednesday, Mr. Povich questioned, among other things, whether Mark McGwire, the hulking, slugging first baseman for the St. Louis Cardinals who has hit 414 career home runs, is a greater home run hitter than Babe Ruth. That seems a growing sentiment, but it was not a popular one with Mr. Povich, who covered Ruth and his exploits. ''To judge McGwire a better home run hitter than Ruth at a moment when McGwire is exactly 300 home runs short of the Babe's career output is, well, a stretch,'' he wrote.

nyt_corpus_1998.har/06/14/1024297.xml	        A: I hope I'd have the good sense to pull back. I remember Vin Scully calling the game when Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruth's career home run record, and he was very specific about the direction the ball was hit, who chased after it and where it cleared the wall. Then Vinny didn't say another word for two or three minutes. All you heard was the crowd. That was brilliant. That said it all.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/06/16/1025037.xml	        Jerry West, a Hall of Fame player for the Lakers in those Celtics years and the Lakers' general manager in the Bulls' era, agrees to some extent. ''Each team, for example, had one dominating player -- Russell for the Celtics, Jordan for the Bulls -- plus superb role players around them. But there is an X factor. That is Michael Jordan. He's an incredible player, the greatest player I've ever seen. He's the best offensive player I've ever seen,  and his defense is second to none. He's the modern-day Babe Ruth.''

The game we know and love is changing before our eyes. It is contrived, scripted. This is what Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has in mind for Yankee Stadium when the team moves to Rudyland near Times Square. On Monday the Mayor was in Baltimore, raving about Camden Yards. nyt_corpus_1998.har/06/30/1028499.xml	        That year, in the month after Don Larsen pitched a perfect game in the World Series, the pitcher (salary: $12,000) earned $22,000 from television and other appearances arranged by Scott. nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/01/1028738.xml	        McGwire may be able to blast the ball deeper and more often than any of his competitors, making him the odds-on favorite to catch Maris. What McGwire didn't want to catch was the debilitating waves of attention, the sort that caused Maris anything but joy in 1961, when that Yankee great eclipsed Babe Ruth's record of 60.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/05/1029439.xml	        McGwire's swing is designed to produce home runs (and strikeouts). Anything else -- doubles, singles, the occasional ground ball -- is an accident. And sometime this September, barring injury, he'll probably break the most recognizable record in American sports: Roger Maris's 61 home runs in a season, which in 1961 supplanted the previous most recognizable record, Babe Ruth's 60 home runs in a season. (Ruth's record lasted 34 years; Maris's has now lasted 37.)
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/05/1029439.xml	        All great sluggers have their own distinctive swings. Babe Ruth began with a graceful stride toward the ball followed by a whiplash of wrists and forearms that left him twisted like a pretzel when he missed. Stan Musial started from a low crouch and uncurled a fluid stroke that still has hitting coaches going back to old films. Mickey Mantle exploded in a violent wrench of his torso, wrists and arms, resulting in a follow-through so powerful that the bat would often slam into his back after a miss.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/05/1029439.xml	        * McGwire and Babe Ruth are the only players to have back-to-back seasons with 50 or more home runs. This August, in all likelihood, McGwire will become only the second player (after Ruth) to have more than two 50-plus home-run seasons. If he had not cut short his rookie season to see his son born, McGwire almost certainly would have surpassed his total of 49 home runs and would now be ready to become the second player (after Ruth) with four seasons of 50 or more home runs.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/05/1029439.xml	        * This season, McGwire's slugging percentage -- total bases collected on hits divided by at-bats -- has hovered around .800. The highest mark in history is Babe Ruth's .847 in 1920. Lou Gehrig's best was .765 in 1927; Ted Williams managed .735 in 1941.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/06/1029871.xml	        *If George Steinbrenner ever moves the New York Yankees from Yankee Stadium, could disgruntled fans insist that the Lipton Brisk tea commercial set there, which features him along with Babe Ruth, Reggie Jackson, Mickey Mantle and Billy Martin, be re-edited to show the rest of them clobbering him with their bats?
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/07/1030121.xml	        And almost every day now, McGwire sees himself linked to Babe Ruth, who hit 60 homers in 1927, and Maris.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/07/1030121.xml	        ''Considering that when I was a kid and all I wanted to do was pitch, it wasn't until my sophomore year in college that I turned into a hitter, never knowing if I'd get a chance to go to the big leagues,'' he said, alluding to the University of Southern California. ''The next thing you now, they're talking about my name along with Babe Ruth, Roger Maris, Mickey Mantle. It's overwhelming.''

nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/08/1030285.xml	        Editorial--commenting on assault on Rogers Maris's single-season home run record by Mark McGwire (St Louis Cardinals), Sammy Sosa (Chicago Cubs) and Ken Griffey Jr (Seattle Mariners)--says time may be right for new mark, noting Babe Ruth's record stood for 34 years and that more time than that has elapsed since Maris exceeded it with 61 home runs in 1961 (M)
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/08/1030285.xml	        In an era of computerized record keeping, when it is possible to determine which left-handed hitter in history knocked in the most winning runs in the bottom of the ninth inning, the home run title is the gold standard for power hitters. Because it was invented and long owned by Babe Ruth, who hit 60 home runs in 1927, Maris has always seemed an interloper to some. By 1961, the season had grown by eight games, clouding Maris's achievement.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/09/1030588.xml	        As a child, McGwire first learned about his poor eyesight while playing Little League. His father had replaced him as the pitcher, sending him to shortstop, and when the boy stopped crying, he realized he couldn't see home plate. McGwire now has 20/500 vision, which he corrects with contact lenses. He strikes out about once every 4.5 plate appearances (at-bats plus walks), compared with 1 in 7.6 for Babe Ruth when he hit 60 home runs in 1927, and 1 in 10.2 for Maris in 1961.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/12/1031394.xml	        Those debacles are well documented. But they are also more than 16 years old. But in Steinbrenner's case, there simply is no Curse of Eric Plunk.

nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/14/1031749.xml	        Chris Martens, an ESPN producer, thought Mace Brown, a former Pittsburgh Pirate, was offering him a rare treasure recently. nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/14/1031749.xml	        Martens did get his hands on plenty of material, though, and it will be on display next Tuesday in ''Outside the Lines: Babe Ruth's Larger Than Life Legacy'' (ESPN, 7:30 P.M.). He had wanted to make a documentary about Ruth for at least 10 years, since collaborating with Ruth's daughter, Dorothy Pirone, on a book about the Babe. And he was not the only one on the cinematic trail of the legendary slugger. Within a month, viewers can decide if they learn more from ESPN's work or from HBO's ''Babe Ruth'' (Aug. 16, 8 P.M.).
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/14/1031749.xml	        ''We wanted to look at his legacy, because the shadow he still casts is enormous,'' Martens said. His research included placing an advertisement in Stars and Stripes, the military newspaper, to find any veteran who heard attacking Japanese soldiers scream, ''To hell with Babe Ruth.'' nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/18/1032506.xml	        The Yankees may not have a single Hall of Famer - a Babe Ruth, a Jimmy Foxx or a Johnny Bench - but they don't have any weaknesses. Home-road, grass-turf, lefty-righty - any way you slice the stats, these Yankees have no Achilles' heel.

nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/19/1033084.xml	        A comparison of Roger Maris's record season for home runs in 1961, Babe Ruth's 1927 season and the 1998 seasons of Mark McGwire, Ken Griffey Jr. and Sammy Sosa. In 1961, the season was increased to 162 games from 154.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/19/1033092.xml	        Charles Shoopak letter contends Babe Ruth's includes home runs that bounced over fence (Now called ground-rule doubles); Editor's Note replies
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/19/1033092.xml	        Babe Ruth's record includes home runs that bounced over the fence (now called ground-rule doubles). I am always amazed at how few people realize this. Otherwise it would be most interesting to see if anyone could match his 154-game total. Instead, Maris is the man to beat, over a 162-game season, with no asterisk needed.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/19/1033092.xml	        Editor's Note: No research has ever determined that any of Babe Ruth's 60 home runs in 1927 bounced into the stands under the ground rule that existed in various ball parks at the time. The rule awarded a home run for fly balls hit more than 250 feet that bounced out of the playing field in fair territory. The current rule awarding a double on such ''bounced'' drives was instituted for all parks in 1931.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/22/1033598.xml	        Now imagine it is Sept. 27 in St. Louis, the final day of the regular season: the Cardinals against Montreal. Then visualize that McGwire has 61 home runs and needs the final one to pass Maris, as Maris needed Oct. 1, 1961, to surpass Babe Ruth. Finally, envision 20,000 fans in Busch Stadium, which fits 49,625.

nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/24/1034005.xml	        Chuck Doehler was at the screening, too, because of a cameo role he plays in the HBO film. nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/26/1034499.xml	        Article by James Reston, originally printed on Oct 1, 1961, takes issue with baseball Comr Ford Frick's decision to place asterisk next to Roger Maris's home run record and refusing to recognize that Maris broke Babe Ruth's record; says Frick ruled during 1961 season that home run record would be official only if it was achieved in 154 games; holds Maris hit 59 home runs through 154 games, 1 short of Ruth; notes major league baseball would later remove notation--so-called asterisk--from the record books, but it appeared at the time that Maris had missed his chance to own record outright; photos (M)
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/26/1034499.xml	        As Roger Maris chased Babe Ruth's home run record through the summer of 1961, he carried a burden that Mark McGwire, Ken Griffey and the other players now pursuing Maris do not have: he knew that even if he set the record, it might not count. Ford Frick, the commissioner of baseball, ruled during the season that a home run record would be official only if it was achieved in 154 games; otherwise it would go in the books beside Ruth's mark, with a notation that it was set in a 162-game season.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/26/1034642.xml	        Letter by Tom McMorrow says Roger Maris never broke Babe Ruth's home run record and defends then baseball Comr Ford Frick's decision to place asterisk beside Maris's record, indicating '162 games' (S)

nyt_corpus_1998.har/07/26/1034642.xml	        Almost certainly both records will be broken this year, but let us honor the incomparable Babe Ruth by observing them as separate records.

nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037703.xml	        Their destination is a stone monolith -- perhaps 10 feet tall and offset by adjoining 5-foot stone slabs -- in the cemetery's hill section. It is the most visited grave in the Gate of Heaven by far, Mr. Ford said -- the resting spot of Babe Ruth, who died 50 years ago next Sunday.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037703.xml	        ''With the current generation of young people, how many have heroes who are still known and continue to ring bells?'' said Mr. Ford, the superintendent of Gate of Heaven, who supplies maps and gives directions to the grave. ''Not many. But Babe Ruth's name resonates. He had a uniqueness that's hard to describe.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037703.xml	        More than baseball's greatest and most famous player, Babe Ruth was a metaphor for America's Roaring 20's. His prodigious skills and gregarious, larger-than-life personality transcended the sport, making him an authentic American folk hero. ''I swing big, with everything I've got; I hit big or I miss big,'' Ruth once said in what could be a suitable epitaph for his eventful life. ''I like to live as big as I can.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037703.xml	        The enduring interest in Ruth is no surprise to Robert Creamer of Tuckahoe, author of ''Babe,'' an acclaimed 1974 biography of Ruth, and a longtime senior writer for Sports Illustrated. ''If his name had been Harold Smith instead of Babe Ruth, he might never have been remembered as much,'' he said. ''I mean, 'Babe Ruth,' It has such a ring. It fits his personality; it's a name that kids learn and never forget.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037703.xml	        In total, Ruth hit 714 home runs in a career that spanned 22 major league seasons -- 15 of them spent center stage with the Yankees. He was part of seven World Series winners -- in 1923, 1927, 1928 and 1932 with the Yankees and three times early in his career with the Boston Red Sox. And it was mostly with the Red Sox that Ruth excelled as a pitcher, winning 92 games before it was determined that his bat was more valuable than his arm. But it was more than baseball that cemented America's enduring interest in Babe Ruth.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037703.xml	        Three baseballs -- one signed, ''Rest in Peace Always, Kevin,'' and another painted red and signed, ''Terence and Patrick''; two Yankee hats; several newspaper clippings about Ruth; a framed photograph of perhaps the most famous baseball team of all, Ruth's 1927 Yankees; a Louisville Slugger bat, Darryl Strawberry model; one right-handed George Brett-model glove, belonging to ''Mike''; a Yankee scrapbook, with pictures of Ruth and his fellow Hall of Fame Yankees, Lou Gehrig, Waite Hoyt and Earle Combs (Gehrig is buried down the hill at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla); an American flag and a 3-by-5-inch index card, reading, ''Dear Babe, Happy Father's Day. I'll hit a homer for you. Patrick.'' That is a probable takeoff on the 1948 film ''The Babe Ruth Story'' in which William Bendix, playing Ruth, makes a promise to a dying boy in the hospital.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037703.xml	        As many as could crowded around the canopied plot in front of the receiving tomb, where the coffin, with ''George Herman Ruth'' on its silver nameplate, was placed for the brief committal service. On the tomb is a carving of Jesus with a young boy and an inscribed quote from Cardinal Spellman: 'May the Divine Spirit That Animated Babe Ruth to Win the Crucial Game of Life Inspire the Youth of America.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037743.xml	        It was a scene fit for Norman Rockwell with the post office festooned in red, white and blue balloons, a Babe Ruth look-alike in a vintage Yankees uniform posing for pictures with giggling old ladies, and a skinny boy wearing a baseball cap stuffing his pockets with free candy.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037743.xml	        But this being the big city, not everyone appreciated the milestone or the fanfare surrounding it. ''It's no big deal,'' said a disgruntled postal customer, Fernando Castillo, 43. ''You still have to wait on line for 10 minutes.'' For the most part, though, spirits were high. Maybe it had something to do with the grinning presence of George Herman Ruth, an alter ego of Ron Oer, a 47-year-old Manhattan comedian whose other job is impersonating the actor John Goodman. Standing next to his likeness on a poster-size stamp -- Babe Ruth is featured in the new Celebrate the Century stamp series -- ''the Babe'' was asked his thoughts on McGwire's record. ''The McGuire sisters?'' the slugger said with a grin. ''I like them a lot.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/09/1037950.xml	        He will end the season with no more than 60 home runs, just enough to declare himself the statistical equal of Babe Ruth, which is the best he can hope for. As a personality, a symbol of his times, a salesman for America and its pastime, he is not even in the same ball park as the Bambino. He is a nice guy from suburban Los Angeles, a dentist's son. But he doesn't even have a nickname.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/10/1038192.xml	        A comparison (by number of games played) of Roger Maris's record season of 61 home runs in 1961, Babe Ruth's 1927 season of 60 homers and the 1998 seasons of Mark McGuire, Sammy Sosa, Ken Griffey Jr. and Mo Vaughn.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/11/1038373.xml	        As a longtime player and coach with the Yankees, Frank Crosetti called Babe Ruth, Joe DiMaggio and Mickey Mantle teammates, and when Crosetti counseled Joe Torre in Oakland last week, the Yankees' manager listened. After all, Torre said, Crosetti has enough World Series rings for all his toes and fingers.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/13/1038723.xml	        Maris beat Babe Ruth's 34-year record of 60 home runs in 1961, but the Ruth legend only deepened its mythic footing because his spikes were firmly planted in the American dream, rags to home runs to riches. Now at the far end of the 20th century, in a country with still-painful racial wounds, we have a white man, a black man and a Hispanic man in this contest of Men Chasing Maris. If Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa remain on pace, if Ken Griffey Jr. can get hot again in the next couple of weeks, then Sojo is right. September will be a month to remember, the fitting conclusion to a season when baseball has moved to reclaim its place as the American game of the people.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/13/1038723.xml	        Ruth changed the way the country looked at all ballplayers, only none of them were black. Sam Lacey, the 94-year-old Baltimore Afro-American sportswriter inducted last month into the Hall of Fame, told me recently that he never wrote a single word about Babe Ruth. ''My readers had no interest in anything white on white,'' he said. ''That was a society we weren't part of.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038866.xml	        Ron Wertheimer reviews hourlong documentary, Babe Ruth, on HBO; photo (M)
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038866.xml	        Sixty-three years after his major league career ended, 50 years after his death, Babe Ruth remains a contemporary baseball presence. He is invoked daily this summer. His Yankees are once again trampling everything in their path. Fans and politicians jabber about the future of the ballpark that was built on his exploits. And as several sluggers bang out home runs at a prodigious pace, they endure constant comparisons with Ruth, who, whatever the record book says, remains the heart's champion.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038866.xml	        So it's a fitting moment to revisit the man still widely revered as the best ballplayer of them all. HBO does just that on Sunday night, with an hourlong documentary, ''Babe Ruth.'' The familiar story lopes along -- from the Baltimore bad boy to the Sultan of Swat to the fallen hero lying in state at Yankee Stadium -- told through the expected blend of archival film and talking heads. If you care about Ruth, you've been here.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038866.xml	        His skills eventually decline with age. In 1935, the Yankees have no more use for him. He's heartbroken,  and plays one last season with the Boston Braves. By then, the only thing he knows how to do is be Babe Ruth, so he works as a glad-hander. In his last years, less interesting but more copiously filmed, he is honored finally by the Yankees. Prematurely old in his 50's, a man who started playing big-league ball before the jerseys bore numbers, he watches as his No. 3 is ceremonially retired.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038866.xml	        ''Babe Ruth is the only guy that lived up to his reputation,'' says  Tommy Henrich, a Yankee of a later era. But who can provide deeper insight? Not the other aging men who sit before the camera here. Even redoubtable wordsmiths like Heywood Hale Broun, Studs Terkel and Pete Hamill are reduced to platitudes. ''To me, the Babe is still alive,'' says the veteran sports broadcaster Bill Mazur. Yes, but why?
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038866.xml	        BABE RUTH
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038979.xml	        Ira Berkow Sports of The Times column on late New York Yankees outfielder Roger Maris, who hit 61 home runs in 1961 to break Babe Ruth's single-season mark; photo (M)
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038979.xml	        And Roger Jr., like the rest of the family -- like the rest of the nation, for that matter -- is being reminded daily this year of the most renowned and, to some, notorious achievement of his father's 12-year major league baseball career. It was when he banged out 61 home runs in 1961 to break Babe Ruth's single-season homer mark of 60. Every day Roger Jr. reads how Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa and Ken Griffey Jr., among others, are hitting home runs that put them in position to catch or pass his father.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038979.xml	        ''I'm enjoying it'' said Roger Jr., now 39 years old. ''I think it's neat to know that guys have been chasing the record for so long. You know that Dad has held the home run record longer than Babe Ruth did. Dad broke the record 34 years after Ruth's record. And it's been 37 years since Dad hit 61.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/14/1038979.xml	        ''Most of the country would like to see the record broken -- it adds excitement and interest to the game -- but that wasn't the case when Dad was going for it. He was going up against two baseball icons, Babe Ruth and Mickey Mantle.''

nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/16/1039636.xml	        EVEN as he faced death, Babe Ruth apparently had time for a kid. This is part of the legend that seems beyond dispute, above and beyond the timeless and insoluble debate of whether he called his shot.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/16/1039636.xml	        ''Babe Ruth was the eternal kid, and that's why he could never resist them,'' said a man who has spent the last 16 years unearthing proof.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/16/1039636.xml	        In 1982, Gibbons knocked on the door of the then-struggling Babe Ruth Birthplace Museum to produce a documentary on the most famous American baseball player. He never left 216 Emory Street, the small row house and birthplace of the Babe, in the shadow of what is now Orioles Park at Camden Yards. Here, he marks a fine line between man and myth.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/16/1039636.xml	        The truth of the matter was that the country was crying for Ruth, and it wasn't as if he had any role in the dramatization of the photo op. nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/16/1039656.xml	        Richard Sandomir reviews television program Babe Ruth; photos (M)
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/16/1039656.xml	        Babe Ruth. Dead 50 years today, he never seems to have left us. He was man and myth, a Brobdignagian force of nature who gorged himself on vices and home runs, who adored show business sweeties but reveled in the smiles of children.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/16/1039656.xml	        With klutzy, unathletic William Bendix in ''The Babe Ruth Story,'' a sappy, silly film and with John Goodman, far overweight despite losing 60 pounds to play Ruth in ''The Babe.'' Both films got fundamental facts wrong in trying to fictionalize a life that could hardly be imagined by a novelist.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/16/1039656.xml	        HBO's ''Babe Ruth,'' shown at 8 P.M. tonight, is part of the fabric, a portrait that advances our understanding beyond what we knew of his charm, crudeness, power and mug. We don't suddenly learn that Ruth stole out of his Riverside Drive apartment to trade quips with Dorothy Parker, but what we know of him is illuminated.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/17/1039803.xml	        The Yankees offered a tribute to Babe Ruth on the 50th anniversary of his death before yesterday's game with the Texas Rangers, eliciting respectful cheers from 50,304 fans at Yankee Stadium. The videotape described how important Ruth was to the Yankees, so renowned that he is credited, figuratively, with building the stadium.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/17/1039803.xml	        ''That's a long way,'' said Jeter, who extended his career-high homer total to 15. ''Babe Ruth must have been up there blowing it.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/17/1039803.xml	        It was not a storybook outing for a pitcher who had a Babe Ruth book and a picture of the Bambino in his locker and who wanted the Yankees to avenge Saturday's 16-5 thrashing by Texas.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/21/1040617.xml	        Among the interesting aspects of this assault on Maris's record is what it says about the importance of power to baseball. Spectacular fielding plays are fun to watch, and a no-hitter is a rare thrill, but nothing quite captures the imagination like a home run. In a recent tribute to Babe Ruth's magnificent 1927 season, when he hit 60 home runs, Sports Illustrated suggested that Ruth had singlehandedly changed the face of the game, elevating the home run from ''its relatively modest role into baseball's most dramatic event and a significant force in determining the outcome of a game.'' The sluggers are also good for baseball's balance sheet. The Cardinals are drawing capacity crowds despite a disappointing season, and wherever they go, Sosa and McGwire attract thousands of people who would otherwise have stayed home.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/21/1040646.xml	        McGwire exhibited a rare display of emotion after his first homer of the day off Mets starter Willie Blair in the seventh inning of the opener as he became the first player in major league history to drill 50 homers in three straight seasons, eclipsing Babe Ruth's record of two straight seasons, which Ruth accomplished twice. McGwire pumped his right fist twice and clapped his hands twice as he trotted around the bases and received a rousing ovation from the enemy-turned-envious fans.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/21/1040647.xml	        By hitting his third and fourth home runs in his last seven at-bats, McGwire left himself only six short of Hack Wilson's 68-year-old National League record and 11 short of the big one. But even if McGwire, for some inexplicable reason, were not to eclipse the big one or even the littler one, he has already gained a status even Babe Ruth missed.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/23/1041063.xml	        Why was this such a well-guarded secret? Because this was the 1930's. American boys were practicing Babe Ruth's swings then. Boys were not supposed to be practicing Michel Fokine's five positions.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/23/1041216.xml	        No eulogies here. If there was a lesson to be learned at Forest Hills, it was about the symbolic positive importance of the cathedral in the Bronx. Yankee Stadium and the West Side Club's stadium represented two faces of the sports coin. Both opened in 1923, to take advantage of crowds eager to see one of the era's great sports heroes. Babe Ruth was a throwaway Baltimore kid who refined his game in the schoolyard of an orphan asylum and openly indulged gargantuan and socially tolerated appetites. Bill Tilden learned his game on the private court of his family's country home and eventually went to jail after lying about his sexual relations with young boys.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/23/1041237.xml	        Even as officials within the N.C.A.A. and within the industry began to worry, bats evolved to include things that would have made Babe Ruth's eyes glaze over: hollow air chambers, cryogenic freezing techniques and rare metal compounds like scandium, which is mined only in Ukraine.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/23/1041307.xml	        I am not a Yankee fan, but I do remember the asterisk attached to Roger Maris's record of 61 home runs because of the discrepancy in games played. However, didn't Maris accomplish the feat in fewer at-bats? Aren't the projections based on at-bats, not games played? The fact that Babe Ruth played in fewer games but had more at-bats would be a statistically significant datum.

So the Ruthian record of 60 over a schedule of 154 games is safe for this year at least. It remains to be seen what the reaction will be if Roger belts a few more in the eight games still on this year's Yankee schedule.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/30/1042789.xml	        Roger Maris hit the Golden Gopher last night, crashing his 60th homer to tie Babe Ruth's great and heretofore untouched high of 1927. nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/30/1042789.xml	        In fact, his personality is exactly the opposite of the man whose homer production he matched, Babe Ruth. The Babe roared through life. I wish I were home with my wife and kids. I can't wait for this season to end.''

nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/30/1042862.xml	        She kept all kinds of baseball stuff that mothers have thrown out, sacrificed to garage sales and tossed in the boxes for Goodwill in that time-honored tradition so many mothers are later made to regret. The wrinkled piece of paper Babe Ruth signed, the ball Cy Young autographed at an old-timers' game, the 75 uniforms gathered from ballplayers who had come to know Barry Halper as the kid who would take any baseball souvenir as long as you had signed it -- they were all where he left them in his mom's house in Newark when he happened upon them one day, many years ago.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/30/1042862.xml	        That's when Mr. Halper, who grew up to run his family's wholesale paper products company in Elizabeth and own ''less than 5 percent'' of the New York Yankees, started collecting baseball memorabilia seriously again. The ultimate baseball fanatic owns the Babe Ruth of baseball collections, the biggest private baseball memorabilia collection in the world. It takes up an entire floor of his sprawling suburban contemporary here (plus two warehouses), makes everyone who sees it 8 years old again and nearly runs his life.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/08/30/1042862.xml	        Entering the Halper baseball sanctuary is like falling into a kaleidoscope. It fills five rooms floor to ceiling with a dizzying array of everything from ads to oddities. nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/02/1043458.xml	        Dr. Bruce H. Shelton (letter, Aug. 30) claims that Babe Ruth was aided in setting his home run records because ''vegetables had a far greater mineral content than they do now.''  There are no data to support the idea that fruits and vegetables are of poorer quality today than those of 70 years ago because of poorer soil, water or air quality. Poorer soil will yield fewer fruits and vegetables, but the produce we have today is at least the same, if not better, quality.

For that matter, Roger Maris's splendid year was closer to Babe Ruth's time than the age of the proprietary Mr. Gates from Seattle.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/04/1043829.xml	        It's not hard to imagine how Roger Maris would handle the news media if he were making his assault on Babe Ruth's record of 60 home runs in 1998. The shy, small-town man from Minnesota and North Dakota wearied of the pack of reporters who chronicled his 61-home run season in 1961. What if hundreds of reporters tailed him from city to city, many from cable television and radio outlets unheard of 37 years ago? What if a Howard Stern lackey taunted him with tawdry questions?
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/05/1043975.xml	        He added: ''I spent most of that off season in tap rooms and I was in terrible condition the next spring, 20 pounds overweight, and I had a terrible year. They were expecting me to break Babe Ruth's record, but I hit only 13.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/05/1043977.xml	        McGwire's next home will tie the old record of Babe Ruth, still the greatest slugger of all. The 61st homer would tie the baseball record set by the vastly undervalued Roger Maris in 1961. And the third home run would make at least two people rich -- McGwire and whoever caught the ball (or the next of kin).
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/05/1043979.xml	        The two sluggers are threatening to outpace the field in the manner of Babe Ruth -- or Secretariat. Fans and reporters talk endlessly of a player's pace for the season. But a better indicator might be their recent performance. If they were to extend their success of the past three weeks, McGwire and Sosa would end up with 71 and 68 home runs, respectively. McGwire has 22 games remaining, and Sosa has 21. In their previous 22 games, each player has hit an extraordinary 12 home runs.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/05/1043990.xml	        People of Fargo, ND, are fairly resigned to likelihood that Mark McGwire of St Louis Cardinals and Sammy Sosa of Chicago Cubs will break his home run record this season; are keenly aware of the sadder particulars of Maris's story: that many reporters and Yankee fans did not want him to break Babe Ruth's record in 1961, that his achievement was denigrated and qualified with an asterisk and that Maris was never elected into Baseball Hall of Fame; photo of Maris's gravestone; map (M)
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/05/1043990.xml	        It's not just that Maris, who died in 1985 of lymphatic cancer, was one of their own. It's also that people from this modest prairie town, tundra-cold and table-flat, are moved by some of the sadder particulars of the Maris story: that in 1961, when he played right field for the New York Yankees, Maris felt hounded by reporters and denigrated by those who did not want him to break the record of 60 home runs set by another Yankee right fielder, Babe Ruth, in 1927. People here are also keenly aware that Maris was never elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame and that the baseball commissioner relegated his achievement to a footnote in the record books because the regular season had been extended by eight games at that time -- a notation (since removed) that came to be known as the ''asterisk.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/05/1043990.xml	        ''You really felt sorry for the guy,'' Mr. Savageau said. ''He'd get that same question every day: 'Are you going to hit a home run today? Are you going to break Babe Ruth's record?' ''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/05/1044017.xml	        McGwire got his last chance, for this night, to match Babe Ruth's 60 home runs in 1927, in the seventh inning. nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/06/1044518.xml	        THE ball soared into the steamy ozone of the Mississippi River Valley, and eventually it came down. nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/06/1044530.xml	        The villain in his story was ''the media,'' which made him ''a whipping boy,'' for not being Mickey Mantle. nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/06/1044530.xml	        Many of the people who treated him shabbily are gone, but so are many of the people who might be motivated to make amends. nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/08/1044862.xml	        The signals are that this is for everybody, for Mr. and Mrs. America, for the people in the Caribbean, for the family of Roger Maris, for the memory of Babe Ruth, for the people who buy tickets and sweat in the stands, for anybody who admires grace under pressure.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/08/1044885.xml	        McGwire's record-tying home run came two days after another first-inning home run tied him with Babe Ruth at 60. McGwire's 61st came in his team's 144th game (including one tie), whereas it took Maris 163 games (also one tie) to surpass Ruth. Because he broke Ruth's total well before his team's 154th game -- the length of the season when Ruth played -- McGwire should not face any talk of an asterisk in regards to surpassing Ruth, an issue that bedeviled Maris.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/08/1044885.xml	        The 6-foot-5-inch, 250-pounder cited as evidence of fate his hitting his 61st home run on his father's 61st birthday, as well as the ball he struck for his 60th home run that tied Ruth's 1927 total. The balls being pitched to McGwire and Sosa are specially coded so that baseball officials can tell which are the ones hit into the stands. ''The other day,'' McGwire said, referring to No. 60, ''it was a No. 3 ball. No. 3 was Babe Ruth. I'm the third guy in the history of the game to hit 60 home runs, and I hit it on the third pitch. If that's not fate, I don't know what it is.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/08/1044894.xml	        Griffey, who had 56 homers last year after hitting 49 in 1996, joined McGwire and Babe Ruth as the only players to hit 50 in consecutive seasons. Ruth did it in 1920-21 and 1927-28, and McGwire has hit 50 or more the last three years.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/09/1045033.xml	        It has helped, too, that both men are likable, modest men who train hard and keep looking for ways to improve. When McGwire hit his 61st on Labor Day, surpassing Babe Ruth, nobody seemed happier than Sosa. The only question mark has been the controversy over legal muscle-building supplements, especially in McGwire's case, but the fans and his fellow players do not seem to care. Supplements do not teach the art of hitting a baseball, and for that reason cannot account for the fact that Mark McGwire has become the most consistent home run hitter since Ruth. His is an amazing accomplishment, and with any luck baseball can find ways to build on it.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/09/1045085.xml	        The incessant buzz of the talk-radio age has turned Babe Ruth into ''the fat guy who hit home runs,'' which is purely bogus. Ruth was an agile right fielder for much of his career, with a good arm and a good baseball brain, and Maris was a worthy successor.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/09/1045085.xml	        Maris surpassed Babe Ruth and Mickey Mantle under intense pressure, and his 61 home runs in 1961 should have brought him more fame, more money, more joy, more permanent respect, than they did.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/09/1045085.xml	        ''Roger played in seven World Series, was a two-time most valuable player -- and he broke Babe Ruth's record,'' said Ralph Terry, a former teammate. ''But he got in a feud with a couple of writers, so he's not in the Hall of Fame.''

nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/09/1045101.xml	        Mark McGwire, St Louis Cardinals' first baseman, hits 62d home run at Busch Stadium in St Louis on September 8, surpassing 37-year-old major league record of late Roger Maris, who hit 61 home runs for New York Yankees in 1961; fourth-inning blast off Chicago Cubs pitcher Steve Trachsel comes during Cardinals' 145th game of season, which they won, 6-3, compared with 163 games required by Maris in 1961; traveled estimated 341 feet, just clearing left-field fence near foul line, and is McGwire's shortest home run of season; he is cheered by exultant fans, mobbed by teammates and openly congratulated by members of Cubs in raucous and impromptu celebration; is embraced by Cubs' right fielder Sammy Sosa, who trails him with 58 home runs; McGwire leaps into stands and embraces each of Maris's children; thanks family, fans, Cubs, Sammy Sosa and St Louis; gives Hall of Fame officials home run ball, which was retrieved on field by member of Cardinals' ground crew, as well as bat that hit home run and complete uniform he wore at time; 62d home run breaks tie with Maris, who accomplished feat in Yankees 163d and last game of 1961; Babe Ruth hit 60th home run in 1927 in Yankees 154th and last game; photo (M)

nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/13/1046375.xml	        Sosa's second homer in two days put him two behind Mark McGwire, who went hitless against Randy Johnson and the Astros in Houston. Sosa joined Babe Ruth, Roger Maris and McGwire as the only players to reach the 60-homer mark in a single season. Sosa needed 149 games to tie Ruth, who hit his 60 homers in a 154-game season in 1927. Maris hit 61 in 163 games in 1961, and McGwire, now a national hero, has been stuck at 62 since Tuesday night.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/14/1046505.xml	        Sosa showed grace by muting his celebration on the home run that equaled Babe Ruth at 60 on Saturday and again today on the home runs that tied Maris and McGwire. After he hit No. 60 on Saturday, he did not even smile. Sosa just waved his cap to the crowd and took his seat. But when Orlando Merced hit the game-winning home run in the ninth, Sosa was the first one to greet him at home plate. Today after each home run, he made his trademark leap of exultation and clenched his fists, but ran the bases as if they were routine home runs. When he reached the dugout, Sosa acknowledged the crowd's cheers and was hugged by his teammates. After the game, he helped carry Grace off the field.
