nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/15/1046762.xml	        When Babe Ruth hit 60 home runs in 1927, his biographer noted his boast, ''Sixty, count 'em, 60!'' and Ruth's dare for anyone to match his total. Now Ruth has been matched, and bested, by Roger Maris, McGwire and Sosa. Not a braggart in the bunch.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/15/1046763.xml	        Whatever happens down the stretch, this home run race promises to be more compelling theater than the last weeks of the 1927 season, when Babe Ruth hit 60, and the 1961 season, when Maris hit 61.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/18/1047273.xml	        ''UPPER WEST SIDE WALKING TOUR'' focuses on history and architecture and includes such stops as former residences of Dorothy Parker and Babe Ruth, and the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument. Meets Sunday at 2 P.M. at the southeast corner of Broadway and 70th Street. Fee: $10. Sponsored by New York City Cultural Walking Tours. Information: (212) 979-2388.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/20/1047673.xml	        Less well known is the story of the 15,500-seat Dexter Park baseball field, which once occupied 10 acres in Woodhaven just east of Franklin K. Lane High School. Baseball history was made there in 1930 with the installation of the first engineered lighting system for night games, said Robert F. Eisen, a local baseball historian. He recalled watching the Bushwicks, the semi-pro team that owned the stadium, play night and Sunday ball before sell-out crowds. Babe Ruth, Jackie Robinson, Satchel Paige and Dizzy Dean were among the pros who played against the Bushwicks, he said.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/20/1048013.xml	        Humorous article in form of interview with Babe Ruth on Larry King Live television show; photo (M)
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/20/1048013.xml	        After a long silence, Babe Ruth has emerged for a rare interview on tonight's ''Larry King Live.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/09/20/1048013.xml	        Larry King: Tonight, a kid so incorrigible his parents threw him out of the family tavern. Pitcher, slugger, gorger, ladies' man. George Herman Ruth. The Babe. A great honor to have the difficult-to-get Babe Ruth in our studio. You've been on our wish list for years.  Babe Ruth: I figured I had to do this sooner or later. Now I've got my Playstation Hooters All-Star Babe '99 CD-ROM game to promote.  King: So many areas to cover. Let's start with Mark McGwire. You know him?  Ruth: Sure.  King: Great guy, good friend, frequent guest.  Ruth: A 6-foot-6 inch weenie. What's he swing, a 34-ounce bat? I showed him the stick I hit 60 with. Fifty ounces. Big wimp couldn't lift it. Whined like Ty Cobb when he didn't get invited to my 50th birthday party at Nathan's.  King: Amazing. Have you talked to Sammy Sosa?  Ruth: Talk to him? He's wearing my lucky cup from 1927.  King: Babe, you played fat. Why?  Ruth: I'm an endomorph, kid. It's my body type. I couldn't help it. Dr. Dean Ornish helped me learn not to hate myself for it.  King: So it wasn't the hot dogs?  Ruth: Ah, that was a lot of hype. Sportswriters saw me eat a dozen dogs between innings and thought that was all I ate. Mostly I ate baby carrots and soy burgers.  King: Supermodel food but still a porker. Amazing. Lou Gehrig. You hated him.  Ruth: Only after his mother made me a sauerbraten with cabbage that put me in a slump in '31. Couldn't lift a bat or a woman for a week.  King: Slugging and sweet talk with the one and only Babe Ruth. We'll be back.  (Begin video clip: William Bendix in a scene from ''The Babe Ruth Story.'')  King: Lots of critics think that was the worst sports movie ever.  Ruth: Can't disagree. But did you see ''Baseketball''? I had to hear Bob Costas talk about how hard his nipples were. But I loved ''Happy Gilmore.'' Adam Sandler just kills me.  King: Why has nobody portrayed Babe Ruth well on the silver screen?  Ruth: I thought John Goodman would be great. But talk about endomorphic! He was 70 pounds too fat playing me when I was 40 pounds overweight. And I'll tell you, I wasn't fat as a kid. But that movie made me look like a hippo at 15.  King: You were great as you in ''Pride of the Yankees.'' If Babe Ruth could choose an actor to play Babe Ruth, who would it be?  Ruth: Pacino. Who else?  King: Great choice. Good friend. Frequent guest. Columbus, Ohio, you're talking to Babe Ruth.  Caller: Hi, Babe. What do you think is the worst trade ever?  Ruth: When that bum Steinbrenner traded Jay Buhner for Ken Phelps. How could he trade a future superstar for a guy who was out of baseball in two years?  King: Walla Walla, Washington, hello.  Caller: Babe, I hear you were depressed because nobody asked you to manage in the majors. But you seem happy now. What's your secret?  Ruth: St. John's Wort. And I read the ''Don't Sweat the Small Stuff'' books.  King: Let's go back. You grew up in Baltimore. Orphanage life tough?  Ruth: Nah, I loved it. Learned baseball there. Played the recorder in the St. Mary's marching band.  King: You were musically inclined?  Ruth: Kid, you think all I did was hit home runs? I had a liberal arts education, short as it was.  King: Did you have any quibbles with the Modern Library's list of the greatest 100 books ever?  Ruth: No Toni Morrison. No Wally Lamb. No Dick Schaap.  King: Me, I'd have voted for Wilt Chamberlain's memoir. Babe, what do you think -- Yankee Stadium on the West Side?  Ruth: Kid, I live on the West Side and I don't want it there. Too much traffic. And a billion dollars? Cripes, I built the first one for $2.5 million.  King: So you're for keeping it in the Bronx?  Ruth: I didn't build it to move it, Larry.  King: You ever meet Rudy Giuliani?  Ruth: Only long enough to sell him a cap with some old sweat on it for 50 grand. He thought it was mine. It was really Wally Pipp's.  King: Don't ever be a stranger, buddy. The name is Babe Ruth. What a mensch. Tomorrow night from Washington, William Bennett and Little Richard. Good night.

nyt_corpus_1998.har/10/04/1051641.xml	        The first sign that 1998 would be the season of the slugger came early, when the Cardinals' Mark McGwire hit four home runs in his first four games. But the pursuit of Roger Maris's 37-year-old home run record was set in full motion by the Cubs' Sammy Sosa when he hit an unprecedented 20 home runs in June. By the end of August, each player had hit 55 home runs and suddenly a game that had produced only two 60 home run hitters in its history was poised to produce two in the same season. McGwire got there first, but Sosa soon joined him and they were even at 66 going into the final weekend. McGwire finally brought the chase to a conclusion with four home runs in his last two games. Babe Ruth and Roger Maris are no longer the landmarks. Now, the names that home run hitters will aspire to are Sammy Sosa and Mark McGwire.

nyt_corpus_1998.har/10/23/1056156.xml	        LOUISVILLE SLUGGER MUSEUM, 800 West Main Street, (502) 588-7228. Look for what may be the world's tallest bat perched outside the door. After a short film, visitors walk through the full-size dugout and onto the museum's playing field. There are exhibitions, interactive displays (the sensation of a 90 m.p.h. pitch coming at you), baseball equipment and memorabilia. ''Baseball's Revolutionary Louisville Slugger Remembers Babe Ruth,'' featuring original photographs, artifacts and memorabilia, is on view through October. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tours every 20 minutes, lasting about 90 minutes. Admission: $5; $4.50 for the elderly; $3 for children 6 to 12; under 6, free.

nyt_corpus_1998.har/11/15/1062250.xml	        Mr. Eno had never turned his hand to songwriting until the idea for the ''King of Swing'' came to him on his way home from a gig soon after his mother's death in July. Mr. Eno saw news of the home run race in a newspaper at a rest stop on the highway. Back in the car, he said he started thinking about his mother and the idea for the song came to him. By the time he got home several hours later, the music and lyrics were complete, with, Mr. Eno says, his mother to thank for the inspiration. The song's title comes not only as a play on swing music, but as a tribute to Babe Ruth, known as the ''Sultan of Swat.''

nyt_corpus_1998.har/12/29/1073175.xml	        The Doctor's World article by Lawrence K Altman on Babe Ruth's death in 1948 from rare naso-pharyngeal cancer that arose in air passages at back of his nose and mouth and later spread; Ruth was one of first patients to receive chemotherapy, and possibly the first to get combination chemotherapy and radiation; images of hoarse Ruth at Yankee Stadium farewell contributed to myth even among doctors that he had throat cancer, possibly linked to his heavy drinking, smoking and use of snuff; study of The New York Times microfilmed articles on death and autopsy report reveal details of treatments that dramatically eased his suffering, but only temporarily; Ruth, whose health started failing in 1946, may not have been told directly that he had cancer, but he was given experimental drug teropterin by Dr Richard Lewisohn's team at Mt Sinai Hospital, and, later, radiation at Memorial Hospital; he died of pneumonia on August 16, 1948; photos (M)
nyt_corpus_1998.har/12/29/1073175.xml	        At Babe Ruth Day at Yankee Stadium in 1947, the baseball hero of the generation stood before an admiring crowd, deep in pain and emaciated from advancing cancer, not yet aware of what ailed him. In the dugout moments before, clad in a topcoat and golf hat, he suffered a coughing spell, then, pulling himself together, walked to home plate, mentally recalling the day Lou Gehrig had made the same trip.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/12/29/1073175.xml	        Ruth's health began failing in September 1946 when he sought to return to baseball as a manager. His voice became progressively hoarser. He was gripped with severe and relentless pain in his left eye. His head ached. In November, he entered French Hospital in New York City, where doctors diagnosed sinusitis, then looked at possible dental problems and pulled three teeth, without improvement. His face swelled, his left eye became shut and he lost the ability to swallow. Ruth said he ''seldom could speak.'' When he did, he wrote in his autobiography (''The Babe Ruth Story,'' E. P. Dutton & Co., 1948), his ''voice sounded like somebody gargling ashes.''
nyt_corpus_1998.har/12/29/1073175.xml	        In April 1947, every ball park in organized baseball celebrated Babe Ruth Day when Ruth, bolstered by his radiation treatments, uttered his famous hoarse words. By June, those benefits from radiation had waned. Severe pain had returned; he could not sleep.
nyt_corpus_1998.har/12/29/1073175.xml	        The Babe Ruth trials clearly exemplify just how much has changed in a half century. Today, besides requiring more extensive animal testing, Federal officials demand that researchers obtain written patient consent and gain approval from formal committees before testing experimental therapies on volunteers.

Other memorable memorabilia have also been tossed in. There is the ball Hank Aaron slammed for his 755th homer, the career record. There is a baseball signed by Babe Ruth and Roger Maris (the two previous record-holders for most home runs in a season before McGwire and Sosa), and another signed by Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig. There is a single lot consisting of 50 souvenirs from last year's world champion Yankees.

Jack Johnson (No. 100) infuriated white America by daring to knock down white boxers and date white women. Joe Namath (No. 88) quarterbacked the biggest upset in Super Bowl history and seemed to personify the liberated 1960's in sports. Josh Gibson (No. 73) hit home runs longer than Babe Ruth's, but lived and died in the era of the Negro leagues. Althea Gibson (No. 65) was the first great black American tennis player. Satchel Paige (No. 63) kept pitching until baseball opened up for him. Billie Jean King (No. 59) won major tennis titles while advancing women's sports. nyt_corpus_1999.har/03/09/1091119.xml	        Now, in the shadow of his passing, I find myself wondering about that explanation. Yes, he was a cultural icon, a hero if you will, but not of my generation. He belonged to my father's youth: he was a World War II guy whose career began in the days of Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig and ended with the arrival of the youthful Mickey Mantle (who was, in truth, my favorite ballplayer).
nyt_corpus_1999.har/03/09/1091055.xml	        DiMaggio was one of those rare sports stars, like Babe Ruth, Muhammad Ali and Michael Jordan, who not only set new standards of athletic excellence but also became a distinctive part of American culture. As stylish off the field as on, DiMaggio was an icon of elegance and success, a name as recognizable on Broadway and in Hollywood as at the ball park. Millions of baby boomers who never saw DiMaggio play instantly understood the reference in the Paul Simon song of the 1960's -- ''Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio? A nation turns its lonely eyes to you.''
nyt_corpus_1999.har/03/09/1091055.xml	        But the numbers alone do not explain the DiMaggio mystique. Part of it was his brief, turbulent marriage to Marilyn Monroe and his taste for nightclubs and tony hotels. Part of it was his $100,000-a-year salary, a small fortune in his days as a Yankee. For younger fans, there was also an almost mystical link to the past -- DiMaggio joined the Yankees in 1936, just two years after Babe Ruth left and before Lou Gehrig retired. His appearance on ceremonial occasions at Yankee Stadium in recent years was thrilling for fans of all ages.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/03/09/1091140.xml	        Joe DiMaggio, the flawless center fielder for the New York Yankees who, along with Babe Ruth and Mickey Mantle, symbolized the team's dynastic success across the 20th century and whose 56-game hitting streak in 1941 made him an instant and indelible American folk hero, died early today at his home here. He was 84 years old.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/03/09/1091140.xml	        DiMaggio burst onto the baseball scene from San Francisco in the 1930's and grew into the game's most gallant and graceful center fielder. He wore No. 5 and became the successor to Babe Ruth (No. 3) and Lou Gehrig (No. 4) in the Yankees' pantheon. DiMaggio was the team's superstar for 13 seasons, beginning in 1936 and ending in 1951, and appeared in 11 All-Star Games and 10 World Series. He was, as the writer Roy Blount Jr. once observed, ''the class of the Yankees in times when the Yankees outclassed everybody else.''
nyt_corpus_1999.har/03/09/1091140.xml	        DiMaggio was left in San Francisco for the 1935 season to heal his knee and put the finishing touches on his game, then was brought up to New York in 1936 to join a talented team that included Lou Gehrig, Bill Dickey, Tony Lazzeri, Red Rolfe, Red Ruffing and Lefty Gomez. It was two years after Babe Ruth had left, and an era of success had ended.

He was 84 years old.

nyt_corpus_1999.har/03/10/1091260.xml	        Joe DiMaggio was tall, handsome, splendidly talented, and a champion. He was modest and came from a humble background. He was tough, and yet he was elegant, both on the field and off. He had class. Americans, still nursing the wounds of the Depression, and now faced with a World War, could use a guy like Joe. He wasn't a middle-aged, over-the-hill rascal, like the retired Babe Ruth. And he wasn't tainted, like Lindbergh.

''Babe Ruth was himself, but DiMaggio was the Yankees. The way he played was not exuberant. He did everything in a restrained and deadly way. He was authoritative in a way that New York was authoritative. That is when we all thought of ourselves as very much the center of things.''

nyt_corpus_1999.har/04/01/1096710.xml	        The page is dominated by text and virtually devoid of graphics. One enjoyable feature uses a formula for something called Bases per Plate Appearance (Total bases + walks + hit by pitch + stolen bases - caught stealing - grounded into double play) divided by (at-bats + walks + hit by pitch + sacrifice flies) to compare how Mark McGwire's 70-home-run season stacks up against the best of all time. McGwire's B.P.A. of .799 was the best ever in the National League but third overall, behind a couple of Babe Ruth's seasons: .863 in 1921 and .862 in 1920.

nyt_corpus_1999.har/05/30/1111122.xml	        Before the professional league's demise, baseball and Cuba's national identity grew up together, from the country's limited break from Spain in 1878 to full independence 20 years later. ''Baseball was played since the beginning of the nation,'' Gonzlez Echevarria writes, ''hence it was part of the nation.'' Its winter league grew strong enough to attract major league teams for exhibition series, the most notable being a Giants hodgepodge managed by John McGraw and featuring a portly slugger in an odd uniform: Babe Ruth. The Cincinnati Reds came over once, and that relationship helped them sign one of the best Cuban pitchers ever, Dolf Luque, who won 27 games in 1923.

Dating from 1790, it has been a stagecoach stop, general store, tavern, possibly a brothel, and has numbered Babe Ruth among its regular customers.  The low, wood ceilings offer reasonable acoustics, wonderful atmosphere and a bit of a challenge for someone as tall as Big Mike. The stage is in the front, and the original front porch can be seen through the more recent but equally roadhouse-worthy stained glass windows.

nyt_corpus_1999.har/08/01/1127321.xml	        The Mayor is clearly in love with the idea of the heroic. He reveres the old Yankee immortals, and his outer office has a photograph of Joe DiMaggio in midswing (and another of Babe Ruth). His great passion, of course, is opera -- and not the corrosive irony of Mozart, but the melodrama and unambiguous moralism and noble death of Verdi. I once heard Giuliani give a very simple and touching speech on this subject. At a ceremony renaming a firehouse for Capt. Scott LaPiedra, who died in the line of duty a year earlier, Giuliani drew inspiration from a plaque on the wall commemorating a firefighter who died at Iwo Jima, and compared firefighters to soldiers in war. ''I'd like you to know why we put you through this ordeal,'' he said, turning to the captain's wife and children and talking with that odd lisp that makes him seem almost flannel-tongued. ''We do it because this is the way in our society, in our culture, we inspire men. . . . We have heroes to convince ordinary people that they can do extraordinary things out of love for other people.''

nyt_corpus_1999.har/08/06/1128732.xml	        In moving to the brink of 500, McGwire took larger strides than any of his predecessors. McGwire's 500th gave him 223 home runs in the last four seasons, a whopping 45 percent of his total. When Babe Ruth hit his 500th, he had 191 in his last four seasons. Hank Aaron's 500th in 1968 gave him 134 in his last four seasons.

nyt_corpus_1999.har/08/15/1130770.xml	        And the significance of records keeps changing. When Roger Maris, who was not Mickey Mantle, hit 61 home runs in one season, we were told that Babe Ruth's really important record was his lifetime tally. Then Hank Aaron, who was not white, hit 715 and we were told that Joe DiMaggio's 56-game hitting streak was the one true record. Maybe if we ever learn to embrace McGwire, we can go back to the single-season home run record.

nyt_corpus_1999.har/08/20/1131847.xml	        Tough? It might have been tough for McGwire to play under the pressure and the attention he created for himself, but it sure didn't look tough. He didn't just break the record; he obliterated it. Whacking a 509-foot home run here, a 501-foot home run there, McGwire slugged 19 more home runs. When Maris broke Babe Ruth's legendary record, he squeaked by it by one. After McGwire reached 62, he hit 8 more home runs.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/08/20/1131847.xml	        Just about. McGwire has hit home runs so frequently the past few seasons that few pitchers have been able to avoid his magical bat. No one, not Babe Ruth, not Henry Aaron, had ever reached those milestones in successive seasons.

nyt_corpus_1999.har/08/23/1132720.xml	        McGwire received a polite standing ovation for hitting Jeff Tam's fastball 401 feet and achieving something that not even Babe Ruth had ever accomplished. nyt_corpus_1999.har/08/24/1132860.xml	        Mark McGwire often says (and no doubt Sammy Sosa feels the same way) that he would much prefer to be playing for a team with a chance to win the pennant, which he isn't, than to be chasing his own record of 70 home runs, which he is. Still, both he and Sosa, who hit 66 last season, must be deriving some private pleasure from the fact that they are once again lighting up the major leagues with a home run race that may not have quite the electricity of last year's chase but, statistically speaking, is every bit as impressive. By Sunday night, Sosa had 51 homers and McGwire 50. At this rate, both will again exceed Babe Ruth's mark of 60 home runs for a 154-game season and Roger Maris's total of 61 for the modern 162-game season.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/08/24/1132860.xml	        Those standards are beginning to look a bit like the four-minute mile. Once Roger Bannister broke that seemingly impenetrable barrier in 1954, a lot of runners broke it. But for now, the only people with a shot at 60 or more homers are the same two who did it last year. Their nearest pursuer in the National League is Houston's Jeff Bagwell, with 37 homers through the weekend. In the American League, Seattle's Ken Griffey Jr. had 38. McGwire and Sosa, like Babe Ruth before them, are plainly in a league of their own.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/08/25/1133150.xml	        Griffey joined Babe Ruth, Ralph Kiner, Duke Snider, Ernie Banks, Harmon Killebrew and Mark McGwire as the only players to hit 40 or more homers in four consecutive seasons. Griffey hit 49, 56 and 56 in his previous three seasons.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/09/04/1135218.xml	        There is also unexpected mystery in them. Tears are the marks of saints (St. Francis of Assisi was said to have been blinded from weeping) and sinners (''You're good, sister,'' Bogart sardonically tells the tearful Mary Astor in ''The Maltese Falcon.'' ''Very good.''). They seem to challenge some gender stereotypes (Norman Schwarzkopf publicly wept; so did Lou Gehrig, Mickey Mantle and Babe Ruth) and reinforce others (several studies have shown that American women cry four or five times as often as men). Tears have been treated as aphrodisiacs, sacraments, curses.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/09/05/1135429.xml	        But in Mr. Halper's home, some things remain the same. He was unable to part with some items of value, for sentimental reasons. He was also unable to part with some items of perhaps little economic value, for the same heart-plucking reasons. He has held on to books and photographs signed ''To my friend, Barry Halper'' from the likes of Joe DiMaggio and George Brett, a lock of Babe Ruth's hair, a rubber glove once used by a doctor to examine Mickey Mantle, to name a few.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/09/05/1135429.xml	        In Mr. Halper's spacious den, which is sectioned off into four rooms, are empty glass cases and barren areas on the walls. No longer can one peer into the window in one part of the wood paneling and see, with a flick of a switch, 1,053 baseball uniforms come rolling past on a dry cleaner's carousel. Many of the uniforms are signed; they include those worn by Cap Anson for the 1888 Chicago White Stockings, Jim Thorpe for the 1918 New York Giants and Jackie Robinson when he played for Kansas City of the Negro leagues in 1946; others belonged to Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Willie Mays and Pete Rose. (About the only things left on the carousel are a few of Mr. Halper's seldom worn suits and some dresses that belong to his wife, Sharon.)
nyt_corpus_1999.har/09/05/1135429.xml	        ''When I was going through my collection,'' Mr. Halper recalled, ''I said to my wife and sons, Steven and Jason, 'I'll have to keep this contract of Babe Ruth's from the Red Sox in 1918, and I have to keep this ball and that bat . . . ' And they said, 'If you're going to keep all those things, you might as well start a new collection,' and so I let most of it go.''
nyt_corpus_1999.har/09/05/1135429.xml	        STILL hanging on the wall in Mr. Halper's basement, however, is a framed letter from 1932 that reads: ''In all my years in baseball I have received many requests of autographs, balls, bats, equipment, but you are the first person to ask for some of my hair. Therefore I feel I am obligated to comply with such a request at least once. You will find enclosed an envelope containing some of my hair. I don't know what you're going to do with it, but I hope you enjoy it. Good luck with your collection. Sincerely, Babe Ruth.''
nyt_corpus_1999.har/09/05/1135429.xml	        Inside the frame is a lock of the Babe's hair, dark brown with a few strands of gray. A note beside it reads, ''I guarantee that the enclosed hair is my own, Babe Ruth.'' The note was addressed not to Barry Halper but to Matthew Ward, a memorabilia collector from Ruth's time with whom Mr. Halper would have obviously identified.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/09/08/1136258.xml	        One year ago on Sept. 7, McGwire bested Babe Ruth's 1927 mark of 60 home runs. The next day, he made obsolete Roger Maris's 1961 record of 61. Then began the friendly competition with Sosa, who finished at 66 homers while McGwire pushed on to 70.

nyt_corpus_1999.har/09/19/1138970.xml	        DURING the half-century in which he accumulated the finest private collection of baseball memorabilia in the world -- rivaling that of the Hall of Fame in  Cooperstown, N.Y. -- Barry Halper was never satisfied with gathering such conventional mementoes as autographed bats and balls. The Livingston, N.J., resident craved artifacts that told stories, from the contract that sold Babe Ruth from the Boston Red Sox to the New York Yankees to a jar of Vaseline signed by the spitballer Gaylord Perry, from George Brett's ''pine-tar'' home run baseball to the shotgun Ty Cobb's mother used to kill his father.

As you can see clearly in photographs we have, the remains of this dilapidated building did pose danger to anyone nearby. The building consisted only of partial sides and no roof. During construction of our fields I would constantly notice loose bricks and stones falling from one of the only remaining walls onto our property. I realized this was a hazard to anyone who might be in proximity to the building, keeping in mind that hundreds of children would soon be occupying these fields.

nyt_corpus_1999.har/09/29/1141441.xml	        The Yankees have had far more instances of team and home run championships than any other team, but even they have not achieved those dual honors regularly. In recent years the Yankees haven't had that type of home run hitter. nyt_corpus_1999.har/10/17/1146141.xml	        The 1920's were the golden age of myth-making sports journalism. A handful of talented writers who found other paths to literary fame blocked began to notice, as indeed their editors had already noticed, that a rising middle class was responding more to the exploits of Jack Dempsey, Babe Ruth and Bobby Jones than to what would come to be known as ''hard'' news stories. Paul Gallico of the New York Daily News, who later went on to better things, admitted to being a ''Gee-Whizzer'' -- one of the new breed of sportswriter who wrote in ''the most florid and exciting prose.''

The business has been in the same location, a brownstone on the south side of West 57th Street, since 1927, the year Babe Ruth hit 60 home runs, the first national radio networks were founded and telephone service was inaugurated between New York and London.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/12/02/1157639.xml	        THE BABE AND I. Written by David A. Adler. Illustrated by Terry Widener. (Gulliver Books/Harcourt Brace & Company; $16.) In the Bronx during the Depression the narrator discovers that his father is really selling apples on the street instead of going to the office. So he becomes a ''newsie,'' successfully hawks papers by Yankee Stadium and even sells one  for $5 to Babe Ruth, who tells him, ''Keep the change.'' The story's sentimentality is balanced by its cheerful, witty pictures, in which hard times were times that brought people together.

nyt_corpus_1999.har/12/08/1159206.xml	        The fact is, however, that corruption is the only serious threat to our booming big-time sports. And when Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis saved baseball after the 1919 Chicago Black Sox scandal (with a big assist from Babe Ruth) he made gambling the only capital crime in the Major League Agreement. Unlike drug abuse, which is subject to collective bargaining with the players union because it is viewed as a sickness,  betting on baseball has never been viewed as a medical issue. And it has been exceptionally rare.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/12/14/1160839.xml	        Jack Dempsey, the brutal ''Manassa Mauler'' of the 1920's, not only helped make boxing a big-time sport, but he also helped turn sports into a big business. He belonged, along with Babe Ruth, Red Grange, Bobby Jones and Johnny Weissmuller, to the so-called golden age of sports, and he is remembered to this day for his unaccommodated ferocity in the ring. Red Smith hailed him as ''a tiger without mercy'' and ''187 pounds of unbridled violence.'' Joyce Carol Oates described him as ''the very embodiment of hunger, rage, the will to do hurt; the spirit of the Western frontier come East to win his fortune.''
nyt_corpus_1999.har/12/14/1160936.xml	        Now ESPN faces a new test: as the countdown heads to No. 1, it will be fascinating to see how well-chronicled lives like Muhammad Ali's, Babe Ruth's and Michael Jordan's can be freshened up. Expect the unexpected.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/12/24/1163407.xml	        New Look at Ruth's 'Called Shot'  A home-movie clip from a Nebraska farm shows Babe Ruth gesturing just before his fabled -- and much debated -- ''called shot'' homer.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/12/24/1163416.xml	        Comment on home movie filmed in Oct 1932 in which Babe Ruth is seen gesturing in way that made some witnesses believe he was pointing to spot in outfield where he would slug home run in world series game; photos (M)
nyt_corpus_1999.har/12/24/1163416.xml	        Warp wasn't an artiste, but in his jiggly style, he filmed one of baseball's legendary sequences: Babe Ruth gesturing in a way that made some witnesses believe he was pointing to a spot in the outfield where he would slug a home run. Ruth then hammered a solo shot off the Cubs' Charlie Root that the film shows, for the first time, landing in faraway center field. Then, Ruth rounds the bases, making mocking gestures to the bench jockeys on the Cubs who were riding him mercilessly.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/12/24/1163416.xml	        When the Ruth footage was played for the family, Jacobs said yesterday, ''You could hear Harold say: 'This is Wrigley Field. There's Lou Gehrig. There's Babe Ruth.' But he wasn't a big fan.'' In 1994, Warp died.
nyt_corpus_1999.har/12/26/1163945.xml	        Especially with Jordan gone, it was easy for Muhammad Ali to emerge this year as the consensus athlete of the century. The pick that would have seemed breathtakingly radical when he actually was the world's most famous person now seems a safe bet. Never as economically important as Jordan and once considered far more of a moral danger than Sprewell, Ali has been tamed by disease and new times. He seems to be celebrated mostly for his nostalgia value rather than his long-gone power to shake up the world. While Jordan and Babe Ruth were probably his closest rivals, a very strong case for the century's m.v.p. could be made for Billie Jean King. Her impact on sports -- think women, promotion, populism and professionalism -- has been enormous and unique.
nyt_corpus_2000.har/01/02/1165612.xml	        Before that season, balls hit over those fences were doubles. They were doubles after that season, too. Williamson, who had hit a total of eight home runs in six previous seasons, connected for a total of 29 in six subsequent seasons. If that record can be discounted as a fluke, the record-holder before Babe Ruth made home runs his province beginning in 1919 was Harry Stovey, a first baseman, who hit 14 home runs for Philadelphia in 1883.
nyt_corpus_2000.har/01/02/1165647.xml	        THE SPORTS WORLD OF THE 20TH CENTURY embraced everyone form Babe Ruth to Kobe Bryant. It was crammed with thrills and disappointments and was punctuated by the fantastic finishes that left millions of sports fans holding their breaths, always believing that it's not over till it's over and that somehow their heroes would win. Here are some snapshots of moments that brought tears of joy and despair.
nyt_corpus_2000.har/01/03/1165800.xml	        She wanted to do everything in her beloved city, they said, and came close. She saw Babe Ruth at Yankee Stadium and Enrico Caruso at the old Metropolitan Opera and had subscriptions to the New York City Ballet, the New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall. She rode on trolley cars, worked for $6 a week, wore ribbed stockings and recalled winters in the days before the city plowed snow from the streets.
nyt_corpus_2000.har/01/03/1165800.xml	        Miss Green remembered winters adrift in snow, playing jacks on the sidewalk, trolley cars and annual Fourth of July outings to Coney Island. Her father took her to see Babe Ruth and talked about the day's news over the dinner table; her mother did the family laundry weekly with a hand wringer and two washtubs.

They will tell you that Babe Ruth never promised to hit a home run for him in Game 4 of the 1926 World Series, and that the three home runs that the Babe did hit in that game in no way saved the 11-year-old youngster's life.
nyt_corpus_2000.har/01/09/1167045.xml	        Greenberg's greatness is undisputed. In a career interrupted for most of five seasons by World War II, the lumbering first baseman hit 331 home runs, compiled a .313 career batting average and knocked in 1,276 runs. In 1937, his 183 runs batted in were one fewer than Lou Gehrig's league record. His 58 home runs in 1938 were second to the 60 hit by Babe Ruth in 1927.

nyt_corpus_2000.har/01/12/1167935.xml	        The 1930's and 40's were the heyday of Greenberg, a son of Jewish immigrants who came out of the Bronx to star with the Detroit Tigers, threaten Babe Ruth's home run record (with 58 home runs in 1938), become the first man to win most valuable player awards at two positions, first base and left field, and become baseball's first $100,000 player.

nyt_corpus_2000.har/01/23/1170876.xml	        Camden Yards blends baseball history (Babe Ruth's birthplace is one sultanic swat away) with consumerism (microbeers and good sausage in the open-air food court) and a reassuring feel of old-timey red brick and steel grillwork. nyt_corpus_2000.har/01/28/1171926.xml	        ''THE LIFE AND TIMES OF HANK GREENBERG,'' directed by Aviva Kempner (not rated, 90 minutes). This unabashed valentine to baseball's Hall of Fame slugger demonstrates how little mankind and some of its sports figures have advanced since the 1930's and 40's and reminds us how the persistence of bigotry stains a nation founded on ideals like religious tolerance. The 30's and 40's were the heyday of Greenberg, a son of Jewish immigrants who came out of the Bronx to star with the Detroit Tigers, threaten Babe Ruth's home run record and become the first man to win most valuable player awards at two positions, first base and left field. In blazing his trail into the Hall of Fame, the tall, handsome Greenberg became a target of anti-Semites. But his stardom, his innate decency, his work ethic and his World War II record made him a beacon of hope to many Jews. Taken as a whole, the documentary is faithful to its title, valuable as history and resonant with meaning for today (Lawrence Van Gelder).
nyt_corpus_2000.har/01/30/1172695.xml	        ''Not many people would capture fans the way McGwire did,'' Devine said. ''Even a mild baseball fan would recognize the home run record and Babe Ruth, so he immediately did something most people, even if they weren't fans, could relate to.''
nyt_corpus_2000.har/02/04/1173695.xml	        ''EYE OF THE BEHOLDER,'' starring Ewan McGregor and Ashley Judd. Directed by Stephan Elliott (R, 105 minutes). Mr. McGregor is a British surveillance expert and Ms. Judd the serial-killing femme fatale he falls in love with (while observing her kill a boyfriend) in this ludicrous psycho-thriller. As Mr. McGregor's character, known only as the Eye, follows the object of his obsession from city to city, the movie tries futilely to capture some of the mystique of ''Vertigo.'' But the film, by the director best known for ''The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,'' is so garish, disjointed and incoherent that it feels like an extended music video posing as a movie (Stephen Holden).  ''FANTASIA/2000,'' with James Levine and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and introductions by Steve Martin, Bette Midler, Mr. Levine, Itzhak Perlman, James Earl Jones, Angela Lansbury, Quincy Jones and Penn and Teller. Various directors (G, 75 minutes). The  millennial version of Disney's 1940 groundbreaking fusion of animation and classical music includes seven new segments and keeps one from the original film (the wonderful ''Sorcerer's Apprentice,'' starring Mickey Mouse). Despite the science-fiction title and the Imax-size screen on which it is shown, ''Fantasia/2000'' is more backward-looking than futuristic. The two best segments are ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' a witty Manhattan-in-the-Jazz-Age homage to the caricaturist Al Hirschfeld set to the music of Gershwin, and the finale (set to Stravinsky's ''Firebird'' Suite), in which a cometlike sprite whooshes around the globe explosively creating, destroying and renewing the planet's life forms. Celebrity introductions lend the film the feel of a deluxe corporate promotion. At the Sony Imax Theater, Broadway at 68th Street, (Holden).  ''GIRL, INTERRUPTED,'' starring Winona Ryder and Angelina Jolie. Directed by James Mangold (R, 120 minutes). Except for being several years too old for the role, Winona Ryder, an actress who oozes high-strung intelligence, is ideally cast as Susanna Kaysen, a college-age girl who lands in a Massachusetts mental institution in 1967 after a halfhearted suicide attempt. (The movie is based on Ms. Kaysen's memoir.) The period details are perfect, and Ms. Ryder has the courage to make her character a pain in the neck. But the small, introspective movie is nearly stolen by Ms. Jolie as a charismatic, brutally truth-telling sociopath who becomes Susanna's best friend (Holden).  ''THE GREEN MILE,'' starring Tom Hanks, Michael Clarke Duncan, David Morse, Doug Hutchison, Sam Rockwell and Bonnie Hunt. Written and directed by Frank Darabont (R, 180 minutes). In adapting the death row drama that Stephen King wrote in multiple installments, the director of ''The Shawshank Redemption'' could have managed more economy and fewer talky bits of business around the cellblock. Still, this lengthy film is vivid and well played. Smooth ensemble acting builds up to the discovery that a gigantic condemned man (Mr. Duncan) is a prisoner with very special abilities, which gives the film its mixture of religious overtones and mild horror. Mr. Hanks, as a wry Southern prison guard, is so unaffectedly good that it's redundant to say so (Maslin).  ''HOLY SMOKE,'' starring Kate Winslet and Harvey Keitel. Directed by Jane Campion (R, 95 minutes). Having roamed so gorgeously through North Africa as a young hippie mother in ''Hideous Kinky,'' Ms. Winslet this time appears in India as Ruth Barron, a headstrong young Australian seeking enlightenment. Eventually Ruth's mother coaxes her home, where a ''cult exiter'' named P. J. (Mr. Keitel) is waiting to wean Ruth away from her Indian guru. But as the film moves from its early mix of rapture and humor into this more serious, confrontational stage, it runs into trouble. It doesn't help that Ms. Winslet's obvious strength and beauty leave Mr. Keitel's P. J. looking overmatched (Maslin).  * ''THE HURRICANE,'' starring Denzel Washington. Directed by Norman Jewison (R, 120 minutes). The life story of Hurricane Carter, a middleweight contender who spent nearly 20 years in prison for a triple murder he didn't commit, is a big, schmaltzy ballad of a movie redeemed by Mr. Washington's moving, bone-deep portrayal of the boxer from Paterson, N.J. But the movie plays fast and loose with the facts, giving far too much credit to the members of a Canadian commune who took up Mr. Carter's cause and all but eliminating his heroic co-defendant, John Artis, from the story. And the minor characters are either saints or monsters. Yet the story of a man heroically fighting his demons and winning his freedom is still inspiring (Holden).  ''ISN'T SHE GREAT,'' starring Bette Midler, Nathan Lane, Stockard Channing, David Hyde Pierce and John Cleese. Directed by Andrew Bergman (R, 90 minutes). In this bio-pic, Ms. Midler portrays the author Jacqueline Susann, who took the lurid pulp genre to a new, sweaty level. No one is more suited to playing a tease of a diva than Ms. Midler, who can wring more comedy out of operatic self-absorption than anyone else. And Mr. Lane, who plays Irving Mansfield, Susann's husband, promoter and biggest fan, is a spark plug: his voice shows up before he does. Yet in this adaptation of the material, Susann's life is flattened, made campy and cute. Sly hostility seems to be a facet of the screenwriter Paul Rudnick's talent. But Mr. Rudnick and Mr. Bergman have so defanged ''Isn't She Great'' that it's like watching a sketch from the old ''Carol Burnett Show'' that has mildewed (Elvis Mitchell).  ''THE LIFE AND TIMES OF HANK GREENBERG,'' directed by Aviva Kempner (not rated, 90 minutes). This unabashed valentine to baseball's Hall of Fame slugger demonstrates how little mankind and some of its sports figures have advanced since the 1930's and 40's and reminds us how the persistence of bigotry stains a nation founded on ideals like religious tolerance. The 30's and 40's were the heyday of Greenberg, a son of Jewish immigrants who came out of the Bronx to star with the Detroit Tigers, threaten Babe Ruth's home run record and become the first man to win most valuable player awards at two positions, first base and left field. In blazing his trail into the Hall of Fame, the tall, handsome Greenberg became a target of anti-Semites. But his stardom, his innate decency, his work ethic and his World War II record made him a beacon of hope to many Jews. Taken as a whole, the documentary is faithful to its title, valuable as history and resonant with meaning for today (Lawrence Van Gelder).  ''MAGNOLIA,'' starring Tom Cruise, Melinda Dillon, Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy, Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly and Jason Robards. Written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson (R, 180 minutes). In ''Magnolia'' the colossally talented Mr. Anderson has set up an artfully orchestrated symphony of intersecting L.A. stories, with many of the cast members from his ''Boogie Nights'' assembled to form a charismatic ensemble. The movie is saved from its own worst ideas by the intimacy of the performances. Its single biggest surprise is Tom Cruise in the role of a strutting, obscenity-spouting cult figure named Frank Mackey (Maslin).  ''PLAY IT TO THE BONE,'' starring Woody Harrelson, Antonio Banderas and Lolita Davidovich. Directed by Ron Shelton (R, 124 minutes). This screwball sports comedy stars Mr. Harrelson (with a shaved head) and Mr. Banderas as fading middleweight boxers and best friends summoned at the last minute to fight each other as the opening act for a Las Vegas heavyweight bout. The formulaic road movie follows them with their pal and mutual ex-girlfriend (Ms. Davidovich) on their wisecracking way from Los Angeles to Las Vegas, where they fight a brutal match. The dialogue has sass, and the filmmaker's jaundiced vision of the professional boxing world is very knowing, but the relationships don't track (Holden).  * ''THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY,'' starring Matt Damon, Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Cate Blanchett and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Written and directed by Anthony Minghella (R, 135 minutes). There are diabolically smart surprises wherever you care to look in this glittering thriller. Proving that the brilliance of ''The English Patient'' was no fluke, Mr. Minghella shapes a hypnotic, sensually charged adaptation of Patricia High smith's fascinatingly reptilian murder story. The traffic-stopping cast includes Mr. Damon as the dangerous chameleon of the title and, in a star-making role, the English actor Jude Law as a rich dilettante who exerts a homoerotic magnetism. Ms. Paltrow plays the odd woman out with the shrewdness of a fine character actress, while Ms. Blanchett makes the delirious most of her role as a needy American post-debutante. As the story's odious playboy-snob, Mr. Hoffman is scene-stealingly wonderful. Gorgeously photographed in Italy by John Seale (Maslin).  * ''TITUS,'' starring Anthony Hopkins, Jessica Lange, Alan Cumming, Harry Lennix and Jonathan Rhys Meyers. Directed by Julie Taymor (R, 160 minutes). Ms. Taymor, the theater director and puppeteer who created transfixing stage pictures in ''The Lion King'' and ''Juan Darien,'' has turned Shakespeare's goriest tragedy, ''Titus Andronicus,'' into a powerful contemplation of murderous revenge enacted throughout history. Mr. Hopkins is ghoulishly funny and tragic as the title character, whose political stupidity sets in motion a devastating chain reaction of killing, torture and retaliation. Ms. Lange is Tamora, the captured Goth empress who strikes back. Although the movie's British theatrical and American film acting styles don't mesh, Ms. Taymor's vision is realized with a shattering force in time-traveling imagery that blends ancient Rome with Mussolini's Italy and contemporary cyberpunk flash (Holden).

nyt_corpus_2000.har/03/23/1186041.xml	        There is in fact a long and honorable tradition of Americans setting off to Japan to play baseball. The sport was introduced there by an American missionary in 1867, and even in the years before World War II, American players sailed across the Pacific in the off-season to give baseball seminars and play exhibition games against Japanese teams. In 1934 enormous crowds turned out to see Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig batter Japanese pitching -- and to roar ''Banzai!'' when Eiji Sawamura, a young Japanese pitcher,  struck out both men.

nyt_corpus_2000.har/04/30/1195910.xml	        When the property was sold in 1918, a stable and kennel complex was added, and the house was converted into a hunt club called the Byram River Beagle Club. (Oral histories claim it was a speakeasy during Prohibition.) About 1933, after Prohibition ended, the building became a dining club. Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz held their wedding reception there, and Babe Ruth drove up on the New York Yankees' days off, sometimes with Lefty Gomez. After 1950, the house reverted to a single-family residence.

''We need the guy who can transport us out of the sport and into the mainstream, who will take us onto the cover of Time rather than the cover of Sports Illustrated.''
nyt_corpus_2000.har/05/26/1202490.xml	        Whether or not McGwire surpasses Aaron and his 755 home runs, he has been the most phenomenal development of the past five seasons. He is the Babe Ruth of baseball's new era.
nyt_corpus_2000.har/05/28/1202825.xml	        Like baseball, all the arts need their heroes. But the art of opera, unlike baseball or hockey or skiing or even tennis, belongs to a frightening degree to custodians who choose to live in the past. ''The garland briefer than a girl's,'' A. E. Housman called the athlete's glory in a famous poem; in sports, records exist to be shattered. But the vestals of opera (critics, biographers, a vocal clique of reactionary fans) treat the starry dead like so many Babe Ruths, and the living like riffraff from a farm team in an age when the major leagues have ceased to exist.

nyt_corpus_2000.har/06/28/1210927.xml	        Over their history, the Yankees have been synonymous with home runs, but none of their Hall of Fame sluggers -- Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle and Reggie Jackson -- ever struck out in a season anywhere near as often as Sosa did the last two seasons and this season.
nyt_corpus_2000.har/07/02/1212062.xml	        Tygiel, a professor of history at San Francisco State University and the author of ''Baseball's Great Experiment: Jackie Robinson and His Legacy,'' places the sport in broad yet precise cultural contexts. He argues convincingly, for instance, that baseball became a national game because improvements in transportation and communication (railroads, the telegraph) unified the United States in the aftermath of the Civil War. Baseball became a symbol of that reunification. Tygiel also argues that the development of the social sciences and of statistics in the mid-19th century led Henry Chadwick to invent the box score and to establish methods to calculate and keep baseball records. Tygiel points out that Branch Rickey's creation of the farm system in the 1930's is coeval with the emergence of the first chain stores, which contributed to the creation of a national culture by making small towns feel they were part of a larger whole. While it is not particularly original to remark that Babe Ruth came onto the scene at the same time as radio broadcasting and the movies, Tygiel goes further by allowing that Ruth was also instrumental in the advance of public relations and advertising as businesses. He was among the first celebrities produced by those industries.
nyt_corpus_2000.har/07/02/1212084.xml	        In his tribute to Henry Aaron, Sandy Tolan delivers a solid hit. Tolan has decided to make an exploration of American racism as central to his memoir, ''Me and Hank,'' as his appreciation of the American pastime. Born and raised in Milwaukee, Tolan grew up watching Aaron lead a Braves team that won the World Series in 1957 but moved to Atlanta after the 1965 season. A loyal fan nonetheless, Tolan cheered Aaron on as, season by season, he closed in on baseball's most famous achievement: Babe Ruth's career total of 714 home runs. But the nearer Aaron came, the more hate mail he received -- menacing letters threatening to kill him should he, a black man, dare to supersede Ruth. Shocked and angered by such prejudice, the young Tolan wrote his hero a letter of support, and Aaron wrote back, thanking him for his concern. Twenty-five years later, Tolan remains perplexed that despite Aaron's formidable statistics, he is still underappreciated. Tolan, who is white, explores just how much race still matters in baseball and in the United States as he interviews, among others, Aaron and his wife and daughter; civil rights leaders, including Jesse Jackson and Andrew Young; old friends, black and white, with whom Tolan went to school; baseball players, coaches and executives like Bud Selig and Dusty Baker; and a black homeless man whom Tolan befriends. At times, Tolan can ramble too far afield, but his probing portrait reminds us that while thousands cheered, others fumed. And the cumulative impact of Tolan's documentary-like approach leaves no doubt of the true nature of Aaron's achievement, on the field and off.
nyt_corpus_2000.har/07/04/1212495.xml	        AT first glance, the streak seems to be one of those arcane achievements that only a statistics freak could know or care about. (b) Products like Bumble & Bumble Hairspray ($9 at Bumble & Bumble, 146 East 56th Street) help build the beehive and artichoke styles that adorn Waters's heroines.  2. Waters wrote his latest opus, ''Cecil B. DeMented,'' with the old movie theaters of Baltimore in mind. In a case of life mirroring art mirroring life, he shot its opening scene, a premiere gone haywire, at the Senator Theater; ''DeMented'' had its world premiere (benefiting AIDS Action Baltimore) there on Wednesday. As a boy, Waters attended birthday parties at this Art Deco landmark, where he saw ''The Wizard of Oz'' for the first time. ''Winged monkeys, a gay lion, great shoes,'' he says. ''I never understood why Dorothy wanted to go home.'' 5904 York Road, Baltimore, (410) 435-8338.

nyt_corpus_2000.har/11/19/1248729.xml	        And there is nothing more authentically Baltimorean than duckpins at Southway, an unpretentious, soothing place where Babe Ruth was photographed bowling a game as he sported a big cigar and a white golf gap. Duckpins is said to have started when Baltimore baseball players -- John J. McGraw and Wilbert Robinson, according to some versions of the story -- wanted to relax with a less risky strain on their throwing arms than the heavier ball of the tenpins game presented. They had a local carpenter make a roughly half-scale version of the larger pins and a smaller ball.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/01/07/1261171.xml	        POSSNER-Bernard Murray. We regret the passing of Bernard Murray Possner of DelRay Beach, FL on Wednesday, January 3, 2001. ''Bernie'', as he was affectionately called, was a resident of the Marine Park section of Brooklyn, NY where he helped found ''The East Highway Little League'' and ''The Kingsway Babe Ruth League.'' He was a distinguished member of the Madison Jewish Center of Brooklyn NY for many years, where his three sons were bar mitzvahed. His memberships in many charitable organizations included the Presidency of the Margorie Bregman Mandel League of the Kingsbrook Medical Center. His affiliation with the Knights of Pythias lasted over 50 years. He is survived by his beloved wife of 59-1/2 years Sylvia, his three sons Harvey, Stuart and Ivan, his ''daughter'' Donna, his two daughters-in-law Sandy and Fran, his seven grandchildren David, Ilana, Marrah, Jamie, Scott, Michelle and Billy, his sisters Henrietta and Sylvia, his beloved brother-in-law Phil, his five nieces Estelle, Joanie, Ronnie, Barbara and Beatrice, and his nephew Steven. He will surely be missed. Rest in peace, sweet prince. Graveside services held today, at 10 AM at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

The F.B.I. said it dismantled a network of forgers that created and sold up to $100 million of bogus memorabilia to fans in 15 states, including 10,000 baseballs with fraudulent signatures from the likes of Babe Ruth, Ty Cobb and Mark McGwire.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/02/11/1270137.xml	        The Yankees won their first championships in 1923 and 1927; those were Babe Ruth's Yankees. Lou Gehrig's Yankees won in 1936, a year when Joe DiMaggio established his own stardom. DiMaggio retired after the 1951 season, and for the next decade, Yogi Berra, Mickey Mantle and Whitey Ford assumed the helm of the dynasty. The Yankees teams that won in 1977 and 1978 were Thurman Munson's Yankees, Reggie Jackson's Yankees, Ron Guidry's Yankees.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/03/11/1276996.xml	        Well before ''A League of Their Own,'' there were women playing baseball. There were organized teams in the 1860's, for example, and the Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center in Little Falls has an 1868 newpaper's front page to prove it. It is part of an exhibition called ''The American Sportswoman: a Tribute to Ladies in Baseball,'' which also displays photographs (among them one of a pitcher named Jackie Mitchell, who struck out Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig in a 1912 exhibition), programs, posters and other artifacts. The exhibition runs to April 29. To mark Women's History Month, the museum will also show a documentary film, ''Running Down a Dream,'' about the basketball career of a girl from stardom at a Long Island high school to her decision to attend the University of California at Los Angeles. The showing will take place 7 p.m. Tuesday, and the filmmaker, Leandra Reilly Lardner, will speak afterward. The Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center, 8 Quarry Road, Little Falls, (973) 655-2377, www.yogiberramuseum.com, is open Wednesdays through Sundays from noon to 5 p.m. Admission is $4; $2 for students.

Some are egregious offenders, like ''The Babe Ruth Story,'' or a recent Showtime film about Rocky Marciano. Detractors picked apart boxing history in Norman Jewison's ''The Hurricane.'' nyt_corpus_2001.har/05/02/1290043.xml	        Ventura's grand slam broke a tie with Cincinnati's Ken Griffey Jr. to restore Ventura as the active leader in the category. Ventura is ninth on the career list for grand slams, one behind Hank Aaron, Babe Ruth and Dave Kingman.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/05/06/1290866.xml	        Neil J. Sullivan uses the history of Yankee Stadium to reflect the currents of change that have swept through New York in the past century, particularly in the Bronx. He is very good on the social and political background that led to the baseball boom of the 1920's. Yankee Stadium was not simply the House That Ruth Built; it resulted from the increasing wealth of the rising multiethnic fan base that attached itself to Babe Ruth. Sullivan, who teaches public affairs at Baruch College, is also good on sizing up the new stadium game as it is currently played by baseball owners around the country. ''The first point that can be held with near certainty,'' he writes, ''is that an economic investment in a stadium will not be returned''; ''wealth is not being created by the stadium so much as it is being diverted from one place to another.'' However, when it comes time to bring together the different strands of his ambitious book, Sullivan is tenuous and relies too much on secondhand material. And he repeats some of baseball's most cherished misinformation: Arnold Rothstein did not fix the 1919 World Series. ''The Diamond in the Bronx'' has many insights into the politics of the new stadium business and has some original observations about the rise of baseball in New York, but it reads like parts of two or even three books whose theses are not fully developed.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/05/10/1292058.xml	        While the nicknames Hammerin' Hank and the Sultan of Swat helped fans of yesteryear envision the home runs hit by Hank Aaron and Babe Ruth, Big Mac makes me think more about hamburgers than the record-breaking home runs slugged by Mark McGwire. The Splendid Splinter effectively depicted the lean frame of Ted Williams. But Junior fails to offer a visual account of Ken Griffey Jr. (To be fair, there are some current baseball nicknames that match up with those given to the old timers. Rocket fits Roger Clemens's rising fastball. Of course, he acquired ''Rocket'' as a rookie about 17 years ago. If Clemens were starting out today he would probably be called Clem.)

nyt_corpus_2001.har/06/05/1299177.xml	        In the 1920's, Babe Ruth was baseball's dominant player. In 1921, for example, his 59 home runs were two and a half times the total for the American League's next-best home run hitter and were more than the totals of five of the other seven teams. When Ruth hit 60 home runs in 1927, he exceeded the totals of each of the other A.L. teams.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/06/20/1303061.xml	        Funny Faces  As celebrity gatherings go, the one scheduled to begin on Friday is certainly top of the line. Among the participants are Babe Ruth, Josephine Baker, Fiorello H. La Guardia, Greta Garbo, the Marx Brothers, Mae West, Emily Post, Al Capone, Theodore Dreiser, Irving Berlin, George Gershwin and Enrico Caruso. What brings them together is ''Celebrity Caricature in America,'' an exhibition of more than 200 works on view through Aug. 31 at the New York Public Library. Organized by the National Portrait Gallery of the Smithsonian Institution and accompanied by related recordings, this show of witty images of celebrities between the 20th century's two world wars features work by artists like William Auerbach-Levy, Peggy Bacon, Ralph Barton, Miguel Covarrubias, Will Cotton, Al Frueh, Paolo Garretto and Al Hirschfeld.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/06/20/1303144.xml	        Ripken, two months from his 41st birthday, has been active in baseball off the field as well as on. nyt_corpus_2001.har/06/24/1304054.xml	        Motion pictures have always used the private lives and the defining struggles of celebrities, religious icons and beloved or notorious historical figures as ready-made stories. These biopics, of course, whether treating the exploits of Babe Ruth, Benny Goodman or Joan of Arc, were selling mythology, not biography. Like most of Hollywood's traditional fare, they were instructional tools as much as they were entertainments, and the cultural norms they validated were those of white, middle-class America. These pictures shaped and reiterated values and cultural biases not only in how stories were told but also in whose stories were told.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/06/24/1304316.xml	        I first went to Ebbets Field in 1938 when Babe Ruth was the Dodgers' first-base coach. By the time the Dodgers won the 1941 pennant, I was hooked. I liked the way the Cardinals ran the bases in those uniforms with the red piping on the sleeves, and I liked the way Stan Musial hit.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/01/1306212.xml	        There is a feel of Brigadoon to Cooperstown, the lush village of baseball and opera tucked into the middle of an idyllic nowhere in upstate New York. Here you can find gangs of sensible grown men dressed up in baseball jerseys, dreamily touring the Babe Ruth exhibits at the National Baseball Hall of Fame. Or you can find them like I did, parked in the Cooper Inn parlor one pristine Sunday morning, earnestly recalling wondrous moments of baseball games past. When I asked what brought them to town, the answer was obvious: ''Ten middle-aged guys escaping for the weekend.''
nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/01/1306212.xml	        The National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, 25 Main Street, (607) 547-7200, on the Web at www .baseballhalloffame.org, is home plate for serious fans. Highlights include Babe Ruth's Yankee Stadium locker; Mark McGwire's 62nd home run ball from 1998, when he broke Roger Maris's record; and the base stolen by Rickey Henderson in 1983, when he became the first player to steal 100 bases in three different seasons. I also liked the history of women in baseball, especially the poignant photograph of Lois Florreich of the Rockford Peaches with a bloody wound on her upper thigh -- a hazard of sliding in a skirt. General admission $9.50. Open daily 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. in summer.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/08/1307582.xml	        At the ceremony, Connor, who held the record for career homers until Babe Ruth bettered his mark in 1921, was honored in speeches by baseball  historians, including Mark Alvarez, the publications director for the Society for American Baseball Research. Following the ceremony, a barbershop quartet sang period songs, there was a reading of Ernest Thayer's poem ''Casey at the Bat'' and a game of vintage base ball (the correct 19th-century spelling) was played at nearby Hamilton Park.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/08/1307810.xml	        HIS assault on McGwire's record, with Ripken's retirement as backdrop, will be a hanging curve to the pious press. Bonds will not just be swiping the home run mark, but a piece of baseball's soul. This is a reprise of the nonsense Roger Maris faced while chasing Babe Ruth's standard of 60 homers in 1961. The charismatic Ruth was the proper man to own the mark forevermore, it was often written, and Maris, a dour North Dakotan, was not worthy of such distinction. To some, Bonds's owning of the record would be considered somewhere between distasteful and disastrous.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/09/1308000.xml	        American baseball has long been a part of Japanese culture. In the early 1870's Horace Wilson, an American hired to teach in Japan, introduced baseball to the country. In 1934 a select American team that included Babe Ruth visited Japan and organized games against an all-Japan team. This marked the beginning of pro baseball in Japan. During World War II, baseball was considered ''an adversarial sport'' and suppressed. The game was restored during the American occupation, and professional baseball quickly became a mainstay of popular entertainment in postwar Japan.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/09/1308071.xml	        It took Roger Maris 34 years to break Babe Ruth's record for most home runs in a season, and 37 years for Mark McGwire to break Maris's mark, with his 70 home runs in 1998. Now, just three seasons later, this most venerated of baseball records is again under siege, this time by Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/12/1308698.xml	        The monuments honor Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle and Miller Huggins; the plaques celebrate DiMaggio, Jacob Ruppert, Ed Barrow, Joe McCarthy, Casey Stengel, Yogi Berra, Whitey Ford, Billy Martin, Don Mattingly, Roger Maris, Phil Rizzuto, Thurman Munson, Elston Howard, Bill Dickey, Lefty Gomez, Allie Reynolds and Mel Allen. Two other plaques commemorate visits by Pope Paul VI in 1965 and Pope John Paul II in 1979.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/12/1308698.xml	        John Henry (Pop) Lloyd, manager-first baseman of the 1930 Lincoln Giants, was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1977, but most Yankee fans have probably never heard of him. In his 1996 book, ''I Was Right On Time,'' Buck O'Neil, now a member of the Hall of Fame Veterans Committee and the chairman of the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum in Kansas City, Mo., wrote that Babe Ruth once called Lloyd ''the greatest player of all time'' and that Connie Mack described Lloyd as the equal of Honus Wagner as a shortstop.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/13/1308843.xml	        Even if no game is scheduled while you're in town, take the short walk (following the baseballs painted on the sidewalk) from Camden Yards to the nearby Babe Ruth Birthplace and Museum, the narrow red brick row house where the Sultan of Swat was born in 1895. Although the Babe played for his hometown team (then in the minor leagues) for only a portion of the 1914 season, the memorabilia collected here takes him through his glory years with the Yankees -- and reminds die-hard (though currently downhearted) Oriole fans of past triumphs.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/25/1312082.xml	        Jackson went on to bat .356 over a 13-year career, the third-best career average ever. Babe Ruth said that he had modeled his swing after Jackson's fluid stroke. Another remarkable element to Jackson's career is that for much of it he used just one bat, which he called Black Betsy, a 34 1/2-inch, 40-ounce instrument that was slightly and oddly curved, like some pickles. The bat, one of the prize pieces of sports memorabilia, will go on sale for the first time in an Internet auction that begins Friday on eBay, with a minimum bid of $500,000.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/07/25/1312082.xml	        The most valuable bat before Jackson's was the one that the dying Babe Ruth leaned on instead of a cane at home plate on the memorable Babe Ruth Day at Yankee Stadium, June 13, 1948, said Barry Halper, the noted collector who is a consultant to Real Legends.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/08/26/1320051.xml	        Offering the final segment of the Hampton Library's ''Fridays at 5 Series: Author! Author!'' Amanda Smith, the granddaughter of Joseph P. Kennedy, will discuss her book, ''Joseph P. Kennedy: Hostage to Fortune'' (Viking, January 2001). In editing her grandfather's letters housed in the John F. Kennedy Library and additional material that she discovered in an abandoned garret on Long Island, Ms. Smith sought to create a portrait of her grandfather as ''father, speculator, film producer, bootlegger, chairman, ambassador, philanderer, philanthropist, kingmaker.'' Working with correspondence from Babe Ruth, Marlene Dietrich, William Randolph Hearst and J. Edgar Hoover and excerpts from Joseph P. Kennedy's diaries while he was ambassador to the Court of St. James, Ms. Smith examined her grandfather's perspective on the 20th century and described how he hoped to create a dynasty (631) 537-0015.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/09/29/1329227.xml	        Five days ago, Bonds hit his 65th and 66th home runs against Middlebrook in the pitcher's first career start. The walk handed Bonds his 163rd base on balls of the season, breaking McGwire's National League mark of 162. The all-time record is held by Babe Ruth, who walked 170 times in 1923.
nyt_corpus_2001.har/09/30/1329640.xml	        1927: BABE'S BIG BLAST Babe Ruth slammed his 60th home run of the season and broke his own single-season record of 59 home runs set six years earlier. Ruth, who hit his final 11 homers at Yankee Stadium, by himself outhomered every team in the American league. The blast came in the eighth inning of a tie game against the Washington Senators, with a man on base. Ruth drove a 1-1 curveball from the left-hander Tom Zachary into the right-field bleachers near the foul line at Yankee Stadium, giving the Yankees a 4-2 victory.

Roger Maris hit 61 homers in 1961, and that mark stood for 37 years. McGwire erased it in 1998 during a memorable long-ball duel with Sammy Sosa, who hit 66.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/10/07/1331811.xml	        Bonds has an .860 slugging and .515 on-base for a total of 1.375. The only better total, according to the Elias Sports Bureau, was Babe Ruth's 1.379 in 1920. Ruth also had the second- and third-highest totals, 1.359 in 1921 and 1.309 in 1923. When Mark McGwire hit 70 home runs in 1998, he totaled 1.222, which is the 13th highest. The previous highest total for a National League hitter was Rogers Hornsby's 1.245 in 1925.

nyt_corpus_2001.har/10/11/1332772.xml	        The singing of ''The Star Spangled Banner'' at sporting events was first documented at the 1918 World Series, when the United States was involved in World War I. It was the Chicago Cubs against the Boston Red Sox, and Babe Ruth pitched a 1-0 six-hitter before only 19,274 fans in Comiskey Park. The Cubs had moved across town from their smaller ballpark, now known as Wrigley Field, to seek greater attendance at a larger park. But the stadium was less than half-filled, demonstrating that, like today, many fans' minds were elsewhere.

Mark McGwire snared his 70th 37 years after Maris. Both Maris and McGwire broke the record in expansion years, with players facing an array of bad pitching. The gap between the good player and the mediocre player tends to widen in expansion years.

But Nascar's founding family, the Frances, has always seemed fearful of promoting characters that might become bigger than the sport and thus have the power to get a better deal from management by threatening to create a rival league.

nyt_corpus_2002.har/01/06/1357257.xml	        The rivalry between Boston and New York, between the Red Sox and the Yankees, is one of the oldest and bitterest in sports, and Boston has been on the short end ever since the fateful moment in 1919 when Harry Frazee sold Babe Ruth, then a Red Sox pitcher, to the Yankees for $25,000 and three i.o.u.'s so he could finance a Broadway musical. This was the beginning, many Bostonians are convinced, of the dread Curse of the Bambino, a spell of inferiority and World Series winlessness that has hung over their city ever since. If you acknowledge the Curse (and the Red Sox loss to the Yankees in the 2000 playoffs made confirmed believers of many who had only been slightly paranoid before), then to have your home team owned by The New York Times only confirms your sense that the universe is deeply and hurtfully unfair.

nyt_corpus_2002.har/01/27/1362546.xml	        Adorned with votive candles, flowers and handwritten prayers, many of New York City's firehouses seem like red brick chapels since Sept. 11. BROTHERHOOD (American Express/Sterling, $29.95) memorializes these improvisational offerings and gives a glimpse into the firefighters' lives after the tragedy. With more than 300 images by over 60 photographers, the collection includes a prologue by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and a foreword by his fire commissioner, Thomas Von Essen. A lively introduction by Frank McCourt reflects on the civic connection we feel with firefighters, whether we see them shopping at the local deli or racing past on a fire truck. The book is organized into several thematic sections, like ''The Fallen,'' which shows snapshot displays of lost firefighters pasted up in firehouses, and ''Grief,'' a showcase of the shrines that sprouted on the city's sidewalks in their memory. In ''The Living,'' two adjacent black-and-white portraits of older firefighters, their faces stoic beneath leather helmets, convey a sense of quiet perseverance. The personalized spaces within the firehouses -- an old poster of Babe Ruth, a musty library of fire records more than a century old -- resonate as powerfully as the portraits of the firefighters themselves. But it's the book's least prominent feature that is also its most stirring: from cover to cover, in tiny, fine silver lettering, the names of the fallen form an unbroken chain across the bottom of each page.

He was a gentleman bandit who robbed scores of banks without firing a shot, sometimes while disguised as a policeman or a telegram messenger. He was a brainy ne'er-do-well who escaped from prison three times, read Schopenhauer for fun and loved to stroll through the roses at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Known variously as the Babe Ruth of Bank Robbers, Willie the Actor and Slick Willie, the Brooklyn native claimed to have stolen $2 million during his 25-year career in robbery.

nyt_corpus_2002.har/03/31/1379971.xml	        Baseball may now have an immutably laid-back and borderline-somnolent image, but it wasn't always thus. The game actually burst out of the womb of war snarling and spoiling for action. Walt Whitman thought it fit perfectly with the ''snap, go, fling of the American atmosphere,'' and Mark Twain found it a symbol of ''the drive, and push, and rush and struggle of the raging, tearing, booming 19th century!'' -- a picture that suits Ty Cobb to a T, as he stormed each base and grabbed for runs like a combination rebel general and robber baron, but not Babe Ruth, who cruised the diamond like a millionaire inspecting the estate on his way to the evening (and nighttime and morning) pleasures as depicted graphically by Jerome Holtzman.
nyt_corpus_2002.har/03/31/1379974.xml	        The slow, wrenching, devastating demise of Gehrig is illuminated in Richard J. Tofel's excellent book about the 1939 Yankees, ''A Legend in the Making.'' The 1927 Yankees are generally regarded as one of baseball's greatest teams, with a Murderers' Row lineup that included Babe Ruth and a young Gehrig. And often the Yankees of 1961, the Oakland Athletics of 1972-74, the Cincinnati Reds of 1975-76 and the Yankees of 1998 are compared with the '27 team. But the '39 Yankees may have been better than any of them, finishing the season with a record of 106-45; Connie Mack, the legendary manager of the Philadelphia Athletics, concluded at the time that the '39 Yankees were history's greatest team. As Tofel notes, that group of Yankees essentially established the franchise as a dynasty, becoming the first team to win three consecutive championships, before winning a fourth straight title in 1939.

nyt_corpus_2002.har/04/07/1382196.xml	        This is clever, in that the Baby Ruth brigade says it ''embraces'' the ''association with baseball'' but is careful to avoid saying that it embraces its association with Babe Ruth himself.
nyt_corpus_2002.har/04/07/1382196.xml	        The fact, according to records of the ''heritage,'' is that when the Curtiss Candy Company of Chicago introduced the candy bar, in 1921, it denied having named the nutty confection bar for Babe Ruth. After the candy company began a ''strong promotion,'' as recalled in ''The Life That Ruth Built,'' by Marshall Smelser (Times Books, 1975), Ruth challenged it. ''Ruth's protests were rebuffed,'' Smelser wrote, and ''he countered by founding the George H. Ruth Candy Company.'' Ruth tried to register the phrase ''Babe Ruth Home Run Bar'' for his candy. But the Curtiss company opposed it, and the patent office turned down the Babe's application.
nyt_corpus_2002.har/04/07/1382196.xml	        So, as the manufacturers of the candy bar then would have had people believe, there was no more association with Babe Ruth than he had with Hershey's Kisses, or Tootsie Roll. They'd have you believe the premise that such an association with the Babe was worth nothing more than a Snicker. You'd have to be from Mars to swallow that one.
nyt_corpus_2002.har/04/07/1382196.xml	        The Curtiss company's official position on the name Baby Ruth was this: The candy bar first appeared in 1921, and this was ''some years before Babe Ruth, the ballplayer, became famous. The similarity of names, therefore, is purely coincidental.'' The current Web site for Baby Ruth, the ''chewy nougat,'' reiterates the same.
nyt_corpus_2002.har/04/07/1382196.xml	        The history books belie this. Babe Ruth was already one of the most famous people in America by 1921. The year before the Baby Ruth candy bar began getting stuck in people's bicuspids, Ruth set the sports world on its ear with his record-shattering 54 home runs, in 1920. The year before that, in 1919, he hit a then-amazing and record-shattering 29 home runs. By 1921, the reference book ''Urban Legends'' states, Ruth's name ''was featured more prominently on the front pages of afternoon newspapers in America than President Harding.''
nyt_corpus_2002.har/04/10/1382833.xml	        Henderson has accomplished much more than the ordinary player. Last season he reached the 3,000-hit mark, and he broke career records held by Babe Ruth (walks) and Ty Cobb (runs). When he has played in 57 games for the Boston Red Sox this season, he will be fourth on the career list for games played.

nyt_corpus_2002.har/04/28/1387716.xml	        Discovery Channel Ducks are restored DUKW's, open-air, canopied amphibious vehicles built by General Motors to carry troops in the Allied invasions of Sicily and northern France. Constellation and the National Aquarium. The tour visits the neighborhoods of Federal Hill, Mount Vernon, Little Italy and Fells Point, where the duck enters the Inner Harbor for a 20-minute cruise.

nyt_corpus_2002.har/05/12/1391670.xml	        The first unfulfilled goal Mr. Masur singled out was his failure to provide a ''lovable time'' for the orchestra and its audiences in the summer. The Philharmonic is living out the reverse of the Curse of the Bambino. Just as the Boston Red Sox have suffered through long decades for letting Babe Ruth go to the New York Yankees, the Philharmonic, having taken a pass on the Tanglewood Festival in western Massachusetts in 1936, has watched with increasing horror as the Boston Symphony has parlayed it into the premier summer music event in the nation.
nyt_corpus_2002.har/05/12/1391899.xml	        No matter what, Bonds will never be the No. 1 player. Babe Ruth will always be No. 1, simply because he not only slugged 714 home runs, he also had a dazzling 94-46 record for the Red Sox as the American League's best left-handed pitcher before he was a Yankee outfielder. Nobody else has even come close to both hitting and pitching that well.

The highlight is the lathes, where cylindrical hunks of wood become recognizable bats in just 30 seconds, as knives carve the rapidly spinning wood down to size, spewing wood chips as children watch from behind a plexiglass shield.
